Sec. 18-161. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ACCESSORY USES 

Sec. 18-162. - General provisions for accessory uses. 
(a)  An accessory use shall be a use customarily incidental to a main use. A use listed in Part II to Part XIII of Section 18-160 may be an accessory use if the director determines that the use is customarily incidental to a main use and otherwise complies with this section. Except as otherwise provided in this article, an accessory use shall comply with all regulations applicable to the main use. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, an accessory use shall be located on the same lot as the main use. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, an accessory use listed in Section 18-160 is subject to the following area restrictions. If the use is conducted outside, it may not occupy more than five percent of the area of the lot containing the main use. If the use is conducted inside, it may not occupy more than five percent of the floor area of the main use. Any use which exceeds these area restrictions is considered to be a main use. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided in this division, an accessory use is permitted in any district in which the main use to which it is accessory is permitted. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.201(a); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-163. - Accessory community center-Private. 
(a)  A private community center shall not be operated as a place of public meeting or as a business. 
(b)  This accessory use need not be located on the same lot as the main use. 
(c)  The area restrictions in Section 18-162 do not apply to this use. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.201(b); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-164. - Accessory game court-Private. 
(a)  This accessory use may occupy up to 50 percent of the area of the lot containing the main use. 
(b)  This accessory use need not be located on the same lot as the main use. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.201(b); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-165. - Accessory outside storage. 
(a)  A person shall not place, store, or maintain outside for a period in excess of 24 hours, an item which is not: 
(1)  Customarily used or stored outside; or 
(2)  Made of a material that is resistant to damage or deterioration from exposure to the outside environment. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, accessory outside storage is not permitted in the front yard or on an unenclosed front porch of a residential building or a carport. 
(c)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (b) of this section that the item is: 
(1)  An operable motor vehicle parked in a manner that meets off-street parking regulations for residential uses contained in Section 18-597; 
(2)  A boat, trailer, or recreational vehicle parked in a manner that meets off-street parking regulations for residential uses contained in Section 18-597; 
(3)  Landscaping or other ornamental structures placed in the front yard or on a front porch for landscaping purposes, or lawn furniture made of a material that is resistant to damage or deterioration from exposure to the outside environment; 
(4)  Located on an unenclosed front porch and not visible from the street. 
(d)  A person shall not use more than five percent of the lot area of a premises for accessory outside storage in a residential district. The area occupied by an operable motor vehicle parked in a manner that meets off-street parking regulations for residential uses contained in Section 18-597 is not counted when calculating the area occupied by accessory outside storage. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.201(b); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2223, § 1(A), 12-28-92; Ord. No. 3160, § 5, 3-8-11; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-166. - Golf safety net. 
(a)  Golf safety nets may be permitted only on lots whose side or rear yard abut a golf course or golf driving range or are across the street from a golf course or golf driving range. 
(b)  Golf safety nets may be erected on property adjacent to or across the street from the golf course or golf driving range. The restriction in Section 18-162 requiring an accessory use to be located on the same lot as the main use does not apply to this use. 
(c)  A person shall not erect or maintain a golf safety net more than 60 feet above grade when located in the rear or side yard. Golf safety nets are prohibited in the front yard. 
(d)  In the event a development permit and specific use permit is approved with golf safety net standards different from the standards in this section, the standards established in the development permit and specific use permit review process shall control. 
(e)  Golf safety nets may not be located within a floodplain easement without consideration of flooding conditions and as approved by the floodplain administrator. 
(f)  The location of a golf safety net shall comply with all visual obstruction regulations contained in Section 18-567. 
(g)  Flags, signs, banners and other appurtenances are prohibited from being attached to the support structure or netting. 
(h)  Golf safety nets shall be constructed in accordance with the following minimum standards: 
(1)  All golf safety nets require a building permit. 
(2)  Support posts and netting shall be consistent in all detail, including height, color and style, with existing golf safety nets surrounding an adjacent golf course or driving range, if any. 
(3)  All golf safety nets shall be constructed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations. 
(4)  Support posts shall be constructed of rust-resistant metal approved by a structural engineer and shall meet all requirements of the city's Building Code and all other applicable codes. 
(5)  Netting material shall be black in color and of a quality designed for the purpose of obstructing golf balls. Netting shall also be designed to withstand the area's climate conditions and shall meet all requirements of the city's Building Code and all other applicable codes. 
(6)  Support structures should be fitted with a device, such as a halyard, that allows the net panel(s) to be removed for repair or storage. 
(i)  Golf safety nets shall be maintained and repaired by the property owner in accordance with the following minimum standards: 
(1)  Any missing or broken support post that was a component of the original design of the golf safety net shall be repaired or replaced with similar material. 
(2)  Torn netting which no longer serves the intended purpose shall be repaired or replaced with similar material. 
(Ord. No. 3020, § 3, 12-18-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-167. - Home occupation. 
(a)  All home occupations shall comply with all of the following standards and requirements: 
(1)  The home occupation can only be conducted by the residents of the dwelling. No employees of the home occupation may conduct business at the residence. 
(2)  The activities conducted at the site shall be contained totally within the principal structure used as a residence. No garages or accessory structures shall be used for this purpose. 
(3)  The home occupation shall clearly be incidental and secondary to the use of the dwelling unit as a residence and shall not change the character thereof. 
(4)  There shall be no interior alterations not customarily allowed for the use of the dwelling as a residence. 
(5)  There shall be no exterior alteration or addition to the home that alters the residential appearance of the premises or creates a separate entrance to the premises except as may be required or allowed by state law. 
(6)  The home occupation shall not generate any adverse impacts such as, but not limited to, noise, vibrations, smoke, dust, odors, heat, glare or interference with radio or television transmissions in the area noticeable at/or beyond the property line. 
(7)  No toxic, explosive, flammable, radioactive, or other hazardous materials, including ammunition, as defined by the International Building Code or the International Fire Code of the City of Thornton, shall be used, sold, or stored on the site for the use and in association with the home occupation. 
(8)  There shall be no outside storage of any type as part of the home occupation. 
(9)  There shall be no outside uses associated with a home occupation anywhere on the lot. 
(10)  No home occupation shall disrupt the residential character of the neighborhood, particularly with numerous cars parked in the neighborhood. 
(11)  Performance of professional sales and services on the site as a home occupation will be limited to no more than one pupil, client or customer at a time. 
(12)  No home occupation shall endanger the health, safety or welfare of the occupants of the residence or the neighborhood. 
(b)  Family child care home facilities allowed as home day care operations shall be regulated as defined by the state and not by this Code. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.201(b); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2718, § 2, 7-10-02; Ord. No. 2728, § 2, 9-10-02; Ord. No. 2968, § 1, 11-14-06; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3439, § 2, 6-13-17) 
Sec. 18-168. - Occasional sales-Garage sales. 
(a)  A person shall sell tangible personal property only on the premises of the owner or lessee of the premises where the sale is conducted, and the owner or lessee shall be responsible for the tangible personal property at the time of the sale. 
(b)  A person shall not sell merchandise acquired solely for the purpose of resale at an occasional sale. 
(c)  A person shall not conduct an occasional sale for a duration of more than three consecutive calendar days. 
(d)  A person shall not conduct more than four occasional sales on a premises during any 12-month period. 
(e)  The area restrictions in Section 18-162 do not apply to this accessory use. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.201(b); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2969, § 1, 11-14-06, eff. 1-1-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3439, § 3, 6-13-17) 
Sec. 18-169. - Private stables. 
(a)  A private stable is permitted only on a lot at least one acre in area (43,560 square feet) and a person may keep only the number of horses permitted for the following lot areas: 
(1)  At least one acre but less than two acres, two horses; and 
(2)  For lots over two acres, a maximum of four horses. 
(b)  A private stable shall include a pen or corral containing at least 800 square feet for each animal with a stable under a roof containing at least 100 square feet for each animal. 
(c)  A stable shall have proper drainage and other facilities so as not to create offensive odors, insect or rodent breeding, or other nuisances. 
(d)  A pen, corral, fences, or similar enclosures shall have a minimum front setback of 50 feet and a minimum side and rear setback of 30 feet from the property line. In addition, they may not be located any closer than 100 feet to the dwelling on premises. 
(e)  The area restrictions in Section 18-162 do not apply to this accessory use. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.201(b); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-170. - Solar collectors. 
(a)  Ground-mounted or freestanding solar collectors may not be located in the required front yard. 
(b)  The area restrictions specified in Section 18-162 do not apply to roof-mounted solar collectors. 
(c)  The commercial sale of converted solar energy is prohibited. No accessory solar collector shall be used as a commercial enterprise. 
(d)  Before any building permit may be issued for a solar collector, where it is to be interconnected with the local public utility company so that excess power produced by the solar collector can be fed into the utility lines, evidence of approval from the local utility company shall be submitted. 
(Ord. No. 3132, § 65, 5-11-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-171. - Swimming pool-Private. 
(a)  No private swimming pool may be operated as a business, except private swimming lessons may be given under the home occupation use. 
(b)  No private swimming pool may be maintained in such a manner as to be a hazard or obnoxious to adjacent property. 
(c)  A private swimming pool shall be surrounded by a fence constructed in such a manner as to prevent access by unauthorized persons, as required in Chapter 10. 
(d)  No private swimming pool may be located in the required front yard. 
(e)  The area restrictions in Section 18-162 do not apply to this use. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.201(b); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-172. - Wind energy conversion systems-WECS. 
(a)  Before any building permit may be issued for a WECS, where it is to be interconnected with the local public utility company so that excess power produced by the WECS can be fed into the utility lines, evidence of approval from the Colorado Public Utilities Commission and local utility company shall be submitted. 
(b)  In all districts where this accessory use is permitted, a person may erect one WECS that exceeds the maximum height permitted in the district, if the WECS: 
(1)  Does not exceed 75 feet in height; and 
(2)  Is set back an additional 12 inches from the required front, side and rear yards for each additional 12 inches of height above the maximum height permitted in the district. 
(c)  No WECS may be located in the required front yard. 
(d)  The minimum distance between any point on the ground and any protruding blade utilized on a WECS shall be a minimum of 15 feet as measured at the lowest point of the arc of the blade. Greater clearance may be required in areas where oversize vehicles may travel. 
(e)  Climbing access to the WECS tower shall be limited by either a fence six feet in height around the base of the tower with a locking portal, or by placing tower climbing apparatus no closer than 12 feet to the ground. Portal locks shall be accessible by authorized city personnel. 
(f)  Cables, ropes or wires used to secure the WECS shall be appropriately marked to prevent accidental bodily harm. 
(g)  Clearly visible warning signs shall be posted to warn of electrical and other hazards associated with the WECS. These signs shall be in English and Spanish. 
(h)  All WECS shall be equipped with the following: 
(1)  Automatic over-speed controls that are designed to render the system inoperable when winds are blowing in excess of the speeds for which the machine was designed. 
(2)  Manual shutdown features that allow the WECS to be manually shutdown in the event of structural or mechanical failure of any part of the system. 
(i)  Commercial sale of converted wind energy is prohibited. No WECS shall be used as a commercial enterprise. 
(j)  All WECS shall be maintained in safe working order. A yearly inspection shall be made by a private entity and shall certify to the city the safety and maintenance of the WECS. city inspectors shall have the right to enter the premises on which a WECS is located, in the company of the owner or the owner's agent, at any reasonable time, to inspect the system. In the event repairs or alterations are needed, the property owner or the property owner's agent shall have 30 days to complete the work. 
(k)  In districts where maximum height is limited to 75 feet or less, roof or building-mounted wind energy conversion systems may project to a maximum height of 75 feet in total (combined building height and wind energy conversion system). In districts where the maximum height is greater than 75 feet, roof or building-mounted wind energy conversion systems may project above the structure to the maximum allowed height specified in the district regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.201(b); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3132, § 65, 5-11-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-173. - Accessory dwelling unit. 
    Accessory dwelling units are permitted for single-family detached dwellings subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Any request to incorporate accessory dwelling units in a new development must be received by the city at the time of application for a conceptual site plan or planned development district zoning. 
(2)  Accessory dwelling units may be located within the principal dwelling unit, attached to the principal dwelling unit, or located separately on the same lot as the principal dwelling unit. 
(3)  Accessory dwelling units shall comply with all established setbacks for the principal dwelling unit. 
(4)  Only one accessory dwelling unit is allowed per lot. 
(5)  Accessory dwelling units shall utilize the same utility connections as the primary residence. 
(6)  Any accessory dwelling unit shall meet the same development standards required for the principal dwelling unit. 
(7)  A certificate of occupancy (CO) will only be granted to an accessory dwelling unit after a CO has been granted to the principal dwelling unit. 
(8)  Required parking shall be located on the same lot as the principal dwelling unit and identified on the site plan required as part of a minor development permit. 
(9)  Size requirements. 
a.  The minimum size for an accessory dwelling unit shall be 500 square feet. 
b.  The maximum size for an accessory dwelling unit shall be 1,000 square feet or 50% of the gross floor area of the primary residence, whichever is less. 
c.  For the purposes of this subsection, area calculations shall exclude any garage, porch or similar area. 
d.  The area restrictions specified in Section 18-162 do not apply to this accessory use. 
(10)  The property owner, as reflected in title records and evidenced by voter registration, vehicle registration or other similar means, must occupy either the principal dwelling unit or accessory dwelling unit. 
(11)  Home occupations are prohibited within an accessory dwelling unit. 
(12)  Manufactured homes, campers, camper buses, travel trailers and recreational vehicles are prohibited as accessory dwelling units. 
(13)  Deed restrictions. 
a.  Prior to the issuance of a building permit for an accessory dwelling unit, the property owner shall file with the county clerk and recorder a declaration of restrictions to the deed for the property where the accessory dwelling unit will be located. At a minimum, the restrictions shall state: 
1.  The accessory dwelling unit shall not be sold separately from the principal dwelling unit, nor shall the lot on which it is situated be subdivided unless such subdivision has been approved by the city in accordance with all provisions of Chapter 18 of the Code; 
2.  The accessory dwelling unit shall comply with an approved minor development permit; 
3.  The certificate of occupancy for the accessory dwelling unit shall be in effect only so long as either the principal dwelling unit or the accessory dwelling unit is occupied by the owner of record; and 
4.  All restrictions run with the land and are binding upon any successor in ownership of the property. 
b.  It shall be unlawful for any property owner to fail to comply with the deed restrictions. 
c.  The deed restrictions shall lapse upon removal of the accessory dwelling unit. Upon verification of removal of an accessory dwelling unit, the city shall record appropriate documentation releasing such encumbrance. The property owner shall pay all required recording fees, and it shall be the property owner's responsibility to ensure that such recording is successfully completed. 
(Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3183, § 2, 10-11-11; Ord. No. 3233, § 1, 4-9-13) 
Secs. 18-174-18-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - AGRICULTURAL USES 

Sec. 18-191. - Animal production. 
(a)  A person shall not operate this use on an area less than five acres. 
(b)  The area used for the production of animals shall be set back from the front, side and rear property line a minimum of 100 feet. 
(c)  The area used for the production of large animals, which includes but are not limited to pigs, cows, sheep, goats, and horses, shall not be located closer than 2,640 feet to any residential zoning district, 1,320 feet to any commercial zoning district, and 660 feet to any industrial zoning district. 
(d)  Structures may be erected for a private stable, pen, barn, shed or silo for raising, treating, and storing products raised on the premises. A dwelling unit is also permitted. 
(e)  Standings under roofed stables shall be made of a material that provides for proper drainage so as not to create offensive odors, insect or rodent breeding, or other nuisances. 
(f)  Adequate drainage facilities and other improvements shall be provided so as to protect any adjacent river, stream, or other body of water from pollution or other environmental degradation. 
(g)  The keeping of horses is subject to the requirements under the private stable accessory use, except that one additional horse may be kept for each additional acre over five acres. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.202; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-192. - Commercial greenhouse and nursery. 
(a)  A person shall not operate this use on an area less than five acres. 
(b)  Retail sales are permitted as a part of the commercial greenhouse and nursery use if the sales are conducted in compliance with the following: 
(1)  Up to 100 percent of the total greenhouse floor area may be devoted to retail sales activities during an occasional greenhouse sale. No more than four occasional greenhouse sales may be conducted during any 12-month period. Each occasional greenhouse sale shall be limited in duration to no more than three consecutive calendar days. 
(2)  Retail sales are permitted at all times as part of the commercial greenhouse and nursery use when the retail sales area does not exceed ten percent of the total greenhouse floor area. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.202; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3132, § 27, 5-11-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-193. - Commercial stable. 
(a)  A commercial stable is permitted only on a lot at least five acres in area and a person may keep only five horses on a five-acre area, plus one additional horse for each additional acre. 
(b)  A commercial stable shall include a pen or corral containing at least 800 square feet for each animal with a stable under a roof containing at least 100 square feet for each animal. 
(c)  A commercial stable shall have sufficient drainage and other facilities so as not to create offensive odors, insect or rodent breeding, or other nuisances. 
(d)  Approved drainage facilities and other improvements shall be provided so as to protect any adjacent river, stream, or other body of water from pollution or other environmental damage. 
(e)  Pens, corrals, or similar enclosures shall have a minimum front setback of 50 feet and a minimum side setback of 30 feet from the property line. In addition, they may not be located any closer than 100 feet to the dwelling on premises or 100 feet to any property line. This provision does not apply to perimeter fences which may be located along the property line. 
(f)  This use does not permit sales, auctions, or similar trading activities. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.202; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-194. - Crop production. 
(a)  A person shall not operate this use on an area less than five acres, unless authorized by C.R.S. § 35-61-104 for industrial hemp cultivation for commercial purposes. 
(b)  Structures may be erected for a private pen, barn, shed or silo for the treating and storing of products raised on the premises. 
(c)  Crop products include but are not limited to vegetables, fruits, trees, and grains. 
(d)  This use may be conducted in all districts as a limited use, subject to the following: 
(1)  The area is at least five acres, unless authorized by C.R.S. § 35-61-104 for industrial hemp cultivation for research and development purposes, in which instance the area utilized shall not exceed ten acres; 
(2)  Crops are limited to grains and field forage crops, unless authorized by C.R.S. § 35-61-104 for industrial hemp cultivation purposes; 
(3)  No structure not otherwise permitted by the zoning district may be placed on the site; 
(4)  Equipment used in crop production may not be stored on the site; and 
(5)  Grazing of animals is not permitted unless a temporary use permit is granted under provisions in Section 18-53. 
(e)  This use does not include gardening as typically practiced by individual homeowners on residential lots. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.202; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3249, § 2, 7-9-13) 
Sec. 18-195. - Community garden. 
(a)  This use may be conducted as a main or accessory use. 
(1)  Main use. On any vacant parcel or tract, this use may be conducted as a main use unless said parcel or tract is restricted from such use by a notation on the plat. 
(2)  Accessory use. On lots developed with other than a single-family use, community gardens shall be located in the side or rear yards. The area limitations in Section 18-162 do not apply to this use. 
(b)  Community gardens shall be less than five acres in size. 
(c)  Community gardens shall not be operated as a commercial venture. 
(d)  Community gardens shall be maintained free of weeds throughout the year. 
(e)  The community garden may have one sign kiosk that shall not exceed 30 square feet in size or six feet in height. Any other signs shall be in accordance with Article VII of the Development Code. 
(f)  Where a community garden abuts a residentially-zoned parcel occupied by a residential use, there shall be a minimum five-foot setback between the garden or farm area and the property line. 
(g)  Structures 120 square feet or smaller are allowed as an accessory to community gardens, regardless of whether the community garden is a main or accessory use. Structures shall comply with the setback requirements of the zoning district. 
(h)  Temporary greenhouses or hoop houses constructed with fabric or plastic walls and roof and that are less than five feet in height are permitted without a permit. Traditional greenhouses are considered a structure and require a permit unless they are 120 square feet or smaller. 
(i)  Exterior lighting for a community garden is not permitted in or adjacent to residential zoning districts. Lighting shall comply with the requirements of Section 18-568. 
(j)  Small farm tractors or other implements of husbandry are allowed in conjunction with a community garden from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
(k)  Community gardens shall be designed so that erosion or drainage problems do not result due to the exposed soil. 
(l)  Fencing shall comply with the setback requirements for the zoning district and with the requirements of Section 18-565. 
(m)  A temporary use permit for a seasonal sales stand is required for any on-site sale of produce, including fruits, flowers, vegetables, or ornamental plants. 
(Ord. No. 3144, § 41, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3188, § 2, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 3439, § 4, 6-13-17) 
Secs. 18-196-18-205. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INDUSTRIAL USES 

Sec. 18-206. - General provisions for industrial uses. 
(a)  A high risk or hazardous industrial use, as defined in this chapter, is permitted by specific use permit only. 
(b)  The following uses, activities, operations, and processes are declared to be high risk or hazardous industrial uses; however, this list shall not be considered exclusive: 
(1)  Asphalt or asphalt products. 
(2)  Alcoholic beverages. 
(3)  Brick, tile, or clay. 
(4)  Cement. 
(5)  Charcoal, lampblack, or fuel briquettes. 
(6)  Chemicals, including, acetylene, aniline dyes, ammonia, carbide, caustic soda, cellulose, chlorine, carbon black or bone black, cleaning or polishing preparations, creosote, exterminating agents, hydrogen or oxygen, industrial alcohol, potash, plastic materials or synthetic resins, rayon yarns, or hydrochloric, picric, or sulfuric acids or derivatives. 
(7)  Coal, coke, or tar products. 
(8)  Excelsior or packing materials. 
(9)  Fertilizers. 
(10)  Gelatin, glue, or size. 
(11)  Graphite or graphite products. 
(12)  Gypsum. 
(13)  Heavy metal casting or foundry products including ornamental iron works or similar products. 
(14)  Insecticides, fungicides, disinfectants, or related industrial or household chemical compounds. 
(15)  Linoleum or oil cloth. 
(16)  Lumber, plywood, veneer, or similar wood products. 
(17)  Matches. 
(18)  Miscellaneous metal alloys or foil, including solder, pewter, brass, bronze, or tin, lead, gold foil, or similar products. 
(19)  Paint, varnishes, or turpentine. 
(20)  Paper. 
(21)  Porcelain products including bathroom or kitchen equipment or similar products. 
(22)  Raw plastics. 
(23)  Rubber, natural or synthetic, including tires, tubes, or similar products. 
(24)  Soaps or detergents. 
(25)  Stone products, including abrasives, asbestos, stone screenings, and sand or lime products. 
(26)  Any other uses designated as a high risk or hazardous industrial use by the county, state or federal government. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.203; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-207. - Heavy equipment operator outdoor training site. 
(a)  The applicant shall apply for a specific use permit for a heavy equipment operator outdoor training site as part of the application for development permit review described in Section 18-48. Additional requirements for specific use permits are described in Section 18-52. The SUP may be granted for a period of up to one year. If, at the end of this year, the outdoor training site is still providing active and continuous on-site training and is in compliance with the Code and conditions of the SUP, one 12-month extension may be granted by renewing the SUP in accordance with Section 18-52. 
(b)  A heavy equipment operator outdoor training site shall not include indoor classroom instruction. Classroom instruction shall be conducted by separate permit, as appropriate, at an indoor location pursuant to City Code requirements. 
(c)  The outdoor training site shall be located on land that is developing or redeveloping. 
(d)  The outdoor training site shall only operate Monday through Friday during the hours of 7:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. 
(e)  The applicant shall obtain the property owner's permission to operate the outdoor training site and shall submit proof of owner's consent to the city upon application. 
(f)  Vehicular site access and circulation shall not impact public streets or surrounding uses. 
(g)  A person to whom a specific use permit for a heavy equipment operator outdoor training site is issued shall: 
(1)  Comply with city, state and federal laws at the outdoor training site; 
(2)  Repair or replace any public improvement that is damaged during the operation of the outdoor training site; 
(3)  Locate and operate the temporary outdoor training site in a manner which controls unnecessary dust, noise and odor; and 
(4)  Provide for on-site temporary chain link fencing, eight feet in height, to prevent people and animals from entering the outdoor training site. Placement of fencing shall comply with the visual obstruction regulations (sight triangles) described in Section 18-567. 
(h)  Within one month of the expiration of a specific use permit that has not been granted an extension: 
(1)  The site shall be cleaned with all evidence of its use removed including equipment, fencing, structures, parking gravel, and materials; 
(2)  The site shall be left in a condition that minimizes adverse impacts to the site and to surrounding properties. 
(Ord. No. 3064, § 14, 8-12-08; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-208. - Industrial-Inside. 
(a)  Caretaker's quarters are permitted as an accessory use. One parking space shall be provided per 500 square feet of floor area of caretaker's quarters, up to a maximum of two parking spaces for each caretaker's quarters. 
(b)  In the Mixed Use District and the Transit Oriented Development District, this use shall not exceed 10,000 square feet and must include a retail outlet. Outside storage is not permitted. 
(c)  The use is prohibited within the Core Subdistrict of the TOD district. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.203; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3115, § 8, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 3144, § 6, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-209. - Industrial-Outside. 
(a)  Caretaker's quarters are permitted as an accessory use. One parking space shall be provided per 500 square feet of floor area of caretaker's quarters, up to a maximum of two parking spaces for each caretaker's quarters. 
(b)  Accessory outside storage may occupy up to 50 percent of the lot. Outside storage that occupies more than 50 percent of the lot is considered a separate main use and is only allowed by SUP. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.203; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-210. - Mining. 
(a)  Caretaker's quarters are permitted as an accessory use. One parking space shall be provided per 500 square feet of floor area of caretaker's quarters, up to a maximum of two parking spaces for each caretaker's quarters. 
(b)  The applicant for a SUP to operate a mining use shall submit to the director a copy of the master plan and site plan, operations plan, and restoration plan that have met state requirements for a mining use. 
(c)  A SUP for a mining use shall not be granted unless a state certificate has been approved. 
(d)  The board in issuing a SUP for a mining use may set a time limit of up to five years. A SUP may be extended by the board following public hearing, if the operator is in full compliance with all terms and conditions of the original permit. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.203; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2815, § 14, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-211. - Outside salvage or reclamation. 
(a)  This use shall have a solid visual screen of at least eight feet in height surrounding the area of outside storage. 
(b)  Sufficient space shall be left between the visual screen and adjacent property, including right-of-way to meet the landscaping requirements. 
(c)  The owner or operator of an outside salvage or reclamation use shall not stack objects higher than six feet. The stacking of automobile bodies is not permitted. 
(d)  Automobile bodies and other objects shall be stored in such a manner that 12-foot lanes are maintained between rows. No row of stored materials may be longer than 1,000 feet in length. Fire lanes shall be provided in the site plan for an outside storage and reclamation use, and maintained at all times during the operation of the use. 
(e)  This use is not allowed within 1,000 feet of any state or federal highway, or in any location where the required screening would not conceal the stored objects from view. 
(Code 1975, § 58.2.203; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-212. - Well sites or production sites. 
(a)  Caretaker's quarters are permitted as an accessory use. One parking space shall be provided per 500 square feet of floor area of caretaker's quarters, up to a maximum of two parking spaces for each caretaker's quarters. 
(b)  Additional provisions for the development of oil and gas well and injection wells sites or production sites are contained in Article X of this chapter. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.203; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2255, § 6, 5-24-93; Ord. No. 2815, § 15, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-213. - Marijuana testing facility. 
(a)  Outside storage is prohibited. 
(b)  Prohibited locations. 
(1)  Marijuana testing facilities shall not be located within: 
a.  1,000 feet of a public or private school; 
b.  500 feet of a licensed childcare facility; or 
c.  500 feet of an alcohol or drug treatment facility. 
(2)  The distance for the purposes of this section shall be measured in a straight line from the nearest property line of the land used for the uses listed above to the nearest portion of the building in which the marijuana testing facility is to be located, without regard to intervening structures or objects. When a marijuana testing facility is to be located on the same lot as a listed land use, the measurement shall be in a straight line from the two closest points of the buildings in which each use is located, without regard to intervening structures or objects. 
(3)  Uses specified in subsection (b)(1) that are located outside the city shall be considered when applying the distance requirements. 
(4)  A marijuana testing facility shall not be located in the same building or structure as a use listed in subsection (b)(1) above. 
(5)  Marijuana testing facilities are prohibited as a home occupation. 
(Ord. No. 3400, § 4, 8-23-16) 
Secs. 18-214-18-223. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - INSTITUTIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE USES 

Sec. 18-224. - Cemeteries and mausoleums. 
    Caretaker's quarters are permitted as an accessory use. One parking space shall be provided per 500 square feet of floor area of caretaker's quarters, up to a maximum of two parking spaces for each caretaker's quarters. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.204; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-225. - Church. 
(a)  The following structures, when located on top of a church building, are excluded from the height measurements of the church building: 
(1)  Belfries, bell towers, campaniles, or carillons; 
(2)  Crosses; 
(3)  Cupolas, spires, or steeples; or 
(4)  Similar architectural appurtenance used as religious symbols. 
(b)  A rectory, convent, homeless shelter, or monastery is permitted as an accessory use. These accessory uses, except homeless shelters, may be located on a separate lot, and are not subject to the area limitations in Section 18-162. 
(c)  A homeless shelter is permitted as an accessory use and shall be located on the same lot as the principal use and is not subject to the area limitations in Section 18-162. For purposes of this subsection, a homeless shelter is a facility providing overnight lodging throughout the entire year if the number of shelter participants is eight or fewer. A homeless shelter serving more than eight participants shall be limited to 120 days per calendar year, whether the days are consecutive or nonconsecutive. It may be operated throughout the entire year if the number of participants is eight or fewer. Persons affiliated with the church and monitoring the shelter facility shall not be counted in determining the number of participants. 
(1)  The site and building shall comply with all building and fire codes as adopted by the city. 
(2)  The provisions of this section shall not limit other occasional overnight events commonly associated with church activities, including but not limited to fellowship activities. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.204; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3156, § 1, 12-7-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3170, § 1, 7-12-11) 
Sec. 18-226. - Crematorium. 
(a)  Facilities shall meet all applicable state and federal requirements for incineration equipment and shall be licensed at all times. 
(b)  All storage shall be inside. 
(c)  Incinerator stacks shall not be located on the front roof of any structure facing any street. 
(Ord. No. 2920, § 5, 10-25-05; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-227. - Day care facility. 
(a)  The persons being cared for, trained, kept, treated, or supervised under this use may not use the facility as a residence. No overnight accommodations shall be provided. 
(b)  All day care facilities shall have a state license and be governed by the rules and regulations of the Colorado Departments of Health and Human Services for such activities. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.204; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2728, § 1, 9-10-02; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-228. - Group homes. 
(a)  A group home shall be state licensed, if required by the state, and follow the state's requirements for inspections and licensure. 
(b)  A separate kitchen shall not be installed for any resident. 
(c)  No group home shall be established within 750 feet of another such group home, unless a request for reasonable accommodation has been approved by the city development department. 
(d)  A group home, as defined in Section 18-901, shall be considered a permitted use in any residential zoning district or any residential portion of any zoning district. 
(e)  A group home, as defined in Section 18-901, shall not include more than one adult who is required to register as a sex offender under the provisions of the Colorado Revised Statutes, as amended. 
(f)  Reasonable accommodation. This section sets out the process for consideration of a request for a variance for reasonable accommodation to the group home regulations. This process is available to group homes that house people with disabilities as defined by the federal Fair Housing Act. 
(1)  An applicant shall submit a request to city development for reasonable accommodation to the development code. This request shall be reviewed administratively. The request shall include the name and address of the applicant, the address of the group home, the type of housing being provided, and an explanation of the need for the reasonable accommodation. The request shall address each of the reasonable accommodation evaluation criteria described below. 
(2)  In order to grant the reasonable accommodation, the director of city development shall find that all of the following have been satisfied: 
a.  Applicant shall demonstrate that the group home serves residents that meet the Fair Housing Act's definition of disability; 
b.  Applicant shall demonstrate that there is a relationship between the disability and the need for the requested accommodation; 
c.  The reasonable accommodation must be necessary under the Fair Housing Act; 
d.  For group homes requesting reasonable accommodation for relief from the minimum 750-foot spacing requirement, the applicant shall demonstrate that adequate parking will be available for the group home; 
e.  Applicant shall demonstrate that the reasonable accommodation, if granted, will not cause a demonstrable detriment to adjacent property or the neighborhood; 
f.  The reasonable accommodation, if granted, will not fundamentally alter the intent of the development code; and 
g.  All other applicable building code and development standards are being met. 
(3)  The request for reasonable accommodation will be reviewed and a decision provided to the applicant in writing within 30 days of the date the complete request was received. The applicant may appeal this decision in accordance with the procedures in Section 18-34. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.204; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3369, § 2, 2-23-16) 
Sec. 18-229. - Hospitals and sanitariums. 
    Hospitals and sanitariums must be licensed by the state as a hospital. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.204; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-230. - Limited fundraising events. 
(a)  Evidence of adequate sanitation facilities shall be provided upon request of the director. 
(b)  If food is to be provided, proof shall be provided that all requirements of the Tri-County Health Department have been satisfied upon request of the director. 
(c)  Off-street parking requirements for this use may be satisfied by using existing parking spaces for other uses located within 500 feet of the site of the special event or by providing temporary parking spaces that do not strictly comply with the construction and maintenance provisions for off-street parking in this chapter. The operator of this use shall provide temporary off-street parking spaces that: 
(1)  Are adequately designed to accommodate the parking needs of the use; and 
(2)  Will not adversely affect surrounding uses. 
(d)  Upon completion of the event the site shall be cleaned, all evidence of its use removed, and left in its original condition to the greatest extent possible. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.204; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2279, § 40, 8-9-93; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-231. - Nursing, convalescent homes and hospices. 
    Nursing, convalescent homes and hospices shall comply with state statutory requirements including any state license requirements. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.204; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-232. - Schools, public and private. 
    Public and private schools do not include business, commercial, trade or craft schools. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.204; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 18-233-18-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - LODGING USES 

Sec. 18-246. - Boardinghouses or rooming-houses. 
(a)  This use may serve meals to the occupants. 
(b)  This use may not have kitchens in the guest rooms. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.205; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-247. - Hotels and motels. 
    Only hotels are permitted in the Employment Center, and Office/Institutional, and Transit Oriented Development Districts. Motels are prohibited. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.205; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3115, § 16, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 3144, § 14, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-248. - Vacation campgrounds. 
(a)  A vacation campground use shall be allowed only where it has access to a street or highway that has at least 50 feet of right-of-way. 
(b)  In no instance shall a vacation campground use be approved in an area where it would be completely surrounded by zoning districts that permit single-family uses, or where the entrance or exit from the campground would be across the street from zoning districts that permit a single-family use. 
(c)  The following size and area standards shall be considered in approving a SUP for a vacation campground use: 
(1)  The minimum size of a vacation campground use shall be five acres. 
(2)  Separate areas shall be provided for tent camping, for camping vehicles or units that are independent of on-site facilities, and camping vehicles or units that are dependent on on-site facilities (e.g., electrical, water, and sewer hookups). 
(3)  Each campground space shall have a minimum area of 1,250 square feet and a width of not less than 25 feet. 
(4)  Each campground space shall contain a surfaced area not less than ten by 30 feet. Surfacing shall consist of asphalt, concrete, or not less than four inches of compacted gravel. All camping vehicles, and other motor vehicles shall park entirely on the surfaced area. 
(5)  The remaining parts of the campground space which are not surfaced shall be provided with landscaping materials that provide for proper drainage and use of the site for camping purposes. 
(6)  One permanent rack and two containers for garbage and trash shall be provided for each four campground spaces. Trash and garbage containers shall be located within 100 feet of any campground they serve. 
(d)  The following facilities standards shall be considered in approving a SUP for a vacation campground use: 
(1)  Each vacation campground shall provide at least one service building that contains at least one public telephone; restroom facilities that have, for men and for women, a minimum of three water closets, two lavatories, and two showers; and not less than five automatic washers. A service building for a vacation campground use may be used only for purposes incidental to the campground. It may be used as a place of residence for an attendant. 
(2)  Restroom facilities for both sexes shall be within 300 feet of any campground space that is not independent. 
(3)  Each campground space shall be provided one picnic table and one fireplace. 
(4)  Each campground shall provide at least one common recreation area. The common recreation area shall have an area equal to at least 20 percent of the total area of the campground spaces. 
(5)  Interior roadways shall be provided to each campground space. Two-way roads shall be at least 28 feet wide and one-way roads shall be at least 18 feet wide. All one-way roads shall be clearly marked. No parking is permitted on the roadways. Roadway surfaces shall consist of asphalt, concrete, or not less than four inches of compacted gravel. Walkways, if provided, shall be a minimum of four feet wide and be surfaced with landscaping materials that provide for proper drainage and use of the site for camping purposes. 
(6)  All roadways and walkways shall be lighted with lights having a maximum spacing of 500 feet. 
(e)  The following minimum setbacks are required for approval of a SUP for a vacation campground use: 
(1)  Setback standards for the campground as a whole: 
Minimum Required For Distance in Feet Front setback Minimum 25 If fronting a state highway 50 Side and rear setback Minimum 15 If abutting a residential district 50 If abutting a dedicated public right-of-way 25 If abutting a state highway 50

(f)  Landscaping of the vacation campground use shall be developed in such a way as to support the use of the site as a campground. The following shall be considered in approving a SUP for this use: 
(1)  Use of native plant materials. 
(2)  Provision of shade and privacy on the individual campground spaces. 
(3)  Screening of support facilities such as garbage and trash containers, service buildings and other structures from campsites and from adjacent properties. 
(4)  Screening of a campground from adjacent residential development. This screening shall provide for the visual separation of the campground from the residential use. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.205; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 18-249-18-258. - Reserved.

DIVISION 8. - RECREATION USES 

Sec. 18-270. - Country club with private membership. 
    Country clubs with private memberships may contain a private bar, dining room, swimming pool, tennis courts, and similar recreational facilities. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.207; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-271. - Neighborhood park or playground. 
    An SUP is required for the expansion or installation of facilities or equipment in a neighborhood park which would, in the judgment of the board, result in the conversion of the neighborhood park to a community park facility. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.207; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2815, § 17, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 18-272-18-281. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - RESIDENTIAL USES 

Sec. 18-282. - Manufactured home park. 
(a)  Uses that are customarily incidental to the manufactured home park, including employee washrooms, manager's office, laundry rooms, swimming pools, and game courts, are permitted provided they are located at least 50 feet from a Single-Family Attached or Single-Family Detached Zoning District. The game courts, laundry rooms, and swimming pool shall be for the exclusive use of the residents and their guests. No exterior advertising of these uses is permitted. 
(b)  The manufactured home park use includes accessory structures such as personal storage buildings, awnings, cabanas, and porches which are erected on the same home site as a manufactured home. 
(c)  Accessory structures located on the same home site as a manufactured home are subject to the same setback regulations as the manufactured home itself, except for required storage buildings which may be set within three feet of the rear or side line of the home site. Storage buildings located according to this exception must be: 
(1)  Separate from the manufactured home; 
(2)  Separate from all other accessory structures; and 
(3)  Located to the rear of the manufactured home. 
(d)  Each home site within a manufactured home park shall have the following: 
(1)  A separate storage shed for each manufactured home park home site. The shed shall be provided by the owner of the manufactured home park unless otherwise provided by the lessee of the home site. Such storage shed shall be a minimum of 200 cubic feet in size; and 
(2)  A utility riser for each utility provided or required by the units located within the park; and 
(3)  A hose bib capable of accommodating a standard garden hose. 
(e)  Each manufactured home park shall provide the following: 
(1)  Park management and operations facility located in a permanent building. 
(2)  A clubhouse containing at least 2,500 square feet of floor area or ten square feet of floor area for each home site in the manufactured home park, whichever is greater. The clubhouse shall be located in a permanent building. 
(3)  A standard depth swimming pool containing at least 800 square feet of surface area, or three square feet of surface area for each home site within the manufactured home park, whichever is greater. 
(4)  A recreation vehicle and utility vehicle storage area with a minimum of 100 square feet of area for each home site within the manufactured home park, screened from adjacent public rights-of-way. 
(f)  The following signs shall be provided in a manufactured home park: 
(1)  An identification sign, in accordance with the sign provisions of this chapter, located at each entrance to the park. The sign shall include the name of the park and its address. 
(2)  Each manufactured home park home site shall be numbered uniformly with numbers not exceeding four inches in height. This sign shall be located such that it is visible from the street or drive at all times. 
(g)  The following maintenance activities are required in a manufactured home park: 
(1)  The property owner shall maintain the facilities required in subsection (e) above in the manner in which they were designed and such that they are available for use by the residents of the manufactured home park. 
(2)  All landscaping shall be kept in a well-maintained and healthy growing condition, which requires but is not limited to regular mowing, irrigation, weeding and pruning, and replacement of dead or dying plant materials. in accordance with the requirements of Section 18-556 of the Code. 
(3)  Fences over 30 inches in height require a building permit and shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the regulations in Section 18-565. 
(4)  Existing drainage patterns shall be maintained in accordance with the design approved at the time of development in accordance with the requirements of Section 18-657 of the Code. 
(5)  Snow, sleet, ice or other obstructions shall be removed from all public sidewalks and legally established accessible parking spaces within 24 hours of the last accumulation of such snow, sleet, ice or other obstruction, in accordance with the requirements of Section 70-106 of the Code. 
(6)  Existing parking areas, driveways and roadways internal to the manufactured home park shall be adequately maintained such that they operate as designed and shall not deteriorate to a level that is an imminent threat to public health and safety. This includes but is not limited to the repair of potholes and other major surface distress. 
(7)  Existing sidewalks, internal to the manufactured home park shall be adequately maintained such that they operate as designed and shall not deteriorate to a level that is an imminent threat to public health and safety. This includes but is not limited to removal of trip hazards and filling of holes or other major surface distress. 
(8)  All other real property owned or controlled by the manufactured home park for the benefit of residents shall be adequately maintained such that this property operates as designed and shall not deteriorate to a level that is an imminent threat to public health and safety. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.208; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2739, § 1, 11-12-02; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3279, § 2, 12-17-13) 
Sec. 18-283. - Multiple dwellings. 
(a)  Uses that are customarily incidental to the multiple dwelling use, including employee washrooms, manager's office, laundry rooms, swimming pools, and game courts, are permitted provided they are located at least 50 feet from a Single-Family Attached or Single-Family Detached Zoning District. The game courts, laundry rooms, and swimming pool shall be for the exclusive use of the residents and their guests. No exterior advertising of these uses is permitted. 
(b)  This use does not include a hotel or motel. 
(c)  In the Eastlake Business and Eastlake Office Districts, dwelling units are allowed up to fifty percent of the total floor area and are not permitted on the street level. 
(d)  In the Eastlake TOD District, dwelling units are allowed up to seventy-five percent of the total floor area and are not permitted on the street level. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.208; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3132, § 42, 5-11-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-284. - Retirement housing. 
(a)  Retirement housing may contain suites for the use of residents. Suites are defined as one or more rooms designed to accommodate one family containing living, sanitary, and sleeping facilities, but not containing a kitchen. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, each occupied dwelling unit or suite shall have at least one elderly resident. Elderly resident is defined as a resident who is 55 years of age or older. Failure to comply with this provision shall result in the facility being reclassified as another residential or lodging use. 
(c)  One dwelling unit or suite may be designated as a caretaker's unit whose occupants are not subject to the age restriction in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  Those persons legally residing with an elderly resident at the facility may continue to reside at the facility for a period not to exceed one year if the elderly person dies or moves out for medical reasons. The board may grant a special exception to authorize an extension of the length of time a person may continue to reside at the facility if the board finds, after a public hearing, that literal enforcement of this provision would result in an unnecessary personal hardship. 
(e)  No use with exterior advertising or signs may be considered accessory to this use. 
(f)  In the Mixed Use and Transit Oriented Development Districts, this use shall be attached dwelling units. Detached or two-family dwelling units are not permitted for this use in these zoning districts. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.208; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3115, § 22, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 3144, § 18, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-285. - Single-family dwellings. 
(a)  In single-family lots, the board may approve a development permit where no parking spaces are fully enclosed. 
(1)  The owner may construct a carport in compliance with the following criteria: 
a.  Carports shall comply with the front, rear and side yard setbacks and shall not be constructed in front of the principal residential structure. 
b.  Carports shall not be constructed of cloth or fabric of any kind. Tarps, canvas or similar materials shall not be used to enclose the carport. 
c.  A building permit obtained from the city is required to build or modify a carport. 
d.  Carports shall not be used for storage or placement of items for a period in excess of 24 hours. 
e.  The maximum height of a carport is 16 feet or the height of the principal structure, whichever is less. 
f.  The minimum size of a carport is 180 square feet and a maximum of 440 square feet with minimum width of nine feet. 
g.  The carport floor shall be in compliance with Section 18-601(c) of the Code. 
h.  The carport shall be architecturally compatible with the existing structure. 
(2)  Carports that were constructed prior to March 8, 2011 and meet the side setback requirements are granted nonconforming status. 
(b)  For single-family units with two or fewer bedrooms, a development permit may be approved by the board where only two parking spaces are provided, one of which must be fully enclosed. In reviewing a request to allow only one fully enclosed parking space, the board shall consider the following: 
(1)  The nature of fully enclosed parking spaces for existing development within 300 feet of the proposed development; 
(2)  The number of fully enclosed parking spaces that would ensure compatibility between the proposed development and existing development, or act as a transition between the proposed development and adjacent existing development; 
(3)  The design and location of off-street parking and the manner in which the proposed development will handle ingress and egress to the site; and 
(4)  The contribution of the enclosed parking spaces to the visual quality of the street. 
(c)  In the Transit Oriented Development District, detached dwellings are allowed in the Transition Subdistrict only. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.208; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2815, § 18, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3160, § 3, 3-8-11; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-286. - Bed and breakfast. 
(a)  This use shall provide temporary lodging accommodations for the general public up to a maximum of 30 consecutive days per guest; 
(b)  Structures shall not be altered in a way that changes their general residential appearance; 
(c)  If three or more off-street parking spaces are required to be provided pursuant to Section 18-596, visual screening for parking spaces shall be required; 
(d)  Other than to registered guests, no meals shall be served to the general public; and 
(e)  No cooking or kitchen facilities shall be allowed in the guest rooms. 
(Ord. No. 3132, § 43, 5-11-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 18-287-18-299. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - RETAIL AND PERSONAL SERVICE USES 

Sec. 18-300. - General provisions for retail and personal service uses. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, the following general provisions apply to all uses listed in Part IX of Section 18-160: 
(1)  All uses shall be retail or service establishments dealing directly with consumers. No person may produce goods or perform services on the premises unless those goods or services are principally sold on the premises to individuals at retail. 
(2)  Retail and personal service uses are allowed to have outside sales, outside display of merchandise, and outside storage only as accessory uses and subject to the provisions in Section 18-165. 
(3)  In the Community Retail, Mixed Use, Eastlake Business, Eastlake Service, Eastlake Office, and Eastlake TOD Districts, and the Transition Subdistrict of the Transit Oriented Development District, no use shall exceed 100,000 square feet per building, except in the Community Retail District, a building may exceed 100,000 square feet when at least 51 percent of the permanent display area is devoted to grocery products. 
(4)  No use shall exceed 20,000 square feet per use in the Core Subdistrict of the Transit Oriented Development District. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(a); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2830, § 1, 6-8-04; Ord. No. 2854, § 1, 11-9-04; Ord. No. 3115, § 5, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3306, § 1, 8-12-14) 
Secs. 18-301-18-305. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-306. - Auto rental. 
    An auto rental use does not include the repair, maintenance, or storage of rental vehicles not in active use by customers of the rental agency. In the event an auto service center use is permitted in the district, it may be combined with this use on one lot. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(2); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-307. - Auto service center. 
    If an inoperable or wrecked motor vehicle remains outside on the premises of an auto service center use for more than 48 hours, the premises is an outside salvage or reclamation use. It is a defense to prosecution under this provision if not more than four inoperable or wrecked motor vehicles are stored on the premises and: 
(1)  They each have a valid state registration; 
(2)  There is documentary evidence of pending repairs or other disposition; 
(3)  The premises has a current certificate of occupancy for a motor vehicle related use; and 
(4)  They are located in an area of the site screened from view from a public street, or any adjacent residential area. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(3); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-308. - Bar, lounge or tavern. 
(a)  Food may be prepared and served as an accessory use. 
(b)  Music, entertainment or facilities for dancing may be provided under this use. 
(c)  In the Employment Center District, a freestanding bar, lounge or tavern use requires approval of an SUP. 
(d)  In the Transit Oriented Development District, only nonresidential uses may be located on the floor immediately above the bar, lounge or tavern. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(4); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3115, § 25, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 3144, § 23, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11)

Type of Carwash Total Number of Stacking Spaces

These doors shall be closed at all times while the blower is in operation.

(1)  The size of the facility exceeds 3,500 square feet; or 
(2)  More than one drive-up window is provided. 
(b)  In the Employment Center District, a freestanding dry cleaning or laundry store requires approval of an SUP. 
(c)  In the Transit Oriented Development District, drive-through facilities are prohibited. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(12); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3115, § 31, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 3144, § 27, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-311. - Equipment rental. 
    When an equipment rental use is located in a Community Retail District, all rental items shall be inside of the building. No outside storage of items for rent is allowed. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(16); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-312. - Garage for repair and rebuilding of personal vehicles. 
    In the Eastlake Service District, this use shall not exceed 3,500 square feet per building. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(12); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-313. - General merchandise or food store 3,500 square feet or less. 
(a)  In the Employment Center District, non-freestanding restaurants shall not occupy more than ten percent of the total floor area of the building. 
(b)  In the Transit Oriented Development District, drive-through facilities are prohibited. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(17); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3115, § 32, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 3144, § 29, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-314. - General merchandise or food store greater than 3,500 square feet. 
    Drive-through facilities are prohibited in the Transit Oriented Development District. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(18); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3144, § 30, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-315. - Home improvement centers, lumber, brick, or building materials. 
    Accessory outside sales, accessory outside display of merchandise, or accessory outside storage may occupy up to 25 percent of the lot used for the home improvement center, lumber, brick or building materials use. If accessory storage occupies more than 25 percent of the lot, it is only allowed by SUP in the Industrial District. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(19); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-316. - Household equipment and appliance repair. 
    Outside storage associated with a household equipment and appliance repair use is prohibited in the Eastlake Business, Eastlake Service and Eastlake TOD Districts. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(20); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3132, § 52, 5-11-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11)

(a)  For drive-through service, the following off-street stacking spaces are required:
