(c)  In the Transit Oriented Development District, drive-through facilities are prohibited. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(22); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2279, § 45, 8-9-93; Ord. No. 3144, § 31, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-318. - Mortuary, funeral home. 
    In the Agricultural District, mortuary, funeral home uses must be associated with a cemetery or mausoleum. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(23); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-319. - Motor vehicle fueling station. 
(a)  All storage tanks for motor vehicle fuel, except for propane, shall be located underground. 
(b)  A fuel pump island shall be constructed in a manner that allows vehicular access adjacent to the island without interfering with or obstructing off-street parking. 
(c)  Fuel pumps are permitted as an accessory use only if they comply with the following: 
(1)  The pumps are available only to the owner and tenant of the main building and not available to the general public. 
(2)  The fuel pump and any sign relating to the pump shall not be visible from the public street. 
(3)  Fuel pumps shall be located at least 40 feet from a property line. 
(4)  Aboveground storage facilities for motor vehicle fuel, less than 500 gallons in size, may be approved as part of an accessory use, subject to proper siting for safety, landscaping and screening. 
(d)  If the motor vehicle fueling station includes a car wash with a forced air blower for drying, and any door for ingress or egress for a vehicle is within 750 feet of a residentially zoned parcel, the car wash shall be enclosed on all sides and have automatic doors. These doors shall be closed at all times while the blower is in operation. 
(e)  Lighting on the underside of canopies shall be flush with, or recessed above the underside of the canopy surface. "Bubble" type lenses which refract light outside of the area directly under the canopy area are not permitted. Light bulbs or fixtures shall be coated to reduce glare. 
(f)  See Section 18-522 of this chapter for additional design review criteria applicable to motor vehicle fueling stations. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(24); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2547, § 4, 6-28-99; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3439, § 5, 6-13-17) 
Sec. 18-320. - Motor vehicle pawnbroker. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of a development permit or minor development permit for a motor vehicle pawnbroker, all applicable requirements in Article VII of Chapter 42 shall be satisfied. 
(b)  A minor development permit is required for motor vehicle pawnbrokers occupying sites or structures on previously developed lots. 
(c)  Outside display and storage of used vehicles for sale is permitted without visual screening, except that screening meeting the requirements of Section 18-566 is required between the use and any adjacent residentially zoned property. 
(d)  In order to provide adequate access for customers around each displayed vehicle and to prevent vehicles from being closely parked, a minimum of 200 square feet is required for each vehicle displayed for sale in the vehicle sales area. 
(e)  In order to assist in mitigating the outdoor display and storage aspects of this use, motor vehicle pawnbrokers occupying sites or structures on previously developed lots shall landscape at least 20 percent of the gross land area. Areas required to be landscaped shall be determined by the city through the minor development permit process. Special attention shall be paid to right-of-way and buffer areas for such landscaping. 
(f)  The weight of each vehicle displayed or sold under this use may not exceed 6,000 pounds, manufacturer's gross vehicle weight. 
(g)  Inoperable or wrecked vehicles are prohibited. 
(h)  Any onsite repair of vehicles shall be conducted in a completely enclosed building. 
(i)  Required parking shall not be utilized for vehicle display. At least half of the required off-street parking shall be marked specifically for customer parking. 
(Ord. No. 3148, § 4, 11-9-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-321. - Nursery, garden shop, and plant sales. 
    In all districts where nursery, garden shop, and plant sales uses are allowed, accessory outside sales, display of merchandise, or storage of plant materials may occupy up to 80 percent of the lot. Accessory outside sales, display of merchandise, or storage of nonplant materials may occupy up to 25 percent of the lot. In no case, may accessory outside sales, display of merchandise, or storage of any material exceed 80 percent of the lot. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(25); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-322. - Outdoor shooting range. 
(a)  This use shall meet the requirements of Section 38-236 et seq. 
(b)  An SUP for an outdoor shooting range may be issued for a period up to five years. Upon approval, an annual permit fee, as established by resolution of the city council, shall be paid. 
(c)  Site plans for this use shall show topography at two-foot contour intervals. 
(d)  In addition to submission requirements normally supplied with an SUP request, the following shall be submitted for this use: 
(1)  An operations plan; and 
(2)  A land use survey of the area within one mile of the proposed shooting range. 
(e)  The following minimum standards shall apply to all outdoor shooting ranges: 
(1)  Site area shall be determined by the board based on the type of shooting range, its proximity to other uses, the operations plan submitted, and the site and landscaping plan. Sufficient size shall be provided to ensure the safety of surrounding areas and the avoidance of negative impacts on surrounding uses. 
(2)  Shooting ranges shall be located to take advantage of natural terrain barriers to the fullest extent possible. The entire range, including a danger area if the range is not of the safety range type, shall be fenced and warning signs shall be posted every 200 feet. 
(3)  The line of fire shall be as nearly horizontal as possible and shall never be below horizontal. In this provision, the term "below horizontal" means the target is lower than the firing point and that the gradient between the firing point and the target exceeds two percent (two feet lower for each 100 feet between the target and the firing point). 
(4)  The perimeter of the range shall be landscaped to provide natural noise barriers. The remainder of the range shall be planted with grass or other suitable ground cover. Additional structures to reduce noise may be required. 
(5)  In addition to firing lines or fields, adequate space for danger areas, parking, equipment storage buildings, clubhouse and restrooms shall be provided. 
(6)  No shooting may occur unless a range officer or instructor qualified by the National Rifle Association, the military services, or a local, state or national law enforcement agency is on site and in control. 
(f)  The following minimum standards shall apply to all pistol, small bore and high caliber rifle ranges: 
(1)  Overhead safety baffles are required if a range is constructed in a built-up area or when natural terrain does not offer adequate protection. 
(2)  A pistol or rifle range shall have at least 16 firing points. Each firing point shall be a minimum of five feet apart for shooting distances up to 200 yards. For shooting distances greater than 200 yards additional spacing may be required. 
(3)  All pistol or rifle ranges shall provide adequate bullet stops, either natural or artificial. 
(g)  Natural bullet stops shall meet the following minimum standards: 
(1)  Only slopes of hills shall be used for natural bullet stops. 
(2)  The crest of a hill used for a natural bullet stop shall be a minimum of 30 feet above the level of the firing point at a firing range of 100 yards. An additional ten feet in height is required for each additional 100 yards of range. 
(3)  The slope of a hill used as a natural bullet stop shall be not less than two feet vertical to one foot horizontal. 
(4)  A vertical cut shall be taken out of the hillside used as a backstop to prevent a nearly perpendicular face to catch bullets and prevent ricochets. 
(h)  Artificial bullet stops shall meet the following minimum standards: 
(1)  For firing ranges up to 300 yards, an earth embankment at least 25 feet in height, well sodded to retain a slope of 35 degrees from the perpendicular, and topped by an earth filled timber barricade at least 15 feet in height shall be provided. 
(2)  For each additional 100 yards of range, the overall height of the artificial bullet stop shall be ten feet higher. 
(3)  Stones shall be removed from the face of the embankment to a depth of 18 inches. 
(4)  The artificial bullet stop shall extend a minimum of 160 feet beyond each end of the firing lines for high caliber ranges. 
(5)  The artificial bullet stop shall extend a minimum of 25 feet beyond each end of the firing lines for small bore rifle and pistol ranges. 
(i)  The following minimum standards shall apply to all trap and skeet fields: 
(1)  The layout of a trap field shall meet the requirements of the American Trap Association. 
(2)  The layout of a skeet field shall meet the requirements of the National Skeet Shooting Association. 
(3)  A danger zone having the following dimensions shall be provided: 
Type of Field Dimensions of Danger Zone in Yards Trap field 100 × 300 Skeet field 300 × 600 Trap and skeet field combined 300 × 600  
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(26); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2815, § 19, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-323. - Pawnshops. 
    Prior to the issuance of a development permit for a pawnshop, all applicable requirements in Article VII of Chapter 42 shall be satisfied. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(27); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2279, § 46, 8-9-93; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-324. - Personal service use. 
    Drive-through facilities for personal service uses are prohibited in the Transit Oriented Development District. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(28); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3144, § 33, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-325. - Restaurant with drive-in or drive-through service. 
(a)  For drive-through service, the following off-street stacking spaces are required: 
Number of Service Windows or Stations Total Number of Stacking Spaces 
Required 1 5 2 10 3 15 4 18 Each additional service window or station 3 additional  
(b)  For drive-through service, a remote ordering station shall be located at least 27 feet from all streets that allow direct access to the station. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(30); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-326. - Restaurant without drive-in or drive-through service. 
    In the Employment Center District, non-freestanding restaurants shall not occupy more than ten percent of the total floor area of the building. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(31); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3115, § 40, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-327. - Sales kiosk. 
(a)  Sales kiosks are limited in size to 500 square feet. 
(b)  The sale of alcohol from a sales kiosk is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 3144, § 35, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-328. - Sexually oriented businesses. 
(a)  A sexually oriented business shall comply with all the regulations and requirements of this chapter. 
(b)  The location of a sexually oriented business shall not be within 750 feet of: 
(1)  Any religious institution; 
(2)  Any school; 
(3)  The boundary of any property which is residentially zoned and has a density of three or more dwelling units per acre; 
(4)  A public park or public building; or 
(5)  Another sexually oriented business. 
(c)  The measurement of distance for the purposes of this section shall be conducted in the following manner: 
(1)  The distance between any two sexually oriented businesses shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures, from the closest exterior structural wall of each business; and 
(2)  The distance between any sexually oriented business and any religious institution, school, public park, public building or residentially zoned property with a density of three or more dwelling units per acre shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the nearest portion of the building or structure used as part of the premises where the sexually oriented business is conducted, to the nearest property line of the premises of a religious institution, school, or the nearest boundary of an affected public park or residential use. 
(d)  A sexually oriented business cannot be operated in the same building, structure or portions of another sexually oriented business. 
(e)  This use shall meet the regulatory provisions of Article VIII of Chapter 42. 
(f)  The following minimum standards shall apply to the exterior of all sexually oriented businesses: 
(1)  There must be adequate fencing to provide security for the building, and to prevent pedestrians from viewing the interior. 
(2)  Off-street parking for a use other than single-family or two-family uses that offers service after dark shall be lighted beginning one-half hour after sunset and continuing throughout the hours of use. If only a portion of the parking area is offered for use after dark, only that part shall be lighted. The lighting of the off-street parking area shall meet the following minimum requirements: 
a.  The intensity of the light on the parking surface shall be: (i) an average of at least one foot-candle, initial measurement; (ii) a minimum at any point of at least four-tenths foot-candle, initial measurement. Requirements for maintenance of parking lot lighting shall include replacement of bulbs and light fixtures, regular cleaning, and replacement of light poles as needed. 
b.  The light sources shall be indirect, diffused, or shielded type fixtures, installed to reduce glare and the consequent interference with boundary streets and adjacent property. 
c.  Fixtures shall be attached to buildings or mounted on poles in such a manner and at such a height that light is not directed at a residential use. 
d.  Maximum height of lights shall not exceed 35 feet. 
e.  Any signs or advertisements placed around the building must be in compliance with the obscenity laws of this state and the city and shall not visually depict or describe any "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as defined in Article VIII of Chapter 42. 
(g)  The provisions of this chapter concerning the zoning of nude model studios do not apply to: 
(1)  A college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; 
(2)  A private college or university which maintains and operates educational programs in which credits are transferable to a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; or 
(3)  A business located in a structure which has no sign visible from the exterior of the structure and no other advertising that indicates a nude person is available for viewing; and where, in order to participate in a class a student must enroll at least three days in advance of the class; and where no more than one nude model is on the premises at any one time. 
(h)  Amortization provisions. 
(1)  Any sexually oriented business lawfully operating on the effective date of this section and which does not come into compliance with the licensing provisions of Article VIII of Chapter 42 or this chapter within the timeframes established in Section 42-581(c) shall be deemed a nonconforming use; provided, however, that such sexually oriented businesses shall be exempt from the locational restrictions of this chapter or Article VIII of Chapter 42 and from the requirements for obtaining an SUP as set forth in Section 18-160. A nonconforming use will be permitted to continue for only a period of six months. The exemptions provided for in this subsection shall not apply if there is a change of ownership after the effective date of this subsection. 
(2)  If two or more sexually oriented businesses are within 750 feet of one another and otherwise in a permissible location, the sexually oriented business which was first established and continually operating at the particular location is the conforming use and the later established business is nonconforming, in which case subsection (h)1 of this section shall apply. 
(3)  A sexually oriented business lawfully operating as a conforming use is not rendered a nonconforming use by the location, subsequent to the grant or renewal of a sexually oriented business permit and/or license, of a religious institution, school, public park, public building or residentially zoned property with a density of three dwelling units per acre within 750 feet of the sexually oriented business. This provision applies only to the renewal of a valid permit and/or license and does not apply when an application for a permit and/or license is submitted after a permit and/or license has expired or has been revoked. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(32); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2367, § 5, 1-23-95; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-329. - Theater. 
(a)  The sale or service of food or drinks is permitted as an accessory use. 
(b)  This use may include service of food or drink to the audience within the main auditorium. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(35); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-330. - Vehicle display, sales, service, and storage. 
(a)  The weight of each vehicle displayed or sold under this use may not exceed 6,000 pounds, manufacturer's gross vehicle weight. 
(b)  Outside display and storage of new or used vehicles for sale is permitted under this use without visual screening, except as required in subsection (e)(4) below. 
(c)  Inoperable or wrecked vehicles are allowed on site under the following limitations: 
(1)  The area where these vehicles are stored is screened from adjacent uses; and 
(2)  These vehicles each have a valid state registration and documentary record of pending repairs or other disposition. 
(d)  A minor development permit is required for facilities selling and servicing exclusively used vehicles on previously developed lots. 
(e)  Facilities selling and servicing exclusively used vehicles shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  In order to provide adequate access for customers around each displayed vehicle and to prevent vehicles from being closely parked, a minimum of 200 square feet is required for each vehicle displayed for sale in the vehicle sales area. 
(2)  The off-street parking required in Section 18-596 shall not be utilized for vehicle display. At least half of the required off-street parking shall be marked specifically for customer parking. 
(3)  In order to assist in mitigating the outdoor display and storage aspects of this use, facilities selling and servicing exclusively used vehicles on previously developed lots shall landscape at least 20 percent of the gross land area. Areas required to be landscaped shall be determined by the city through the minor development permit process. Special attention shall be paid to right-of-way and buffer areas for such landscaping. 
(4)  Screening that meets the requirements of Section 18-566 is required between the use and any adjacent residentially zoned property. 
(5)  Any onsite repair of vehicles shall be conducted in a completely enclosed building. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.209(b)(36); Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2223, § 1(E), 12-28-92; Ord. No. 3148, § 5, 11-9-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-331. - Marijuana store. 
(a)  Prohibited locations. 
(1)  Marijuana stores shall not be located within: 
a.  1,000 feet of a public or private school; 
b.  500 feet of a licensed childcare facility; or 
c.  500 feet of an alcohol or drug treatment facility. 
(2)  The distance for the purposes of subsection (a)(1) shall be measured in a straight line from the nearest property line of the land used for the uses listed above to the nearest portion of the building in which the marijuana is to be sold, without regard to intervening structures or objects. Listed uses that are located outside the city shall be considered when applying the distance requirements. When a marijuana store is to be located on the same lot as a listed land use, the measurement shall be in a straight line from the two closest points of the buildings in which each use is located, without regard to intervening structures or objects. 
(3)  A marijuana store shall not be located within 1,500 feet of another marijuana store. This distance shall be measured in a straight line from the two closest points of the buildings in which each use is located, without regard to intervening structures or objects. Marijuana stores located outside the city shall not be considered in applying the distance provisions. 
(4)  A marijuana store shall not be located in the same building or structure as another marijuana store or a use listed in subsection (a)(1) above. 
(b)  Locational limitations. 
(1)  Only one marijuana store shall be approved to operate in each of the four designated city quadrants. 
(2)  For purposes of this section, designated city quadrants shall be as listed below, with boundaries following the approximate centerlines of the specified streets. Where a portion of the specified street does not exist or where the street has an alternative alignment, the boundary shall follow the anticipated centerline of the street as it would exist in the specified hundred block within the Denver Grid System, generally following a straight line running North and South for York Street and Colorado Boulevard, and East and West for 120th Avenue. 
a.  Quadrant 1. South of E. 120th Avenue and west of York Street. 
b.  Quadrant 2. South of E. 120th Avenue and east of York Street. 
c.  Quadrant 3. North of E. 120th Avenue and east of Colorado Boulevard. 
d.  Quadrant 4. North of E. 120th Avenue and west of Colorado Boulevard. 
(c)  Additional provisions. 
(1)  A marijuana store may not operate as an accessory to or in conjunction with any other land use. 
(2)  Marijuana stores are prohibited as a home occupation. 
(3)  Accessory outside display of merchandise, accessory outside sales, and accessory outside storage are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 3400, § 5, 8-23-16) 
Sec. 18-332. - Commercial amusement-Outside. 
(a)  A development project containing an outside commercial amusement use shall have access to a major arterial roadway, as identified in the City's Transportation Plan, and that access shall be located within one-half mile of any state or federal highway. 
(b)  The distance between an outside commercial amusement use and any land with residential zoning shall be at least 350 feet. This distance shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the nearest property line of the land on which the outside commercial amusement use is located to the nearest property line of any residentially zoned land. For purposes of this provision, residential zoning shall include land zoned planned development if the use or intended use is residential in nature. 
(Ord. No. 3453, § 4, 10-10-17) 
Sec. 18-333. - Indoor shooting range. 
(a)  The distance between an indoor shooting range and any land used or zoned for a residential use or used for a school shall be at least 350 feet. This distance shall be measured in a straight line from the nearest property line of any land used or zoned for a residential use or a school to the nearest portion of the building occupied by an indoor shooting range use, without regard for intervening structures or objects. For purposes of this provision, planned development districts shall be considered in the spacing requirements if the property is designated to include residential uses or a school. 
(b)  In addition to the required application requirements specified in Section 18-31 or Section 10-61, the following additional information shall be submitted for this use: 
(1)  A safety operations plan. 
(2)  A sound impact analysis. 
(3)  Any federal or state licensing or permits required to operate shooting range shall be submitted to the city prior to issuance of the certificate of occupancy. 
(c)  The design and construction of the indoor shooting range shall completely confine all ammunition rounds within the building and in a controlled manner. The design and construction of the shooting range shall be performed by a registered engineer. The certified plans shall include the specifications and construction of the bullet trap(s), ceilings, exterior and interior walls, and floors. The certified plans shall specify the type and caliber of ammunition that the range is designed to totally confine. 
(d)  No ammunition shall be used in the indoor shooting range that exceeds the certified design and construction specifications of the gun range. 
(e)  For purposes of this section, "school" shall mean day care facilities for children, and/or private or public educational institutions that have a curriculum for preschool, kindergarten, elementary, and secondary education. The definition does not include private or public postsecondary, technical, trade, or business schools. 
(Ord. No. 3523, § 5, 4-23-19) 
Secs. 18-334-18-359. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - TEMPORARY USES 

Sec. 18-360. - Christmas tree lots. 
(a)  Upon approval, the director shall issue a temporary use permit for a period of 60 days for this use. The director may grant one 30-day extension of the temporary use permit if the use has fully complied with all applicable city ordinances and conditions of the TUP. 
(b)  Upon completion of the temporary use, the site shall be cleaned, all evidence of its use removed, and left in a condition that minimizes adverse impacts to the site itself and to surrounding properties. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.210; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-361. - Other temporary use. 
    Subject to the conditions listed below, the director may approve other temporary uses and activities if it is determined that such uses would not jeopardize the health, safety, or general welfare, or be injurious or detrimental to properties adjacent to, or in the vicinity of, the proposed location of the activity. 
(a)  Traffic. The proposed site must be adequately served by streets or drives having sufficient width and improvements to accommodate the type and quantity of traffic that such temporary use will or could reasonably generate. 
(b)  Parking. Adequate parking must be available, either on-site or at alternate locations, to accommodate vehicular traffic reasonably expected to be generated by such use. 
(c)  Signs. Only temporary and vehicular signs are permitted. Signs shall conform to the provisions of the Sign Code in Article VII of this chapter and shall be removed when the activity ends. Permanent signs are prohibited. 
(d)  On-site lighting. Temporary uses operating after dark shall provide lighting in accordance with Section 18-568. 
(e)  Trash. The operator of a temporary use is responsible for the storage and removal of all trash, refuse, and debris on the site. When possible, all trash storage areas should be screened from view from adjacent rights-of-way. The property owner and the applicant are responsible for ensuring that the site is maintained in a clean and safe manner. An application for a temporary use permit shall include a waste management plan to manage any trash and other waste generated by the use. 
(f)  Noise. All temporary uses shall comply with the sound level standards specified in Section 38-441 of the Code unless otherwise exempted. 
(g)  Dwelling prohibited. Except as authorized in Sections 18-367 and 18-569, no temporary use shall be used as a dwelling unit. 
(h)  Restoration. Upon completion of the temporary use, the site shall be cleaned, all evidence of its use removed, and left in a condition that minimizes adverse impacts to the site itself and to surrounding properties. 
(i)  Additional review criteria. All temporary uses shall meet the requirements of Section 18-53 pertaining to temporary use permits. 
(j)  Licensing and permits. The applicant is responsible for obtaining any licenses and permits when required by this Code, state statute, or other regulation. No person shall engage in the operation or activities of a temporary use prior to the issuance of a temporary use permit, unless exempted in Section 18-53. 
(Ord. No. 3499, § 2, 10-10-18) 
Sec. 18-362. - Farmers' market. 
(a)  Off-street parking requirements for this use may be satisfied by using existing parking spaces for other uses located within 500 feet of the site of the farmers' market, or by providing temporary parking spaces that do not strictly comply with the construction and maintenance provisions for off-street parking in this chapter. The operator of this use has the burden of demonstrating to the satisfaction of the director that temporary off-street parking spaces: 
(1)  Are adequately designed to accommodate the parking needs of the use; and 
(2)  Will not adversely affect surrounding uses. 
(b)  Food concessionaires and the sale of non-agricultural products are permitted, but the area dedicated to such products shall not occupy more than 25 percent of the total sales area. 
(c)  Canopies may be allowed in order to provide protection from the elements for both the operators and the products. 
(d)  A farmers' market may operate a maximum of two days per week. 
(e)  Upon completion of the temporary use, the site shall be cleaned, all evidence of its use removed, and left in a condition that minimizes adverse impacts to the site itself and to surrounding properties. 
(Ord. No. 3132, § 59, 5-11-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-363. - Seasonal sales stand. 
(a)  No product may be placed for sale or display and no structure used for a temporary seasonal sales stand may be closer than 50 feet to the public right-of-way. 
(b)  No temporary seasonal sales stand may have more than 3,500 square feet floor area. 
(c)  Upon completion of the temporary use, the site shall be cleaned, all evidence of its use removed, and left in a condition that minimizes adverse impacts to the site itself and to surrounding properties. 
(d)  In the manufactured home, neighborhood service, city center and office/institutional districts, seasonal sales stands are permitted only in conjunction with a community garden. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.210; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3188, § 4, 2-14-12) 
Sec. 18-364. - Temporary concrete or asphalt batch plant. 
(a)  A temporary use permit for a batch plant is valid for a period up to one year. The director may grant up to three six-month extensions if the builder maintains active and continuous construction on the project for which the temporary batch plant permit was granted. 
(b)  A person to whom a temporary use permit for a batch plant is issued shall: 
(1)  Comply with city, state and federal laws at the batch plant site; 
(2)  Clear the site of equipment, materials, and debris upon completion of the project; 
(3)  Repair or replace any public improvement that is damaged during the operation of the temporary batch plant; 
(4)  Locate and operate the temporary plant in a manner which eliminates unnecessary dust, noise and odor; and 
(5)  Provide for adequate on-site fencing, screening, or buffering elements so that adjacent properties are protected from hazards and negative impacts. 
(c)  A person shall only furnish concrete, asphalt, or both, to the specific project for which the temporary use permit was issued. 
(d)  Upon completion of the temporary use, the site shall be cleaned, all evidence of its use removed, and left in a condition that minimizes adverse impacts to the site itself and to surrounding properties. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.210; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-365. - Temporary construction yard, or construction or sales office. 
(a)  The lot used as a temporary construction yard shall be adjacent to the construction site, or located in such a manner that access from the temporary construction yard to the construction site does not impact public streets or surrounding uses. 
(b)  Siting of a temporary construction yard shall provide adequate buffering for adjacent structures and uses. 
(c)  All structures and materials on a temporary construction yard shall be removed within two months after completion of the project, even if the temporary use permit is still valid. 
(d)  A temporary use permit for a temporary construction yard or office is valid for a period of one year. The director may grant up to three six-month extensions if the builder maintains active and continuous construction on the site or within the subdivision. 
(e)  A temporary use permit for a temporary sales office is valid for a period of one year. The director may grant up to three one-year extensions as long as a minimum of ten lots within the subdivision remain unsold. 
(f)  Upon completion of the temporary use, the site shall be cleaned, all evidence of its use removed, and left in a condition that minimizes adverse impacts to the site itself and to surrounding properties. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.210; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-366. - Temporary grazing. 
(a)  A person shall not operate this use on an area less than five acres. 
(b)  An application for a TUP for this use shall specify the number and type of animal that will be grazing. No TUP shall be granted where the number and type of animals to be grazed is likely to result in overgrazing and/or significant environmental degradation of the site. 
(c)  Structures may be erected for a stable, pen, barn, or shed for the protection of the animals on the premises. 
(d)  Standings under roofed stables shall be made of a material that provides for proper drainage so as not to create offensive odors, insect or rodent breeding, or other nuisances. 
(e)  Adequate drainage facilities and other improvements shall be provided so as to protect any adjacent river, stream, or other body of water from pollution or other environmental damage. 
(f)  A temporary use permit for grazing is valid for a period of three years. The director may grant up to two one-year extensions, if conditions at the time of initial approval have not changed. 
(g)  Upon completion of the temporary use, the site shall be cleaned, all evidence of its use removed, and left in a condition that minimizes adverse impacts to the site itself and to surrounding properties. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.210; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-367. - Temporary living quarters. 
(a)  Approval is required from the Tri-County District Health Department before a TUP for this use can be granted. 
(b)  The TUP for this use is valid for a six-month period. An additional six months may be granted by the director provided the exterior walls and roof of the residence are completed. Under all other circumstances, application for an extension shall be to the board. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.210; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-368. - Traveling show, carnival, circus, or special event. 
(a)  Off-street parking requirements for this use may be satisfied by using existing parking spaces for other uses located within 500 feet of the site of the traveling show, carnival or circus, or by providing temporary parking spaces that do not strictly comply with the construction and maintenance provisions for off-street parking in this chapter. The operator of this use has the burden of demonstrating to the satisfaction of the director that temporary off-street parking spaces: 
(1)  Are adequately designed to accommodate the parking needs of the use; and 
(2)  Will not adversely affect surrounding uses. 
(b)  The director shall issue a temporary use permit for a period not to exceed 30 days for this use. The director may grant one 30-day extension of the temporary use permit if the use has fully complied with all applicable city ordinances and conditions of the TUP. 
(c)  Before a traveling show, carnival, circus or special event may occur on a site it shall fully comply with licenses requirements in Article IV of Chapter 42. 
(d)  Upon completion of the temporary use, the site shall be cleaned, all evidence of its use removed, and left in a condition that minimizes adverse impacts to the site itself and to surrounding properties. 
(e)  Hot air balloon rides are permitted at special events provided all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The applicant shall sign a statement holding the city harmless from claims arising out of incidents involving permitted hot-air balloons; 
(2)  The applicant shall abide by all requirements imposed by the Federal Aviation Administration; 
(3)  The pilot shall be properly licensed; 
(4)  The balloon shall be properly tethered; 
(5)  The balloon shall not be launched from public property; and 
(6)  The maximum height above grade for a hot air balloon used as a special event sign is 150 feet. 
(7)  A permit for a hot air balloon ride is valid for seven days. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.210; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3168, § 4, 6-28-11) 
Sec. 18-369. - Vending cart sales. 
(a)  A vending cart shall comply with all applicable health and sanitation statutes, rules, regulations, ordinances, sales taxes, and other laws. 
(b)  Vending carts shall be located on sidewalks or in pedestrian plazas only, not within the travel lanes of the street. The pedestrian way shall remain unobstructed at all times. 
(c)  Vending carts shall serve only walk-up customers, and may display, sell, give away anything of value including any food, beverage, goods, wares, or merchandise. The display, sale, or giving away of alcohol from a vending cart is prohibited. 
(d)  Vending carts may not be stored outdoors when the vendor is not open for business. 
(e)  Temporary use permit requirements: 
(1)  The director may issue a temporary use permit that allows intermittent occurrences (such as every weekend) or a continuous time for up to a total of 100 days per calendar year for this use. 
(2)  The application for the temporary use permit shall include a waste management plan to manage any trash or other waste generated by the use. 
(3)  The application for the temporary use permit shall specify anticipated hours of operation. 
(4)  The application for the temporary use permit shall specify the desired location or perimeter of the area for the vending cart. If more than one vendor desires the same location or area, the city may hold a lottery for the purpose of determining which vendor will occupy the desired location or area. 
(Ord. No. 3144, § 40, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-370. - Temporary donation collection bin. 
(a)  Requirements. 
(1)  No person shall place, use or operate a donation collection bin without first obtaining a temporary use permit pursuant to this article. Upon approval, the director shall issue a temporary use permit that is valid for a period of one year. The director may approve the renewal of the permit for subsequent one-year periods, subject to payment of a new permit fee, if the use has and continues to fully comply with all applicable city ordinances and conditions of the TUP. 
(2)  At a minimum, each bin shall display the name, address and telephone number for the person, business, or organization responsible for placing and maintaining the bin. 
(3)  Only one bin is permitted per lot, and each bin shall not exceed 200 square feet or be taller than six feet in height. Bins shall be made of metal, steel, or similar durable product. 
(4)  No donation collection bin shall be located on property zoned for residential use. 
(5)  Each bin shall be located on an improved durable, drainable surface. If placed in a parking area, the bin shall not reduce the number of available parking spaces below the minimum number required for the lot. 
(6)  No bin shall be placed in the following locations: 
a.  Within a required building setback; 
b.  Within a site visibility triangle; 
c.  Within an access easement; 
d.  In a driveway, sidewalk, or other pedestrian circulation area; 
e.  Within three feet of any fire hydrant; 
f.  Within any fire lane; 
g.  Within required landscaped areas; 
h.  In whole or in part upon any portion of a public-right-of-way or projecting onto or over any part of a public right-of-way; or 
i.  On an undeveloped parcel of land. 
(7)  Each application for a temporary use permit shall include: 
a.  A waiver and consent form authorizing the city to remove graffiti vandalism from the donation collection bin if the person, business, or organization responsible for the bin does not do so within 48 hours of notice by the City. 
b.  An authorization form signed by the property owner or property owner's agent authorizing the placement of the bin on the private property. 
c.  An authorization form signed by the property owner or property owner's agent authorizing removal by the city of the bin, its contents and any items dumped outside the bin upon reasonable notice that the maintenance requirements specified in subsection (b) have not been met. 
(b)  Maintenance; enforcement. 
(1)  Each bin shall be serviced and emptied as needed or within 24 hours of a request by the property owner or city. 
(2)  Each bin shall be enclosed by use of a one-way receiving door and locked so that the contents of the bin may not be accessed by anyone other than those responsible for the retrieval of the contents. 
(3)  Each bin shall clearly display a sign indicating that no donated items, garbage or other debris is to be left outside of the bin. 
(4)  Upon completion of the temporary use the bin shall be removed, the site shall be cleaned, all evidence of its use removed, and left in a condition that minimizes adverse impacts to the site itself and to surrounding properties. 
(c)  Violations and penalties. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for a property owner or donation bin owner to place, use, permit, or allow a donation collection bin to be placed or allow to remain on a property without a permit, or permit or allow operation of a bin that is not in compliance with any requirement of this section. Violations of this section are detrimental to the public health and safety. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any donation bin owner to fail to maintain or keep in good repair any donation collection bin, including without limitation, the prompt removal of graffiti and the repairing of any part of the bin that is missing, broken, damaged, or deteriorated. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any property owner or donation bin owner to fail to maintain the area around a donation bin, including without limitation, the prompt removal of dumped items. 
(4)  Any person, property owner, donation bin owner, or company in violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be issued a fine up to the maximum fine authorized by Section 1-8(a). The court shall make a finding that the bin is a cause of blight and shall order the removal of the donation bin and any property in the area around or inside a donation bin. The court shall also issue an order for reimbursement for any costs incurred by the city for the failure to remove any donation bin or property in the area around or inside the donation bin. 
(Ord. No. 3317, § 2, 11-25-14; Ord. No. 3432, § 3, 5-9-17) 
Secs. 18-371-18-379. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - TRANSPORTATION USES 

Sec. 18-380. - Airports. 
(a)  A minimum of 100 acres is required for this use. 
(b)  This use is subject to the Federal Aviation Administration's rules, regulations, and approval. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.211; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-381. - Heliports. 
(a)  This use may include fueling and servicing facilities. 
(b)  This use is subject to the Federal Aviation Administration's rules, regulations, and approval. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.211; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-382. - Transit passenger shelter. 
(a)  This use may be installed only by public agencies. 
(b)  This use is exempt from the front, side, and rear yard requirements of this chapter. 
(c)  A person may not place a sign on a transit passenger shelter unless authorized by the responsible public agency. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.211; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3439, § 6, 6-13-17) 
Secs. 18-383-18-392. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - UTILITY AND PUBLIC SERVICE USES 

Sec. 18-393. - Electric substation and gas regulator station. 
    The board shall review only the following criteria in considering a development permit for this use: 
(1)  Each installation of this use is required to be enclosed by a wall or solid wood fence with a minimum height of eight feet. The wall or fencing shall be solid to mitigate this use from surrounding properties and be designed to deter access to the equipment by unauthorized persons. 
(2)  The following setbacks from the property lines are required for this use: 
Setback Minimum Distance in Feet Front 30 Side 10 Rear 10  
(3)  The height of any building shall not exceed 35 feet. On the exterior of the required wall or fence, landscaping shall be provided for aesthetic purposes. The specific requirements for landscaping shall be determined by the board, as part of the approval of the development permit, based on one or more of the following landscape criteria: 
a.  Installation of ground covers, trees, and shrubs for aesthetic purposes. 
b.  Designing the facility to utilize natural screens, where possible. 
c.  All plant materials shall be maintained in a healthy growing condition at all times. The public utility is responsible for the regular weeding, mowing, and other maintenance of all plant materials. Proper irrigation of plant materials shall be provided. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.212; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2295, § 3, 11-15-93; Ord. No. 2815, § 20, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-394. - Electrical generating plants. 
    No SUP shall be issued to an electrical generating plant unless it meets all requirements of the applicable regulatory agencies and has all state and federal licenses. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.212; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-395. - Library. 
(a)  This use shall be owned or operated by a public or quasi-public agency and be open and available to the general public. 
(b)  Retail sales in a library is permitted as an accessory use. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.212; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-396. - Local utilities. 
(a)  This section shall only apply to new electric transmission poles or when the utility provider upgrades the voltage in its electric transmission lines and shall not apply to any repairs, replacements or modifications to existing facilities so long as Section 18-451 is met. 
(b)  Aboveground storage tanks are not permitted under this use. 
(c)  The board shall only review the following criteria in considering a development permit for any aboveground electric transmission line: 
(1)  The width of easements or rights-of-way for new electric transmission lines shall exceed the National Electrical Safety Code standards by at least five feet. The board may waive the additional five feet if the public utility demonstrates that there are unique physical circumstances or conditions that create a hardship. 
(2)  The proposed electric transmission lines and their poles shall not unreasonably obstruct emergency equipment due to their location and construction or enlargement of the lines. 
(3)  The proposed electric transmission lines and their poles located at or near intersections shall meet the standards in Section 18-567. 
(4)  The height requirements established in subsection 18-451(e) shall be met. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.212; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2295, § 3, 11-15-93; Ord. No. 2524, § 5, 10-12-98; Ord. No. 2815, § 20, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-397. - Refuse transfer station. 
(a)  Refuse transfer stations may not handle any hazardous waste products. 
(b)  This use does not permit any storage or disposal of solid waste products on site, with the exception of separated recyclable materials which shall be allowed to stay on site no longer than 30 days. No other material brought to a refuse transfer station is allowed to remain on site longer than 48 hours. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.212; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 18-398-18-407. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 14. - WHOLESALE, DISTRIBUTION AND STORAGE USES 

Sec. 18-408. - Contractor's maintenance yard. 
    Contractor's maintenance yards shall be surrounded by a solid fence or other form of complete screening. The screening shall be at least eight feet in height. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.213; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-409. - Mini-warehouse. 
(a)  A caretaker's quarters is permitted as an accessory use. 
(b)  One parking space shall be provided per 500 square feet of floor area of a caretaker's quarters, up to a maximum of two parking spaces for each caretaker's quarters. 
(c)  No outside storage is allowed. 
(d)  Parking and maneuvering of trucks is permitted only off the street in off-street parking areas. 
(e)  The development shall be surrounded by a six-foot high solid wall or fence. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.213; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2456, § 3, 5-12-97; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-410. - Office showroom/warehouse. 
(a)  Retail sale of products which are sold at wholesale on the premises are permitted as a part of this use. 
(b)  Office and/or showroom uses must make up at least 20 percent of the total floor area of the office showroom/warehouse use. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.213; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-411. - Outdoor storage. 
(a)  A person shall not place, store, or maintain outside for a period in excess of 24 hours, an item which is not: 
(1)  Customarily used or stored outside; or 
(2)  Made of a material that is resistant to damage or deterioration from exposure to the outside environment. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, outside storage is considered to be a separate main use if it occupies more than five percent of the lot. Outside storage may be permitted as an accessory use on more than five percent of the lot if it is customarily incidental to a main use. The term "customarily incidental" means that the accessory use is an integral and functional part of the main use conducted on the property. See Section 18-165. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.213; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2223, § 1(F), 12-28-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-412. - Recycling collection center. 
(a)  This use may be located in a residential district as a limited use subject to the following: 
(1)  The collection center is sponsored by a governmental agency; 
(2)  It is located in a public park, or on a public school site; 
(3)  The collection facility is on-site at a scheduled time, for a period less than a week at a time; and 
(4)  The collection containers are accessible at all times for the deposit of recyclable goods. 
(b)  This use may be located by SUP: 
(1)  On a parking lot in an enclosed vehicle or drop-off container; 
(2)  In an automatic collection machine; or 
(3)  Within the premises of a retail food store as an accessory use. 
(c)  A collection center in a vehicle or drop-off container may only be placed on the parking lot of a building site containing 50,000 square feet or more of floor area. A collection machine may be placed on the parking lot of a building site containing 50,000 square feet or more of floor area, or on the parking lot of a building site containing a retail food store with 20,000 square feet or more of floor area. Not more than one collection center is permitted on a building site. 
(d)  A collection center located on a parking lot may not occupy required off-street parking spaces. A collection center shall be arranged so as to not impede free flow of traffic. 
(e)  Receipt of and payment for cans, glass, and paper at a collection center located on a parking lot may take place outside the collection center, but at a point no more than 20 feet from the opening of the enclosed vehicle where the products are stored. 
(f)  The owner of the property and the owner and operator of the collection center shall not process or flatten the products on the site. It is a defense to prosecution that the flattening of beverage cans is being conducted wholly within an automatic collection machine. 
(g)  The owner of the property and the owner and operator of the collection center shall remove products stored at the collection center at least once a week. 
(h)  The owner of the property and the owner and operator of the collection center shall keep the collection center in proper repair and the exterior shall have a neat and clean appearance. 
(i)  The owner of the property and the owner and operator of the collection center shall keep the building site clean and in a neat appearance and shall dispose of cans and other litter from the building site where the collection center is located. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.213; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-413. - Warehouse. 
(a)  Retail sales are permitted as a part of the warehouse use if the sales are conducted in compliance with the following: 
(1)  Up to 100 percent of the total warehouse floor area may be devoted to retail sales activities during an occasional warehouse sale. No more than four occasional warehouse sales may be conducted during any 12-month period. Each occasional warehouse sale shall be limited in duration to no more than three consecutive calendar days. 
(2)  Retail sales are permitted at all times as part of the warehouse use when the retail sales area does not exceed ten percent of the total warehouse floor area. 
(b)  In the Mixed Use District, this use shall not exceed 10,000 square feet and must include a retail outlet. Outside storage is not permitted. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.213; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3115, § 50, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 18-414-18-423. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 15. - WIRELESS TELECOMMUNICATION FACILITIES USES 

Sec. 18-424. - Commercial radio or TV facility. 
    See Article IX of this chapter for additional provisions related to commercial radio or TV facilities. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.212; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2524, § 5, 10-12-98; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-425. - Commercial satellite dish. 
    See Article IX of this chapter for additional provisions related to commercial satellite dishes. 
(Ord. No. 2524, § 5, 10-12-98; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-426. - Mobile telephone facility. 
    See Article IX of this chapter for additional provisions related to mobile telephone facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2524, § 5, 10-12-98; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-427. - Public safety telecommunications facility. 
    See Article IX of this chapter for additional provisions related to public safety facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2524, § 5, 10-12-98; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 18-428-18-437. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2550, § 5, adopted July 12, 1999 repealed former Art. V of Ch. 18 in its entirety. Former Art. V, §§ 18-566-18-570, 18-596-18-598, pertained to environmental performance standards and derived from the 1975 Code, §§ 58-9.101, 58-9.102, 58-9.104, 58-9.106, 58-9.107, 58-9.201, 58-9.202, 58-9.301; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, adopted Aug. 10, 1992; and Ord. No. 2279, §§ 179, 180, 182, 184, adopted Aug. 9, 1993. Environmental standards can be found in Ch. 38. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-438. - Dwelling unit density. 
(a)  A person shall not erect, alter, or convert any structure or part of a structure to create a greater dwelling unit density than is allowed in the district regulations. 
(b)  Dwelling unit density is based on gross acreage in a parcel at the time of application for a subdivision plat for single-family development or manufactured homes, or development permit application for all other residential development. 
(c)  Cluster development is permitted as long as the overall dwelling unit density within the entire parcel is within the limits provided by the district regulations and the project otherwise meets other yard, lot, and space standards. When such development maximizes permitted dwelling unit density and creates open spaces, that open space shall be permanent open space which may be achieved by dedication to the city or to a homeowners' association, or through deed restrictions. Common open space may not be used at some future time to increase the dwelling unit density within the original tract. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.404; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-439. - Lot coverage. 
(a)  No person shall erect, alter, or convert any structure or part of a structure to create greater lot coverage than is allowed in the district regulations. 
(b)  Surface parking, driveways, and walkways are not counted in calculating coverage. 
(c)  In calculating coverage for antennae towers, elevated tanks and similar structures, a horizontal rectangle shall be placed around the furthermost parts of the structure and projected to the ground. The area covered by this projection shall be considered the coverage of the structure. The board in reviewing a development permit may use a different method to calculate this coverage if the method: 
(1)  Results in providing space for landscaping; 
(2)  Avoids crowding of structures on the lot; and 
(3)  Does not create negative impacts on adjacent property. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.407; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2815, § 32, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-440. - Floor area. 
(a)  General provisions. 
(1)  Floor area is the total square feet of floor area in a building measured to the outside faces of exterior walls or to the omitted wall lines, whichever produces the larger area. 
(2)  Floor area ratio is the ratio of the total floor area to the area of the site. In calculating floor area ratio for a building or a site, the following areas are excluded: 
a.  The floor area of a structure used for off-street parking. 
b.  The floor area in a basement. 
(3)  A different minimum floor area for a residential use or a different maximum floor area ratio for a nonresidential use may be established through the development permit review process, if the board applies performance criteria or standards that: 
a.  Have been adopted by the board; and 
b.  Are available to the applicant prior to submission of the application for a development permit. 
(b)  Residential development. 
(1)  No person shall erect, alter, or convert any structure or part of a structure to create residential dwelling units with less floor area than the minimum required in the district regulations. 
(2)  In the event a development permit is approved with a minimum floor area different from the minimum contained in the district regulations, the minimum floor area contained in the development permit shall control. 
(c)  Ratio for nonresidential development. 
(1)  No person shall erect, alter, or convert any structure or part of a structure to create a greater floor area ratio than is allowed in the district regulations. 
(2)  In the event a development permit is approved with a maximum floor area ratio different from the maximum contained in the district regulations, the maximum floor area ratio contained in the development permit shall control. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.405; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2815, § 30, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 18-441, 18-442. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-443. - Lot size. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall erect, alter, or convert any structure or part of a structure to create residential lots with less area than the minimum required in the district regulations. 
(b)  The city or other governmental agency may reduce the lot size by widening an abutting street or alley. In this situation the minimum lot area is computed on the basis of the original lot size before the street widening. 
(c)  A larger lot size than the minimum may be required as a condition of approval of a subdivision plat, as provided in the district regulations. In the event a subdivision plat is approved with a minimum lot area greater than the minimum contained in the district regulations, the minimum floor area contained in the subdivision plat shall control. 
(d)  These regulations do not specify minimum requirements for lot frontage, width, or depth. These features shall be determined during the subdivision plat review process and generally be guided by: 
(1)  The lot frontage, width, and depth of existing development within 300 feet of the proposed development; 
(2)  Access to the lot by vehicular and pedestrian traffic; and 
(3)  The architectural design of the structures. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.408; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2279, §§ 61, 62, 8-9-93; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-444. - Front yards. 
(a)  General provisions. 
(1)  Front yards are determined through the development permit review process. Minimum front yards are established for each district. A front yard greater than the minimum may be required up to the maximum front yard within each district. Nothing in these regulations shall prevent the approval of front yards that are larger than the maximum that the board may require. 
(2)  In establishing a front yard requirement greater than the minimum permitted, the board shall consider the following: 
a.  The nature of front setbacks for existing development within 300 feet of the proposed development. 
b.  The number of street frontages for the building site. If the site has more than one street frontage, different front yard setbacks may be needed on the different streets. 
c.  Front setbacks for the proposed development that would ensure compatibility between the proposed development and existing development, or act as a transition between the proposed development and adjacent existing development. 
d.  The design and location of off-street parking and the manner in which the proposed development will handle ingress and egress to the site. 
e.  The nature of the adjacent public thoroughfare and the impact of the proposed development on it. 
f.  The ability to landscape the front yard of the site and its contribution to the visual quality of the street. 
(3)  In the event a development permit is approved with a front yard different from the minimum contained in the district regulations, the front yard specified in the development permit shall control. 
(4)  Required front yards shall be left open and unobstructed except for fences and landscaping, and parking in driveways or permitted parking space of single-family dwellings. 
(5)  The front yard setback is measured from the front lot line of the building site or the required right-of-way as determined by the transportation element of the Comprehensive Plan for all thoroughfares except local streets, whichever creates the greater setback. For local streets, the front yard setback is measured from the front lot line of the building site or the existing right-of-way, whichever creates the greater setback. 
(b)  Residential development. 
(1)  For individual lots or home sites with two or more front yards that are developed for single-family, two-family, or manufactured home uses, a primary front yard may be designated on a plat or on a site plan approved as part of the development permit review process. The designated front yard shall comply with all front yard provisions of this chapter. The remaining front yards may be fenced or landscaped under provisions for side or rear yards as appropriate. 
(2)  A front yard setback may be established for residential development that is staggered when: 
a.  Used to vary the setback of structures on adjacent lots in accordance with Part 2 of Division 2 of this article; and 
b.  All off-street parking requirements are met by parking spaces located behind the front yard setback except as permitted by Section 18-597. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.401; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2574, §§ 2, 3, 10-25-99; Ord. No. 2815, § 27, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3233, § 2, 4-9-13; Ord. No. 3279, § 3, 12-17-13) 
Sec. 18-445. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-446. - Side yards. 
(a)  Side yards are determined through the development permit review process. Minimum side yards are established for each district. A side yard greater than the minimum may be required up to the maximum side yard within each district. Nothing in these regulations shall prevent the approval of side yards that are larger than the maximum that the board may require. 
(b)  In establishing a side yard requirement greater than the minimum permitted, the board shall consider the following: 
(1)  The nature of side yard setbacks for existing development within 300 feet of the proposed development. 
(2)  Side yard setbacks for the proposed development that would ensure compatibility between the proposed development and existing development, or act as a transition between the proposed development and adjacent existing development. 
(3)  The design and location of off-street parking and the manner in which the proposed development will handle ingress and egress to the site. 
(4)  The ability to landscape the side yard of the site and its contribution to the visual quality of the development. 
(c)  In the event a development permit is approved with a side yard different from the minimum contained in the district regulations, the side yard specified in the development permit shall control. 
(d)  Required side yards shall be left open and unobstructed except for fences, landscaping, golf safety nets as permitted in Section 18-166, buildings less than 120 square feet in area, and permitted parking spaces and driveways. 
(e)  The side yard setback is measured from the side lot line of the building site. 
(f)  In commercial districts, side yards may be omitted if rear access to the building is provided from an alley or along one side of the building. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.402; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2815, § 28, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3020, § 4, 12-18-07, eff. 4-1-08; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3233, § 3, 4-9-13) 
Sec. 18-447. - Rear yards. 
(a)  Rear yards are determined through the development permit review process. Minimum rear yards are established for each district. A rear yard greater than the minimum may be required up to the maximum rear yard within each district. Nothing in these regulations shall prevent the approval of rear yards that are larger than the maximum that the board may require. 
(b)  In establishing a rear yard requirement greater than the minimum permitted, the board shall consider the following: 
(1)  The nature of rear yard setbacks for existing development within 300 feet of the proposed development. 
(2)  Rear yard setbacks for the proposed development that would ensure compatibility between the proposed development and existing development, or act as a transition between the proposed development and adjacent existing development. 
(3)  The design and location of off-street parking and the manner in which the proposed development will handle ingress and egress to the site. 
(4)  The ability to landscape the rear yard of the site and its contribution to the visual quality of the development. 
(c)  In the event a development permit is approved with a rear yard different from the minimum contained in the district regulations, the rear yard specified in the development permit shall control. 
(d)  Required rear yards shall be left open and unobstructed except for fences, landscaping, golf safety nets as permitted in Section 18-166, buildings less than 120 square feet in area, and permitted parking spaces and driveways for lots that have alley access or a second access point on a corner lot. For single-family detached dwelling units, open unenclosed covered rear patios, and decks between 30 inches and eight feet in height, may encroach into the required rear yard setback up to ten feet from the rear property line in the SFD, SFA, MF and PD zoning districts, unless otherwise regulated in the PD standards, provided they do not encroach into any easements. 
(e)  The rear yard setback is measured from the rear lot line of the building site. 
(f)  A rear yard setback may be established for residential development that is staggered to the minimum allowed when it is used to vary the setback of structures on adjacent lots in accordance with Part 2 of Division 2 of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.403; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2279, § 60, 8-9-93; Ord. No. 2574, § 4, 10-25-99; Ord. No. 2815, § 29, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3020, § 5, 12-18-07, eff. 4-1-08; Ord. No. 3164, § 2, 3-22-11; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3233, § 4, 4-9-13) 
Secs. 18-448, 18-449. - Reserved.

Sec. 18-451. - Height. 
(a)  Height is measured as the vertical distance from grade to the highest point of the structure. 
(b)  No person shall erect, alter, or convert any structure or part of a structure to be higher than the maximum height permitted in the district regulations, except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(c)  In districts where maximum height is limited to 35 feet or less, the following building-mounted structures may project a maximum of 12 feet above the maximum structure height specified in the district regulations. 
(1)  Elevator penthouses or bulkhead. 
(2)  Mechanical equipment room. 
(3)  Cooling tower. 
(4)  Tank designed to hold liquids. 
(5)  Ornamental cupola or dome. 
(6)  Skylights. 
(7)  Clerestory. 
(8)  Visual screens which surround roof-mounted mechanical equipment. 
(9)  Chimney and vent stacks. 
(10)  Parapet wall, limited to a height of four feet. 
(d)  The heights allowed in subsection (c) of this section are subject to residential proximity slope height restriction. 
(e)  Poles or support structures for electric transmission lines constructed in a Single-Family Detached, Single-Family Attached, Multifamily, Residential Estate or Manufactured Home Zoning District shall not exceed 120 feet in height, except for traverse conditions. A traverse condition exists if the utility demonstrates that it will encounter and cross one or more of the following: traffic light, bridge, highway or arterial roadway, overhead pedestrian walkway, intersection of roadway, wetland, floodplain, waterway, gravel pit, railroad, electric distribution line, phone line, streetlight, storage yard, parking lot, or tree. This height restriction may also be waived by the board if any other condition causes the electric conductors to be in violation of local, State or national codes. This limitation shall only apply to new construction and not to the repair, replacement or modification of an existing pole or structure so long as the repair, replacement or modification does not cause a pole or structure to exceed 120 feet in height in the above-listed zoning districts. 
(f)  General height requirements for retail centers larger than four acres. 
(1)  In Community Retail (CR) and Regional Commercial (RC) zoning districts the maximum height for towers, bell towers, spires and other architectural appurtenances that are used to enhance the identity of the retail center and provide a focal point for customer interaction is limited to 90 feet or less in height. The retail center shall be at least four acres in size. 
(2)  The heights allowed in this subsection are subject to the residential proximity slope height restrictions. 
(3)  The architectural design of these architectural appurtenances is subject to the architectural design standards of the Thornton City Code as amended. 
(4)  Signs will not be permitted on these towers, bell towers, spires and other architectural appurtenances. 
(5)  Any lighting on these architectural appurtenances shall be reviewed as part of the development permit. 
(g)  Catenary or other lines and support structures to provide electrical service to rail mass transit electric multiple unit vehicles, excluding street cars, are exempt from the height restrictions of this Section 18-451. 
(Code 1975, § 58-2.406; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2295, § 9, 11-15-93; Ord. No. 2524, § 6, 10-12-98; Ord. No. 2634, § 1, 9-25-00; Ord. No. 2815, § 31, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3009, § 1, 9-11-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-452. - Residential proximity slope. 
(a)  Definitions. In this section, the following definition of general terms shall apply: 
(1)  Private property means any property not dedicated to public use, except that private property does not include: 
a.  A private street or alley; 
b.  Railroad rights-of-way; 
c.  Ditch rights-of-way; or 
d.  A cemetery or mausoleum. 
(2)  Restricted building or structure means the building or structure whose height is restricted by a residential proximity slope. 
(3)  Site of origination means any private property in a residential district, or any identifiable portion of a Planned Development District, which portion is restricted to residential uses not exceeding 35 feet in height. 
(b)  Residential proximity slope defined. The residential proximity slope is a plane projected upward and outward from every site of origination as defined in subsection (a)(3) of this section. Specifically, the slope is projected from the line formed by the intersection of: 
(1)  The vertical plane extending through the boundary line of the site of origination; and 
(2)  The grade of the restricted building or structure. 
(c)  Angle of projection. The angle of projection of the residential proximity slope depends on the zoning category of the site of origination as follows: 
Zoning District of Site of Origination Angle of Projection A, RE, SFD, SFA 11.3° (1 to 5 slope) MF 18.4° (1 to 3 slope)  
(d)  Calculation of height restriction. The horizontal distances used to calculate the height restriction imposed by the residential proximity slope may be determined by using the dimensions shown on the official plat or zoning maps of the city, or by scale measurement of the distances on such official maps. All dimensions and methodology used in determining the distance measurement are subject to the approval of the board in the development permit review process. 

(Code 1975, § 58-2.406; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 2815, § 31, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 18-453-18-462. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DESIGN STANDARDS 
Part 1. - Generally 

Sec. 18-463. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to provide for uniform performance standards and criteria for the design of buildings within the city in recognition that quality and compatibility of building design directly impact the health, safety and welfare of the citizenry and stimulate economic stability through orderly growth and enhancement of the tax base essential to the generation of funds adequate to address the increasing demands for municipal services. These purposes are achieved through: 
(1)  The enhancement of the physical character of the community and quality of life of its citizens through the coordinated control of the built environment created by development; 
(2)  The balancing of aesthetic design qualities with functional development and utility resulting in a community offering benefits as a place to live, recreate, and work; 
(3)  The preservation and enhancement of the physical character, integrity, and quality of community areas, particularly those areas having a discernible character or special historic, or other significance; 
(4)  The enhancement and protection of the property values, occupancies of uses of the surrounding areas in furtherance of the Comprehensive Plan and other development goals and objectives of the city; 
(5)  The stimulation of improvements and maintenance of surrounding properties, thereby preventing and reversing the effects of urban blight and deterioration; and 
(6)  The heightening of community expectations and awareness concerning the design quality of the built environment and its positive influence on the citizens of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 58-8.101; Ord. No. 2183, § 1, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 18-464-18-469. - Reserved. 
Part 2. - Residential Design Standards 

Sec. 18-470. - Single-family detached and duplex residential and development projects. 
    Design review standards for single-family detached and duplex residential and development projects are as follows: 
(1)  Façades. 
a.  All subdivisions with more than 20 lots shall offer at least four different home models (with distinctly different floor plans). No identical home model elevation shall be repeated more than once every four lots (i.e. the first and fourth lots in a row may contain the same model elevation, but the second and third lots must contain two different model elevations). No identical home model elevation shall be repeated directly across any street from itself. For purposes of this section, each home model elevation used to satisfy this requirement shall incorporate at least three of the following nine areas: 
1.  The placement of windows and doors on the front façade elevation (at least a two-foot vertical or horizontal variation in size or location is required). 
2.  The use of different materials on the front façade elevation. 
3.  The width of the front façade elevation must differ more than two feet. 
4.  The locations and proportions of front porches must vary substantially. 
5.  The location and proportion of garage doors must vary substantially. 
6.  Variations in the front plane and roofline. 
7.  Use of roof dormers. 
8.  A variation of building types: ranch, two-story and split-level. 
9.  Window shapes that are substantially different. 
b.  All of the homes on corner lots, and 45 percent of the remainder of the homes in the filing, shall meet the requirements of either subsection b.1 or b.2 below: 
1.  An area equivalent to at least 30 percent of the first floor front façade elevation (including window and door areas and related trim areas) shall be clad in brick, stone, stucco, or other approved masonry materials; 
2.  An area equivalent to at least 15 percent of the first floor front façade elevation (including window and door areas and related trim areas) shall be clad in brick, stone, stucco, or other approved masonry materials if two or more of the following applies: 
i.  All portions of each first floor front façade elevation which extend beyond the primary front wall plane of the home and which are clad in brick, stone, stucco or an approved masonry material shall continue such materials back to the primary front wall plane of the home.
