DIVISION 7. - OTHER DISPLAYS ON WALLS, STRUCTURES, OR SITES 

Sec. 18-770. - General provisions. 
(a)  Except as stated in subsection (b) below, this Division 7 applies to all displays on walls, or structures that: 
(1)  Are not exempt from the requirements of this article under Section 18-705; 
(2)  Are not prohibited signs under Section 18-706; 
(3)  Do not qualify as attached signs under Division 3, freestanding signs under Division 4, or temporary signs under Division 6; and 
(4)  Exceed the height, size, duration, or another physical standard in this article. 
(b)  This section does not apply to any city-sponsored sign, work of art, or wall graphics that are located: 
(1)  On city property; or 
(2)  On public utility boxes, meters, or panels where such placement is allowed by a written contract with the city and/or public utility company. 
(Ord. No. 3439, § 1(Exh. A), 6-13-17) 
Sec. 18-771. - Special review required. 
(a)  Applications for approval of a display under this Division 7 shall be reviewed by the Thornton Arts, Sciences, and Humanities Council (TASHCO) pursuant to the review criteria in Section 18-772. 
(b)  A decision on the application shall be made within 45 days after the city's receipt of a complete application. Any appeal of the decision shall be heard and resolved as set forth in Section 18-718(a) (Appeals). 
(c)  An approved special display expands the number, size, and duration of signs otherwise permitted on the property. Any approval of a special display shall not affect the ability of the applicant to erect or maintain any other signs on the property permitted by this article and the approved display shall not be included in calculations to determine the total sign area or number of authorized signs. 
(d)  An approval under this Division 7 runs with the property unless otherwise specified by TASHCO in the approval document and all conditions and limitations related to the approval shall be binding on future owners and users of the property. 
(Ord. No. 3439, § 1(Exh. A), 6-13-17) 
Sec. 18-772. - Review criteria. 
    The TASHCO may approve an application for a special display if it finds that the proposed display: 
(1)  Is a form of speech or expression protected by the First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and/or the Colorado Constitution; 
(2)  Will be created, constructed, erected, or displayed in a way that is visually distinct from other permitted signs on the property; 
(3)  If located on public property, will activate or enhance a public space or streetscape; 
(4)  Does not exceed the dimensions of any surface upon which it is mounted; 
(5)  Will be treated to address vandalism and exposure to sun; 
(6)  Will not require extensive or repeated maintenance, or the applicant has provided adequate assurance (including financial assurance) that maintenance and repairs will be timely performed; 
(7)  Does not create a threat to public health or safety or to vehicular, bicycle, or pedestrian traffic safety; 
(8)  Does not create noise, sound, light, reflection, glare, shading, flickering, vibration, or odor impacts on nearby properties; and 
(9)  Does not impair the performance of required city functions on or around the property. 
(Ord. No. 3439, § 1(Exh. A), 6-13-17) 
Sec. 18-773. - Maintenance required. 
    The maintenance standards in Section 18-704 apply to all special displays approved under this Division 7. 
(Ord. No. 3439, § 1(Exh. A), 6-13-17) 
Sec. 18-774-18-799. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - RESIDENTIAL GROWTH PACING SYSTEM 

Sec. 18-800. - Purpose and intent. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to establish a system to provide for the uniform distribution of residential building permits at a rate that relates to historic development in Thornton and allows for coordinated control by the city council based on economic indicators, community desires, and the available public and private resources for development and public infrastructure at such time as the city council makes a determination to enact residential growth pacing allocations. 
(b)  The residential growth pacing system promotes the health, safety, and the general welfare of the city in order to: 
(1)  Implement the city's goals, policies, plan, and regulations related to land development; 
(2)  Promote orderly growth and provide for harmonious development of the city in accordance with the Comprehensive Plan relating to growth, community character, transportation, infrastructure, community facilities, and economic development; 
(3)  Conserve and stabilize the value of real property in the city; 
(4)  Protect private property rights as required by the U.S. and Colorado constitutions, statutes, and case law as applied to a Colorado home-rule municipality; 
(5)  Facilitate adequate provision of utilities and public facilities such as transportation, water, sewer, drainage, parks and open space, schools, libraries, and other public facilities; 
(6)  Promote a more balanced community where there is space to live, recreate and work; 
(7)  Ensure that the community character of the city as a desirable place to live and conduct business is not eroded; and 
(8)  Provide for proper distribution of the residential population in the city and the amenities necessary for stable and enduring neighborhoods. 
(Ord. No. 3012, § 1, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-801. - Exclusions. 
    Any residential development that has a Metropolitan District Service Plan approved by the city council shall not be subject to this article. 
(Ord. No. 3012, § 1, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-802. - Definitions. 
(a)  Terms used in this article that are defined in Chapter 18, Article XI of the Thornton City Code, shall have the same meaning for the purposes of this article, except that the definitions given for terms in Section 18-802 shall prevail whenever there is a conflict. Terms specifically defined in Section 18-802 shall have the meanings ascribed to them for use in administering and applying this article. 
(b)  Specific terms. 
(1)  Active residential development project means a project for which one or more building permits for dwelling units have been issued, but the project is not yet completed, i.e. certificates of occupancy have not been issued for one or more dwelling units in the project. 
(2)  Applicant means the person, persons, legal entity or entities submitting an application for residential development allocations. 
(3)  City Center Area means the area intended by the city for development of an urban center with higher intensity residential, retail, office, and entertainment uses. The City Center Area is defined by East 88 th Avenue to the south, Grant Street to the east, East 98 th Avenue west to Interstate 25, then following the City of Thornton municipal limits west from Interstate 25 to Switzer Lane, then south along Huron Street back to East 88 th Avenue. 
(4)  Contact person means the individual identified on an application for residential development allocations as representing the applicant for purposes of receiving communications and notices from the city pertaining to the application. 
(5)  Residential development means construction activity resulting in the production of dwelling units according to plans approved by the city. 
(6)  Residential development project or project means a residential development contained within a filing of a recorded subdivision. 
(7)  Residential development allocation or allocation means an awarded approval for the construction of a single residential unit. 
(8)  Residential development, multifamily means residential development at a dwelling unit density of more than 12 units per acre, excluding residential development in manufactured home parks. 
(9)  Residential development, medium-density means residential development at a dwelling unit density between five and 12 units per acre, excluding residential development in manufactured home parks. 
(10)  Residential development, single-family means residential development at a dwelling unit density of less than five units per acre, excluding residential development in manufactured home parks. 
(11)  Subdivided lot means a lot created by a recorded subdivision plat. 
(12)  Phase means a portion of a subdivision as defined in the approved developer's agreement that is self-sustained in regards to utilities and vehicular access in accordance with the City of Thornton Standards and Specifications. 
(Ord. No. 3012, § 1, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-803. - Applicability and projects of special merit. 
(a)  Residential development allocation required. Upon establishment of residential development growth allocations by city council, no building permit for construction of a residential dwelling unit or for a structure containing multiple residential dwelling units shall be issued by the city unless the applicant is either: 
(1)  Granted a residential development allocation for each dwelling unit subject to the building permit to be issued, or 
(2)  Satisfies the requirements set forth in subsection (b) below. 
(b)  Applicability. The following types of development are excluded from the requirement of securing a residential development allocation prior to the issuance of a building permit: 
(1)  All nonresidential development, including agricultural, industrial, institutional and community service, lodging, office, recreation, retail and personal service, temporary, transportation, utility and public service, wholesale, distribution and storage, and accessory uses, and wireless telecommunication facilities. 
(2)  Redevelopment, remodeling, restoration, reconstruction, or replacement of legally established structures that does not increase the number of residential dwelling units that existed previously on the site. 
(3)  Single-family residential development or medium-density residential development on lots that have a recorded subdivision plat and approved architectural review prior to July 12, 1999. Recorded plats as of July 12, 1999, that are required by the city to be replatted after July 12, 1999, shall also be exempt if the replatting does not increase the number of residential lots contained in the original recorded plat. 
(4)  Single-family residential development or medium-density residential development on lots in an amended subdivision plat recorded after July 12, 1999 if the original subdivision plat was recorded prior to July 12, 1999, and the amendment does not increase the number of residential lots contained in the original subdivision plat. 
(5)  Multifamily residential development that has submitted a complete application for a preliminary plat and for a development permit prior to July 12, 1999. 
(6)  Multifamily residential development with a minimum density of 25 units per acre on a site located entirely within the boundaries of the city Center. The City Center Area is defined by East 88 th Avenue to the south, Grant Street to the east, East 98 th Avenue west to Interstate 25, then following the City of Thornton municipal limits west from Interstate 25 to Switzer Lane, then south along Huron Street back to East 88 th Avenue. 
(7)  The placement or replacement of a manufactured home on a space or lot in a manufactured home park in existence prior to July 12, 1999. The replacement of a manufactured home on a space or lot in a manufactured home park created on or after July 12, 1999, if the space or lot received an initial award of a residential development allocation. 
(8)  Residential development designated by the city council as a project of special merit at the time of an annexation agreement. An applicant shall obtain a determination from the city council that a residential development qualifies for this designation as provided in Section 18-804. 
(9)  Residential development determined by the city council to be a project of special merit. An applicant shall obtain a determination from the city council that a residential development qualifies for this designation as provided in Section 18-804 below. 
(10)  Residential development proposed for property annexed to the city after July 12, 1999, for which a Newmark Agreement is in effect as of the date of the annexation petition. Properties having Newmark Agreements are the following: 
a.  The Newmark property located on the northeast corner of 112 th Avenue and Holly Street, consisting of approximately 118 acres; 
b.  The Wright Farms property located at the northeast corner of 120 th Avenue and Holly Street, consisting of approximately 156 acres; 
c.  The Funk Farms property located at the northeast corner of 136 th Avenue and York Street, consisting of approximately 154 acres; 
d.  The North York Land Associates property located at the intersection of 144 th Avenue and York Street, consisting of approximately 330 acres; 
e.  The Regal Properties located at 151 st Avenue and Washington Street, consisting of approximately 73 acres, described as the NE 1/4 of Section 15, Township 1 South, Range 68 West of the 6 th P.M.; 
f.  The North Colorado Boulevard Land Associates property located at the southwest corner of 144 th Avenue and York Street, consisting of approximately 240 acres; 
g.  The CAHB property located at the southwest corner of 160 th Avenue and Washington Street, consisting of approximately 160 acres; and 
h.  The Lee Carlson property described as the West 1/2 of Section 20, Township 1 South, Range 68 West of the 6 th P.M. 
(11)  Residential development in which a property owner is requesting no more than one building permit for a single dwelling unit in any one calendar year. For purposes of this section, lots owned by any persons, legal entities or any combination thereof that has a common ownership interest of more than 50 percent in each entity shall be deemed to have the same property owner. 
(Ord. No. 3012, § 1, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-804. - Designations of special merit. 
(a)  An applicant desiring a designation of special merit shall file a written request for this designation with the director. Such requests shall be filed on a form furnished by the department and shall provide a written justification as to how the request fulfills the criteria set forth in this section. The burden of proof shall be upon the applicant to present the case that the designation is justified, and to supply information deemed necessary for that purpose. 
(1)  Action by city council. Requests for designation of special merit shall be forwarded to the city council for action at a regular city council meeting. The city staff shall make a recommendation whether the request meets the criteria set forth in this section. The city council shall act by resolution to approve or deny the request based on the criteria set forth in this section. An action on a designation of special merit is at the sole discretion of city council. The city council may elect to approve all or a portion of the designation request. 
(2)  Public hearing. Prior to action on any request for designation of special merit, the city council shall hold a public hearing on the request. Notice of the public hearing shall be given in accordance with the requirements for a public hearing for zoning district changes in Section 18-41 of the City Code. 
(3)  Criteria for designation of special merit. The city council may act to approve a request for designation of special merit, if the project meets one or more of the following criteria: 
a.  The request contributes to the maintenance or expansion of the community's economic base. 
b.  The request will result in the guaranteed construction or funding of extraordinary infrastructure such as roads, water or sewer lines, storm drainage, parks or open space intended to serve community or regional needs greater than needs of the residential development subject to the request. 
c.  The request fulfills community goals or needs identified by city council as deserving particular attention, or provides particular community benefits. 
d.  The request is for property that is or will be entirely included in a special district approved by the city. 
e.  Multifamily residential development that provides at least three, and at the discretion of city council more, of the following at the time of a development permit: 
1.  At least eight of the architectural quality enhancements listed in Section 18-472(11) of the City Code. 
2.  The minimum landscape requirements in Division 3 of Article V and Section 18-472 for the project are exceeded by 25 percent in materials or area requirements. 
3.  All residential buildings within the project are separated from residential property lines by at least 70 feet and are separated from commercial or other land use property lines by at least 50 feet. 
4.  The project provides at least one additional on-site recreational amenity as defined in Section 18-472(9) of the Thornton City Code. 
5.  The project provides at least one full size enclosed garage parking space for each unit. 
f.  Developments which demonstrate that the amount of water required to maintain landscaping of the project, once established, will be reduced by one-third of the water required under current landscape standards. 
(4)  Vested rights. Any residential development receiving "vesting rights" after October 26, 1999 in accordance with City Code and state statutes shall be subject to the provisions of this subsection if requesting a designation of special merit. 
(Ord. No. 3012, § 1, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-805. - Residential development allocations. 
(a)  Allocation categories. The annual allocation shall separately establish the number of residential development allocations that shall be available in each of the following categories: 
(1)  Single-family residential development; 
(2)  Medium-density residential development; 
(3)  Multifamily residential development; 
(4)  Manufactured home parks; and 
(5)  Housing mix. 
(b)  Allocations. 
(1)  If the city council desires to activate the residential growth pacing system, the city council shall conduct a public hearing to establish by ordinance the number of residential development allocations to be made available and the effective date for the requirement that allocations be obtained. The number of allocations shall be specified by the categories set forth in this section. Notice of the public hearing shall be given in accordance with the requirements for a public hearing for zoning district changes in Section 18-41 of the City Code. 
(2)  The residential growth pacing system is established based on quarters. If the city council chooses to activate the residential growth pacing system other than at the beginning of a calendar year, the start date will correspond to the beginning of the next calendar quarter. 
(3)  Number of allocations-Factors to consider. The city council may consider the following factors in determining the number of allocations: 
a.  Projected municipal revenues and expenditures in the following year, and progress in providing infrastructure and services to cure existing deficiencies and to serve new development. 
b.  Expansion or contraction of the city's commercial and industrial economic base, and the effect on tax revenues to the city. 
c.  Traffic conditions and school occupancy conditions. 
d.  Data indicating the number of residential dwelling units built during the prior year by type and location, the current reservations of residential development allocations for future years, and the availability of staff to process residential development applications. 
e.  Past and projected growth in the local and regional area, changes in the cost of living, and other economic indicators including job growth. 
f.  Annexations approved after January 1, 2000, that have not been exempted from the requirement to obtain allocations. 
g.  Allocation absorption schedules submitted in accordance with Section 18-806(a). 
h.  Applications for the multifamily residential category on file from the previous calendar year as provided in Section 18-807(c)(2). 
i.  The city council shall also take into consideration the recommendation of the city staff on the number of allocations to be made available and on proposals for procedural or substantive changes to improve the administration and operation of this article. 
j.  Notwithstanding the provisions in subsection (5), the minimum number of allocations to be made available for the single-family residential category shall be determined as set forth in subsection (4). 
(4)  Minimum number of allocations for single-family residential category. The minimum number of allocations to be made available for the single-family residential category shall be equal to the three-year average for number of building permits issued for single-family dwelling units, as defined herein, in the five years preceding the year in which the allocation is set by city council, excluding the following: 
a.  Building permits for single-family dwelling units or medium-density dwelling units exempted from this article through an approved annexation agreement (see Section 18-803). 
b.  Building permits for single-family dwelling units or medium-density dwelling units exempted from this article as "residential developments of special merit" (see Section 18-804). 
c.  Year having the lowest number of building permits, with medium-density dwelling units included with the single-family permits through the year 2000. 
d.  Year having the highest number of building permits, with medium-density dwelling units included with the single-family permits through the year 2000. 
e.  The number of allocations for the single-family residential category established by city council may be higher but shall not be lower than the required minimum. 
(5)  Revision to allocation. The city council may revise the number of allocations established for a given calendar year if it determines that economic conditions are such that the number of allocations needs to be either increased or decreased, except that the number of allocations for the single-family residential category shall not be less than the minimum using the procedure set forth in subsection (4) above. The city council shall take action to revise the annual allocation by ordinance. Prior to revising the annual allocation, the city council shall hold a public hearing on the revision. Notice of the public hearing shall be given in accordance with the requirements for a public hearing for zoning district changes in Section 18-41 of the City Code. 
(c)  Housing mix category. 
(1)  Purpose. This category is intended to promote an adequate mix of housing types in the city through making residential development allocations available for specific housing types that are unavailable or have limited availability in the city's housing inventory. 
(2)  Assigning allocations to housing mix category. As part of establishing the annual number of residential development allocations, the city council may deem it appropriate to assign allocations to the housing mix category and to specify the housing type eligible to apply for these allocations. 
(Ord. No. 3012, § 1, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-806. - Administration of single-family and medium-density residential categories. 
(a)  Allocation absorption schedules. 
(1)  Allocation absorption schedules for proposed subdivision plats. Each application for subdivision plat approval for single-family residential development or medium-density residential development shall include annual estimates of the number of residential development allocations expected to be requested for the five calendar years commencing with the year in which the plat is expected to be recorded. If the applicant is proposing to subdivide the residential development into two or more phases, the annual estimates shall be by phase. The annual estimates shall not exceed the limit specified in subsection (3) below. This five-year estimate shall be considered the allocation absorption schedule for the residential development. 
(2)  Allocation absorption schedules for approved subdivision plats. Applicants requesting allocations for residential development projects that received preliminary plat approval prior to January 1, 2000, shall submit to the department a five-year estimate in the form and meeting the requirements described in subsection (1) above prior to or concurrent with filing an application for residential development allocations. This five-year estimate shall be considered the allocation absorption schedule for the residential development project. 
(3)  Limit on estimates. The annual estimates contained in allocation absorption schedules required by this subsection (1) shall not exceed 120 dwelling units for each subdivision phase. 
(4)  Revisions to and extension of allocation absorption schedule. As part of the annual allocation request referenced in subsections (1) and (2), the applicant shall provide an updated allocation absorption schedule with estimates of the number of allocations expected to be requested for each of the five calendar years following the year for which the annual allocation request is being made. 
(b)  Availability of allocations by calendar quarters. The annual number of allocations for the single-family residential category and the medium-density residential category shall be divided into four equal parts, and one part shall be made available at the beginning of each calendar quarter. 
(c)  Submittal of allocation applications; submittal deadline. 
(1)  First through fourth calendar quarters of year. Applications for allocations in a given calendar quarter shall be submitted to the department no later than 30 days prior to the first day of the calendar quarter. Applications for allocations shall comply with the qualification and submittal requirements stated in Section 18-808. The department shall review applications in accordance with the procedures set forth in Section 18-808. 
(2)  Fourth quarter unused allocations. Applications for unused allocations, after the fourth quarter allocations have been awarded and noticed to builders, may be submitted to the department no later than 15 days into the fourth quarter. No allocations shall be awarded over the annual amount allowed per phase, and all fees and requirements of this article shall apply. 
(d)  Annual schedule for allocation requests. 
(1)  Schedule submitted with initial allocation requests. As part of the initial application for allocations, the applicant shall provide a schedule showing the number of allocations requested for the initial calendar quarter, and the number expected to be requested for the following three calendar quarters. The schedule for allocation requests shall be filed on a form provided by the department. The total number of allocations requested for each project in any one calendar year shall not exceed the maximum stated in subsection (3). 
(2)  Annual schedule for active projects in subsequent years. No later than August 31 st of each calendar year, applicants who have active residential development projects and who intend to request allocations in the following calendar year, shall specify to the department the number of allocations expected to be requested for each project for each calendar quarter of that following calendar year. The annual schedule for allocation requests shall be filed on a form provided by the department. The total number of allocations estimated for each project in any one calendar year shall not exceed the maximum stated in subsection (3). 
(3)  Maximum number of allocations per calendar year and per calendar quarter. The total number of allocations requested for each project in any one calendar year shall not exceed 120 dwelling units per phase of a subdivision plat. The total number of allocations requested for each project in any one calendar quarter shall not exceed 60 dwelling units per phase of a subdivision plat. 
(e)  Number of applications. An applicant may submit one or more applications in any given calendar quarter provided that each application is for dwelling units in a separate subdivision phase and no more than one application shall be submitted for any individual lot. 
(f)  Eligibility for allocations. Applications determined by the department as complying with the requirements in Section 18-808 shall be eligible to receive allocations. The department shall reject applications determined to be ineligible. 
(g)  Available allocations. The number of allocations available in any given calendar quarter shall consist of one fourth of the annual number of allocations for that calendar year, as initially determined or as revised by city council as provided in Section 18-805, and any unused allocations from the previous calendar quarter that were either not awarded, returned or became invalid as provided in this Section 18-806. 
(1)  Allocations that are not awarded in a given calendar quarter shall be made available in the following calendar quarter, except that allocations shall not be transferred from one calendar year to a subsequent calendar year. 
(2)  Allocations available after the fourth quarter has been awarded shall be made available for eligible builders, as defined in subsection (c)(2), up to their annual limit per phase. 
(h)  Award of allocations; pro-rating. 
(1)  Allocations shall be subject to the maximums set forth in subsection (d)(3) of this section. 
(2)  In each calendar quarter, if the number of allocations requested for eligible applications is less than or equal to the number available, the director shall award allocations in the amount requested to eligible projects, subject to the maximums stated in subsection (d)(3), the allowance for awards to "end of phase" requests stated in subsection (h)(4), and the penalties stated in subsection (k)(3) of this section. 
(3)  Pro-rating. If the number of allocations requested exceeds the number of available allocations, the director shall distribute the allocations to all eligible projects on a pro rata basis, subject to the maximums stated in subsection (d)(3), the allowance for awards to "end of phase" requests stated in subsection (h)(4), and the penalties stated in subsection (k)(3) of this section. For example, if applicants request 385 allocations, but only 325 allocations are available: 
_____
EXAMPLE 
Requests (385) Allocations Available (325) 
Pro Rata Share Applicant A 60 or 15.6% 15.6% of 325 = 51 allocations Applicant B 45 or 11.7% 11.7% of 325 = 38 allocations Applicant C 55 or 14.2% 14.2% of 325 = 46 allocations Applicant D 50 or 13% 13% of 325 = 42 allocations Applicant E 45 or 11.7% 11.7% of 325 = 38 allocations Applicant F 45 or 11.7% 11.7% of 325 = 38 allocations Applicant G 25 or 6.5% 6.5% of 325 = 21 allocations Applicant H 60 or 15.6% 15.6% of 325 = 51 allocations Total 385 325  
_____ 
(4)  End of phase requests. An applicant submitting an application for allocations for a subdivision phase that has ten or fewer lots for which allocations have not yet been received may request "end of phase" status as part of the application. If the application for allocations is determined to be eligible as provided under Section 18-808, and meets the criteria in this subsection for "end of phase" status, the director shall award allocations to these applications prior to awarding allocations to all other eligible applications and prior to any prorating required by subsection (3). 
(5)  Prorating. If the number of allocations requested for eligible applications is less than or equal to the number available, the director shall award allocations in the amount requested to eligible projects, subject to the maximums stated in subsection (d)(3), the allowance for awards to "end of phase" requests stated in subsection (h)(4), and the penalties stated in subsection (k)(3). 
(6)  End of year requests. If after the fourth quarter has been awarded and noticed, and there are allocations remaining, then eligible builders may request up to their annual limit per phase. The department shall award any remaining allocations on a first-come, first-served basis. 
(i)  Notification of awards. Notification of awards in the single-family residential category and medium-density residential category shall be made for each category for each calendar quarter as follows: 
(1)  Posting. The city shall publish the allocations awarded by the director by posting a listing at the City Hall. 
(2)  Notification to applicants. The listing of the awards shall be mailed by First Class U.S. Mail to the contact person for each application filed in a given calendar quarter, where the application was determined to be complete and eligible. 
(j)  Validity. 
(1)  Allocations. An allocation shall remain valid if a building permit is issued for the allocation no later than five days prior to the end of the first calendar quarter. If a building permit has not been issued by the five-day limit, and if the allocation has not been returned to the city as provided in subsection (k)(2), the allocation shall become invalid. 
(2)  An allocation shall remain valid if both of the following criteria are met: 
a.  A complete building permit application is submitted no later than 45 days from the end of the calendar quarter in which the allocation is awarded. If no building permit application has been filed by the 45-day limit, and if the allocation has not been returned to the city as provided in subsection (k)(1), the allocation shall become invalid. 
b.  A building permit is issued for the allocation no later than five days prior to the end of the calendar quarter in which the allocation is awarded. If a building permit has not been issued by the five-day limit, and if the allocation has not been returned to the city as provided in subsection (k)(2), the allocation shall become invalid. 
(k)  Unused allocations. 
(1)  Returning unused allocations if building permit applications not submitted. No later than 45 days from the end of a given calendar quarter, applicants may return allocations received in that calendar quarter for which building permits have not been issued. Applicants shall provide written notice that they are returning allocations on a form provided by the department. 
(2)  Returning unused allocations if building permits not issued. No later than five days from the end of a given calendar quarter, applicants may return allocations received in that calendar quarter for which building permits have not been issued. Applicants shall provide written notice that they are returning allocations on a form provided by the department. 
(3)  Penalties for failure to return unused allocations. If an applicant allows allocations to become invalid as provided in subsection (j) of this section, the director shall reduce the number of allocations awarded to an applicant in a given calendar quarter by a number equal to the number of allocations that the applicant allowed to become invalid in the preceding calendar quarter. 
(Ord. No. 3012, § 1, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-807. - Administration of multifamily residential, manufactured home and housing mix categories. 
(a)  Submission and evaluation of applications. Applications for allocations from the multifamily residential, manufactured home park and housing mix categories may be submitted throughout the calendar year beginning on the first business day following January 15 th . Applicants shall specify the category from which they are requesting allocations in their application. Submittal requirements are set forth in Section 18-808(b) of this article. The department shall review applications in accordance with the procedures set forth in Section 18-808. 
(b)  Eligibility for allocations. Applications determined by the department as complying with the requirements of Section 18-808 of this article shall be eligible to receive allocations. The department shall reject applications determined to be ineligible. 
(c)  Award of allocations. 
(1)  Manufactured home and housing mix categories. Beginning on January 15 th of each calendar year, allocations from the manufactured home and housing mix categories shall be awarded on a first-come, first-served basis to eligible applications as long as allocations are available in the category. A request for allocations may be for any amount up to the number of allocations available in the applicable category at the time of application. 
(2)  Multifamily residential category. Beginning on January 15 th of each calendar year, allocations from the multifamily residential category shall be awarded as follows: 
a.  First priority shall be given to eligible applications that did not receive allocations in the previous calendar year and that were placed on file by the department as provided in subsection (f). Allocations in the current calendar year shall be awarded first to these eligible applications in the order in which they were submitted in the previous calendar year, except applicants may decline receiving allocations. The number of allocations available shall be increased to allow allocations to complete projects as provided in subsection (d). 
b.  If allocations remain available after all of the applications on file from the previous year that want allocations have received allocations, allocations shall be awarded on a first-come, first-served basis to eligible applications filed in the current calendar year as long as allocations remain. The number of allocations available shall be increased to allow allocations to complete projects as provided in subsection (d). A request for allocations for a single project may be for up to 110 percent of the total number of allocations assigned to this category by the city council for the calendar year. 
(d)  Increase in allocations for multifamily residential category. If an application is received for a project in the multifamily residential category, and the number of allocations available is insufficient to allow the complete project to proceed, the director shall increase the number of allocations available if all of the following criteria are met: 
(1)  The amount of the increase needed so the total number of dwelling units in the project would receive allocations is not more than ten percent the total number of allocations assigned to this category by the city council for the calendar year. 
(2)  The increase in allocations to be allowed by the director is the minimum needed to award allocations for the total number of units in the project. 
_____
    For example, Project A described below would meet the criteria allowing the director to increase the multifamily residential allocation and Project B would not meet the criteria. 
    EXAMPLE 
PROJECT A Allocation for MF Residential Category = 400 Previous allocations from MF Residential Category = 250 Allocations remaining = 150 Project proposed = 190 Increase in Allocations needed for project proposal = 40 40 allocations = 10% of annual allocation Meets % criteria. Allocations in MF Category increased to = 440 Project awarded allocations. No further project applications accepted for calendar year.  
    EXAMPLE 
PROJECT B Allocation for MF Residential Category = 400 Previous allocations from MF Residential Category = 250 Allocations remaining = 150 Project proposed = 320 Increase in Allocations needed for project proposal = 170 170 allocations = 42.5% of annual allocation Project does not meet % criteria. Project not awarded allocations. Allocations remaining in MF Category for next application. 150  
_____
(e)  Notification. Notification of awards of residential development allocations in multifamily residential, manufactured home and housing mix categories shall be mailed by First Class U.S. Mail to the contact person specified in the application receiving an award. Notification that an application in the multifamily residential category has not received allocations and therefore has been placed on file in the department, as provided in subsection (f), shall be mailed by First Class U.S. Mail to the contact person specified in the application. 
(f)  Placing multifamily residential applications on file. When the department receives an eligible application for the multifamily residential category and an award of allocations cannot be made because insufficient allocations are available, the department shall place the application on file, unless upon notification as provided in subsection (e) of this article, the applicant withdraws the application. Applications placed on file in a given calendar year shall receive first priority for obtaining allocations in the following calendar year as provided in subsection (2)a. 
(g)  Validity of allocations. 
(1)  Multifamily residential and manufactured home park categories. An allocation awarded from the multifamily residential or manufactured home park categories shall remain valid if the first building permit is issued for the first allocation no later than 24 months from the date on which the allocation is made. If no building permits have been issued by this time limit, the allocations shall become invalid. Based on adequate documentation presented by the developer, staff may administratively grant an extension of up to 36 months for multifamily residential allocations for projects that are constructed as for-sale units. 
(2)  Housing mix category. An allocation awarded from the housing mix category shall remain valid if a building permit is issued for the allocation no later than the last business day of December in the year in which the allocation is awarded. If no building permit has been issued by this time limit, the allocation shall become invalid. 
(Ord. No. 3012, § 1, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-808. - Application procedures. 
(a)  Qualification requirements. Applicants shall fulfill the following requirements prior to filing an application for residential development allocations: 
(1)  Recordation of a subdivision plat for any lot for which allocations are requested. 
(2)  Approval of architectural reviews. 
(3)  Approval of all development permits for all landscaping and right-of-way fencing associated with the subdivision filing. 
    The director may administratively postpone, at the direction of the city manager/utilities director, the requirement for an approved landscaping plan until the water conservation standards have been adopted by city council. 
(b)  Submittal requirements. Applicants shall submit written requests for residential development allocations on an application form provided by the department. Such application shall include the following information and submittal materials: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number and signature for the applicant and property owner, if different from the applicant. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number for the developer, if different from the applicant; builder, if different from the applicant; and contact person, as defined in Section 18-802(b)(4). 
(3)  The approval date and City of Thornton development case number for the subdivision plat, architectural reviews and development permits pertinent to the application, as evidence that the qualification criteria in subsection (a) have been met. 
(4)  For applications for allocations from the single-family residential category and the medium-density residential category, submittal of an allocation absorption schedule and annual schedule as required by Section 18-806(a). If the allocation absorption schedule or annual schedule was previously submitted as part of a subdivision plat application or a previous allocation request, a copy of the schedule shall be submitted. 
(5)  For applications for allocations in the housing mix category, submittal of a complete building permit application and applicable fees. 
(6)  Vicinity map to scale with north arrow. 
(7)  Approved subdivision plat map for the development site for which allocations are being requested. The lots for which allocations are being requested shall be indicated on the approved subdivision plat. 
(8)  A listing on a form provided by the department of the allocations requested by category, and identifying the subdivision name and filing number for each project and the lots within each project for which allocations are being requested. 
(9)  Other documentation and information required by the director in order to evaluate the application, apply the requirements and procedures, and obtain compliance with the intent and purposes of this article. 
(c)  Waiver of submittal requirements. The director may waive specific submittal requirements, based on a determination by the director that the item is inappropriate or unnecessary for evaluation of the allocation request based on the size of the request or other such factors. 
(d)  Fee for review of application. A nonrefundable processing fee in the amount of $75.00 per lot associated with an allocation request shall accompany each allocation application. The application processing fee shall be in addition to all other city development processing and permit fees. 
(e)  Determination of eligibility. The director shall evaluate each application received and shall determine the application to be eligible for allocations if it meets all of the following criteria: 
(1)  If the application is for allocations from the single-family residential category or the medium-density residential category, the application has been submitted by the required time deadline stated in Section 18-806(c). 
(2)  Application meets the qualification requirements set forth in Section 18-808(a). 
(3)  Application includes all of the items required by Section 18-808(b), except for items waived in accordance with Section 18-808(c). 
(4)  Application fee required by Section 18-808(d) has been paid. 
(5)  The applicant is not under penalty for failure to return unused allocations as provided in Section 18-806(k)(3). 
(f)  Rejection of ineligible applications; notification. 
(1)  If the director determines that an application has not met the eligibility requirements contained in Section 18-807(b), the director shall reject the application in its entirety. Fees shall be refunded for any lots associated with allocations determined to be ineligible minus 15 percent to cover administrative costs. 
(2)  The department shall return by U.S. Mail applications determined to be ineligible no later than five business days following the closing day for receiving submittals, for applications for the single-family residential category or the medium-density residential category, and no later than five business days following receipt of submittals for the other categories. Ineligible applications shall not be awarded allocations. 
(g)  Withdrawal of allocation application. An applicant may elect to withdraw an allocation application without prejudice at any time prior to an award being made. Fees shall not be refunded for any lots associated with allocations that are being withdrawn. 
(h)  Award of allocations. Procedures for award of allocations are set forth for the single-family residential category and the medium-density residential category in Section 18-806, and for the multifamily residential, manufactured home and housing mix categories in Section 18-807. 
(Ord. No. 3012, § 1, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-809. - General administration and enforcement. 
(a)  Issuance of building permits. Each dwelling unit shall have a corresponding residential development allocation before a building permit allowing construction of the dwelling unit is issued, unless exempted by Section 18-803(b). Building permits shall be issued subject to compliance with all other applicable city ordinances and regulations. 
(b)  Limits on transferability of allocations. 
(1)  Allocations tied to lots, units or spaces. After an allocation becomes valid with the issuance of a building permit, the allocation shall be tied to the subdivided lot, unit or space identified in the approved building permit application. Allocations may not be transferred between subdivided lots, units or spaces unless approved by the director and the transfer may only be granted within the same subdivision plat. 
(2)  Transfers between property owners. 
a.  A valid allocation may be transferred to a lot buyer upon conveyance of the lot for which it was awarded with approval of the city. Applicants transferring allocations shall notify the city of the proposed transfer on a form provided by the department, and shall obtain approval from the director prior to the transfer. The dwelling unit to be built after the transfer shall comply with the architectural review or development permit application and the building permit application previously approved by the city for the lot at the time the allocation was awarded, except as otherwise provided in this section. 
b.  If the lot buyer is proposing to build a dwelling unit that does not comply with the previously approved architectural review or development permit application and building permit application, the lot buyer shall submit and obtain approval for a revised architectural review or development permit application and a revised building permit application prior to the city's approval of the transfer. 
(c)  Validity of allocation. 
(1)  Issuance of building permits. Once a building permit is issued, the corresponding residential development allocation shall remain valid except as otherwise provided in Section 18-806(j). All applicable city codes and ordinances shall govern completion of the residential unit or units associated with the building permit. 
(2)  Expiration of building permits; effect on allocation. If a building permit for a residential unit for which construction has not commenced is allowed to expire, and this residential unit had a residential development allocation, the allocation shall also expire and shall no longer be valid for the purposes of obtaining a building permit. 
(d)  Enforcement. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful to erect, construct, reconstruct, alter, maintain or use any building or land area in violation of any provision of this article. 
(2)  No permit, certificate, license or other document or oral approval, the use of which is subject to the provisions of these regulations, shall be issued by any department, agency, commission, board, or city council or until it has been determined that all substantive requirements of this article have been met and all procedures have been followed. 
(e)  Revocation of residential development allocation. A residential development allocation may be revoked as follows: 
(1)  The director shall have the authority to revoke a residential development allocation for the violation of any provision of this article or of any conditions imposed in the granting of the residential development allocation. Prior to revocation, the holder of the residential development allocation shall receive ten days written notice by First Class U.S. Mail of the director's intent to revoke the allocation. The notice shall include the reasons for the director's decision to revoke. The holder of the allocation may request a hearing before the director by filing a written request within five days from the end of the notice period. The hearing shall be held within ten days from the end of the notice period. 
(2)  At the conclusion of the notice period, or if a hearing is held, after the hearing is conducted, the director shall make written findings and shall take action to either revoke or to cancel the revocation of the residential development allocation. The department shall send written notice of the director's decision to the holder of the allocation by First Class U.S. Mail. 
(f)  Violations and penalties; civil enforcement. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of this article. Whenever, in any section of this article or in any section of any rule or regulation of any code or standard adopted and incorporated in this article the doing of an act is required, prohibited, or declared to be unlawful, any person who shall be convicted of a violation thereof shall, for each offense, be punished as provided in Section 1-8(a) of the City Code. Each separate day during which any violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense so punishable. 
(2)  In addition to the penalties set forth in subsection (1) above, the city attorney is authorized to bring an action before any court of suitable jurisdiction to abate, remove, or enjoin such violation and to recover damages, costs, and reasonable attorney's fees incurred in the abatement and removal of such violation. 
(Ord. No. 3012, § 1, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 18-810-18-824. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - WIRELESS TELECOMMUNICATION FACILITIES 
DIVISION 1. - DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS 

Sec. 18-825. - In general. 
(a)  Limitations . Nothing in this article shall be construed to limit other applicable ordinances of the city not in conflict with this article. If there is a conflict between this article and other regulations and standards in this chapter, this Article IX shall govern. 
(b)  Requirements . The following requirements apply to wireless telecommunications facilities as defined in Article XI and regulated in Article IV. The standards in Section 18-826(i) are intended to supplement the specific regulations for nonresidential and public safety telecommunications facilities in residential districts provided in Sections 18-827 and 18-828, respectively. The following requirements apply regardless of the zoning district in which the wireless telecommunication facility is located. 
(c)  Factors to be considered in granting specific use permits for telecommunication towers and commercial satellite dishes. In addition to the criteria stated or referred to in Section 18-160, the city shall consider the following factors in determining whether to issue a specific use permit for telecommunication facilities requiring such permits, although the city may waive or reduce the burden on the applicant of one or more of these criteria if the city concludes that the goals of this section are better served by such action. 
(1)  Height or size of the proposed facility relative to the scale of surrounding structures; 
(2)  Proximity of the facility to residential structures and residential district boundaries; 
(3)  Nature of uses on adjacent and nearby properties; 
(4)  Compatibility with the surrounding topography: 
(5)  Compatibility with the surrounding tree coverage and foliage; 
(6)  Design of the facility, with particular reference to design characteristics that have the effect of reducing or eliminating visual obtrusiveness and allow for co-location of antennae on proposed towers; 
(7)  Proposed ingress and egress; 
(8)  Evaluation of the applicant's plans for development of its telecommunication facilities within the city in accordance with the Comprehensive Plan of the city; and 
(9)  Availability of suitable existing freestanding telecommunication facilities and other structures for attachment of telecommunication antennae, the use of which would avoid construction of additional towers. 
(Ord. No. 2524, § 7, 10-12-98; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-826. - Design standards. 
(a)  Tower design. 
(1)  Use of camouflage and stealth design . All towers and satellite dishes shall be camouflaged as defined in Article XI of this chapter, except in cases in which the director determines that a specific tower shall use stealth design as defined in Article XI of this chapter. 
a.  The director, or the board as a condition of approval for a specific use permit, may require stealth design if it is determined by the city that the tower is within: 
1.  Three hundred feet of property zoned for residential development. 
2.  The City Center District. 
3.  A sensitive view corridor along a major arterial, state highway or interstate highway. 
4.  A sensitive view corridor from publicly-owned park or open space land to the front range. 
b.  Upon determination that stealth design is required, the director shall notify the applicant in writing within 30 days after the city accepts a completed application for review. 
(2)  Use of monopoles. Telecommunication towers that are camouflaged as opposed to stealth in design shall be constructed using monopole-style towers, except for public safety telecommunications facilities may use lattice-work towers. 
(3)  Antennae array attached to towers at time of initial construction . No part of the attachment shall be in excess of ten horizontal feet from the tower at the time of initial construction. The height of the antennae mounted on the array shall not exceed the height limit for the tower. Antennae added as attachments to a tower after initial construction shall conform to the requirements of Section 18-838 or the requirements for an eligible facilities request. 
(b)  Screening and fencing. 
(1)  For ground-mounted commercial satellite dishes, the support structure shall be screened from off-site view using an opaque wall or fence, buildings on the site, or landscape materials. The height of the wall, fence, buildings or landscape materials shall have the effect of a six-foot screen to a person viewing the property from the grade at the perimeter of the lot. The materials used in any wall or fence shall coordinate with the architecture and building materials used in any principal building on the site. 
(2)  For towers using camouflaging, the area occupied by the tower base and any structures housing equipment related to the telecommunications operation shall be enclosed by a solid screen wall or fence at least six feet in height. The screen wall or fence shall also meet the following requirements: 
a.  The six-foot screen wall or fence shall be constructed in a manner to also secure the area occupied by the tower base and equipment structures from unauthorized entry. 
b.  Where two or more telecommunications providers have facilities on the same site, the design of screen walls and fences shall be coordinated to present a unified appearance. 
c.  All other fencing, screening, and visual obstruction requirements, as listed in Sections 18-565 to 18-567 of this chapter, shall apply. 
(3)  For towers using stealth design, the requirements for a solid screen wall or fence stated in Section 18-826(b)(2) shall be met except they may be modified or waived by the director if determined necessary to coordinate with the type of stealth design used. 
(c)  Landscaping. The following requirements shall apply to all towers and commercial satellite dishes. In cases where stealth designed towers are proposed, the landscaping requirements may be modified or waived by the director upon determination that such action is appropriate to coordinate with the type of stealth design proposed. 
(1)  Landscaping shall be planted along the outside edge of any required screen wall or fence to screen a ground-mounted dish or tower base (see Section 18-826(b)). This requirement may be modified by the director as provided in subsection (4) below. Landscaping shall consist of one or more of the following as determined by the board, in the case of development permits, and by the director, in the case of minor development permits: 
a.  An evergreen hedge planted a maximum of three feet on center, and using a plant species that will reach six feet in height within three years of planting; 
b.  A row of evergreen and deciduous trees equivalent to one tree for every 25 lineal feet of fence or wall. At least 75 percent of the trees shall be evergreen species. The deciduous trees shall be no less than 2.5 inch caliper at the time of planting. The evergreen trees shall be at least six feet tall. The trees may be clustered to provide a natural looking appearance; or 
c.  A combination of hedges and trees. 
(2)  Existing vegetation (trees and shrubs) shall be preserved to the maximum extent possible. 
(3)  All other landscaping requirements provided in Article V, Division 3 of this chapter shall apply. 
(4)  The requirement to provide landscaping along the outside edge of the screen wall or fence required in subsection (c) may be modified or waived by the director as follows: 
a.  Where the tower is located in agricultural or non-urbanized areas or on undeveloped lots where landscaping would be impractical, the requirement may be waived. 
b.  Where the tower base is located in an area not visible to the general public or inappropriate for landscaping, the director may allow the required landscaping to be redistributed on the site so that it improves the general appearance of the site. 
(d)  Lighting. No tower or antenna shall be artificially lighted except as required by the Federal Aviation Administration. Equipment structures may be equipped with security lighting provided that light fixtures are shielded and comply with requirements of Section 38-442. 
(e)  Color. Towers using camouflaging, and commercial satellite dishes shall be painted a non-contrasting blue, gray, white or similar color to match the surrounding built or natural environment and to minimize their visibility. Towers using stealth design shall be painted or finished in a manner consistent with the type of stealth design being used. 
(f)  Signs. Unless otherwise permitted by city, state or federal law, signs are not permitted on the surface of a wireless telecommunication facility. 
(g)  Equipment buildings and structures. 
(1)  Unless equipment is placed in an underground vault or housed in a weatherproof cabinet system, wireless telecommunications ground equipment facility shall be in an enclosed and roofed building or structure. The equipment building or structure shall be constructed in an architectural style and with building materials that coordinate with any principal building on the site, except if the principal building(s) are of poor quality, the equipment building or structure shall be constructed of high quality masonry such as brick, split face block, or stucco. 
(2)  Where two or more telecommunication providers have facilities on the same site, the equipment buildings and structures associated with each provider shall be constructed so that the architectural design and building materials are coordinated, and the buildings shall be clustered together. 
(h)  Natural resource protection standards. The location of any tower, antenna, or equipment building or structure shall comply with all natural resource protection standards established in the Code, including those for floodplain, wetlands, and steep slopes. 
(i)  Federal requirements. All telecommunication facilities must meet the current standards and regulations of the FAA, the FCC, and any other agency or the federal government with the authority to regulate telecommunications facilities. If such standards and regulations are changed, then the owners of the telecommunication facility governed by this chapter shall bring such telecommunication facility into compliance with such revised standards and regulations within the time period mandated by the controlling federal agency. Failure to meet such revised standards and regulations shall constitute grounds for the removal of the telecommunication facility at the owner's expense. The owners of the telecommunication facility shall provide notice to the city of any enforcement actions by the federal government or loss of license. 
(j)  Allowance for co-location. No telecommunication facility owner or operator shall unfairly exclude a telecommunication competitor from co-locating antennae on existing towers or from using the same facility or location. 
(k)  Administrative relief. Applicants requesting approval for a mobile telephone tower or public safety telecommunications tower may apply for administrative relief from the setback and height restrictions stated in this Article IX using the procedures stated in Section 18-59. Administrative relief shall be granted only if it is determined by the director that such relief is necessary because no technologically practical or feasible location exists otherwise to provide mobile telephone or public safety telecommunications services in a given service area, and without administrative relief such services will be unavailable. 
(l)  Issuance of a development permit or specific use permit for unsubdivided property. A development permit or specific use permit for a wireless telecommunication facility governed under this article may be granted on unsubdivided property without requiring the property to be subdivided. 
(Ord. No. 2524, § 7, 10-12-98; Ord. No. 2543, § 4, 5-10-99; Ord. No. 2550, § 3, 7-12-99; Ord. No. 2815, § 54, 2-24-04; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11; Ord. No. 3335, § 3, 5-12-15; Ord. No. 3439, § 9, 6-13-17) 
Sec. 18-827. - Nonresidential districts. 
(a)  Applicability . Wireless telecommunication facilities governed by this article and allowed as main uses in the Neighborhood Service, Community Retail, Regional Commercial, Business Park, City Center, Industrial, Employment Center, Mixed Use, Office/Institutional, Transit Oriented Development, Eastlake Business, Eastlake Service, Eastlake Office, and Eastlake TOD Districts are subject to the requirements in this section. 
(b)  Minimum lot size. The lot or unsubdivided parcel on which a wireless telecommunications facility is located shall conform to the minimum lot size required for the zoning district in which the facility is located. This provision shall not be construed to require that a lot meeting the minimum lot size be created for sole use by the wireless telecommunications facility. 
(c)  Minimum setback requirements. 
(1)  Tower. Fifty percent of the height of tower from any property line other than a residential property line and 100 percent of the height of the tower from any residential property line. In this provision, the tower is defined by the smallest imaginary rectangular prism that contains all the extremities of the structure. 
(2)  Equipment building or structure. Same as zoning district. 
(3)  A person shall not erect a wireless telecommunication facility, or any associated guy wires, support structures, or accessory equipment structures in the "front view area" as defined in Article XI of this chapter. On developed lots that do not abut a public right-of-way, and therefore have no front view area, telecommunication facilities shall not be placed in the area between a line tangent to the front face of the building and extending across the width of the lot to the nearest property line. 
(d)  Maximum height. 
(1)  Ground-mounted tower/dishes. The maximum allowable height for telecommunication towers (including all antennae and appurtenances) and commercial satellite dishes on nonresidential lots shall conform to the Maximum Height Chart for Ground-Mounted Facilities below or as provided in subsection (d)(3) below. 
Legend: 
All heights are expressed in vertical feet measured from grade as defined in Article XI of this chapter.

(3)  Equipment shelter. Accessory equipment structures shall not exceed 16 feet in height. 
(4)  Height bonus for towers with co-located antennae. A height bonus of an additional 20 feet shall be allowed for a tower constructed such that antennae of at least two providers can be mounted on the tower. In order to qualify for the height bonus, the applicant shall provide at the time of application written evidence satisfactory to the director of the following: 
a.  The method of construction is sufficient to allow the attachment of antennae for at least two telecommunications providers. 
b.  The applicant will make the tower available to additional telecommunications providers for the purpose of attaching and operating antennae. 
(e)  Maximum size of accessory equipment structure. Two hundred forty square feet for a single shelter or 720 square feet for all shelters combined. 
(f)  Ground-mounted facilities on sites with an existing use. A wireless telecommunications facility is permitted on a property with an existing use subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The existing use on the property may be any permitted use in the district and need not be affiliated with the wireless telecommunications provider. 
(2)  The wireless telecommunications facility shall be automated, shall not require on-site personnel to be present on a daily basis, and shall be visited only for periodic and necessary maintenance (except during construction or in an emergency). 
(3)  Access. The service access to the facility shall, whenever feasible, be provided along the circulation driveways of the existing use. 
(Ord. No. 2524, § 7, 10-12-98; Ord. No. 2543, § 5, 5-10-99; Ord. No. 3115, § 55, 10-13-09; Ord. No. 3132, § 81, 5-11-10; Ord. No. 3144, § 50, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 3165, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 18-828. - Residential districts. 
(a)  Applicability . Wireless telecommunications facilities governed by this article and allowed as main uses in the Agricultural, Residential Estate, Single-Family Detached, Single-Family Attached, Multifamily, Manufactured Home, and Eastlake Residential Districts are subject to the requirements in this section. 
(b)  Location . In applying for a permit for a telecommunication facility in any residential district, the applicant must present evidence as to why it is not feasible to locate in a nonresidential district. 
(c)  Minimum lot size. The lot or unsubdivided parcel on which a wireless telecommunications facility is located shall conform to the minimum lot size required for the zoning district in which the facility is located. This provision shall not be construed to require that a lot meeting the minimum lot size be created for sole use by the wireless telecommunications facility. 
(d)  Minimum setback requirements. 
(1)  Tower. The distance from any telecommunication tower, with the exception of guy wires and anchor points, to any property line shall be no less than 50 percent of the height of the tower from any property line other than a residential property line and 100 percent of the height of the tower from any residential property line. In this provision, the tower is defined by the smallest imaginary rectangular prism that contains all the extremities of the structure. 
(2)  Equipment building or structure. Same as zoning district regulations. 
(3)  A person shall not erect a telecommunication facility, or any associated guy wires, support structures, or equipment buildings or structures in the "front view area" as defined in Article XI of this chapter. 
(e)  Maximum height . 
(1)  The maximum allowable height for either building-mounted or ground-mounted facilities shall conform to the following Maximum Height Chart. The maximum height for ground-mounted facilities shall include all antennae and appurtenances. 
Legend: 
All heights for building-mounted facilities indicate the maximum number of feet above the highest point of the existing building or structure on which the facility is mounted. 
All heights for ground-mounted facilities are expressed in vertical feet measured from grade as defined in Article XI of this chapter.
