Chapter 19 - HISTORIC RECOGNITION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the Historic Recognition Code. 
(Ord. No. 3225, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Sec. 19-2. - Purpose. 
    The city council hereby declares that the recognition of structures, sites and districts of cultural, historical and architectural significance is in the interest of the prosperity, civic pride, economic development and general welfare of the people of the City of Thornton. 
(Ord. No. 3225, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Sec. 19-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Historic district means a geographically definable area that has been designated as such by the city because of its historic significance and importance to the community. A historic district includes a concentration, linkage or continuity of sites, buildings, structures and/or physical features. A district is related by a pattern of either physical elements or social activities. A term "district" may include neighborhood, agricultural or commercial districts. 
    Improvement means any building, structure, place, work of art or other object constituting a physical betterment of real property or any part of such betterment. 
    Landmark means a property or structure designated by resolution of the city council, that is worthy of rehabilitation, restoration and preservation because of its cultural, architectural and/or historical significance to the city. 
    Site means a specific location or place which may or may not have structures or improvements located upon it. 
    Structure means that which is built or constructed, an edifice or building of any kind, or any piece of work artificially built up or composed of parts joined together in some definite manner. 
(Ord. No. 3225, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Secs. 19-4-19-11. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HISTORIC DESIGNATION 

Sec. 19-12. - Criteria for historic designation. 
(a)  General historic designation. Properties receiving historic designations should be at least 50 years old except as otherwise provided herein and possess architectural, social, archeological, or geographical/environmental importance. 
(b)  Additional criteria for historic districts. Properties that do not contribute to the significance of the historic landmark district may be included within the boundaries, as long as the noncontributing elements do not noticeably detract from the district's sense of time, place and historic development. 
(c)  State or National Register listing recognition. Any site listed on the Colorado State Register of Historic Properties or National Register of Historic Places shall be deemed to qualify for local designation under this chapter, but shall not be locally designated until an application for designation is filed and processed pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3225, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Sec. 19-13. - Historic designation nomination. 
(a)  Nominations for historic designation shall be made on a form designated by the city. Nominations may be submitted by the owners of record of the nominated property or structure, the city council, the city staff, or any other person or organization. 
(b)  Upon nomination, the city shall contact the owner of record of all nominated property and secure the consent of the owner to such designation. 
(1)  A nomination for a historic landmark or site shall not be considered until all owners have consented to such designation. 
(2)  The boundaries of a proposed historic district shall be modified to exclude any properties where the owner has not consented to such designation. 
(c)  Once the required property owner's consent to the nomination has been received by the city, TASHCO shall consider the application and make a formal recommendation to city council. Written notice of the date, time, and place of the TASHCO public meeting to consider the application shall be sent by first class mail at least ten days prior to the public meeting to the applicant and all property owners, as determined by county records, whose property would be included in the proposed designation. 
(d)  In addition to considering the report and recommendation from city staff, TASHCO may request input from members of other city boards and commissions, or other professionals with expertise in subject matter relevant to the application under consideration, including but not limited to architecture, landscape architecture, archaeology, history, planning, or cultural geography or anthropology. 
(e)  At the specified public meeting, TASHCO shall review the application to make a determination as to whether the nominated property, site or area meets the criteria of Section 19-12 for historic designation. TASHCO shall recommend approval, approval with conditions, or denial of the application for designation and shall forward its recommendation to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3225, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Sec. 19-14. - Historic designation. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a recommendation from TASHCO and pursuant to the procedures set forth herein, the city council may, by resolution: 
(1)  Designate as a landmark an individual structure or other feature or an integrated group of structures and features on a single site having cultural, architectural or historical significance. 
(2)  Designate as a historic district an area containing a number of structures having cultural, architectural or historical significance. 
(b)  The city council shall make its decision on an application for historic designation based on the recommendation of TASHCO, staff reports, and other evidence presented, and on findings that the application meets the requirements of this chapter and other applicable regulations, standards, requirements, or plans adopted by the city council. 
(c)  Any designation resolution shall include a description of the characteristics of the landmark or historic district which justify its designation, and a description of the particular features that should be preserved, and shall include a legal description of the location and boundaries of the landmark site or historic district. 
(d)  The designation resolution may also include recommendations to encourage the preservation and enhancement of the designated landmark or historic district. 
(e)  The city council shall approve, approve with conditions, or deny an application for historic designation by resolution. The decision of the council shall be considered final. 
(f)  If the historic designation is approved or approved with conditions by the city council, a copy of the resolution shall be provided to all owners of record of the structure or site, or in the historic district. 
(g)  Any historic marker provided by the city should be installed in a location such that it is clearly visible from a public street. 
(Ord. No. 3225, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Sec. 19-15. - Historic property preservation. 
    Owners of historic landmarks and owners of properties located within a historic district are encouraged to retain the historic characteristics when carrying out any maintenance, repair, construction, alteration, removal, relocation or demolition. 
(Ord. No. 3225, § 1, 12-18-12)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OZONE DEPLETING SUBSTANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Chlorofluorocarbon regulations, C.R.S. §§ 25-7-105(11), 25-7-122.5, 25-7-128(7)(b). 

Sec. 22-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Acceptable disposal facility means those establishments, businesses, landfills, or other certified companies that accept those substances, identified by this article to be ozone depleting compounds, for elimination within federal, State, and local statutes, rules and regulations. 
    Approved halon recapturing and recycling equipment means any and all equipment that has been certified by Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. (UL), for the purpose of extraction and reclamation of halon from fire extinguishing systems or units. 
    Approved major refrigerator system recapturing and recycling equipment means any and all equipment that has been certified by Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. (UL), for the purpose of extraction and reclamation of refrigerant contained within a major refrigeration system, as defined in this section. 
    Approved motor vehicle refrigerant recapturing and recycling equipment means any and all equipment that has been certified by Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. (UL), to meet the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) Standard for the Extraction and Reclamation of Refrigerant from Motor Vehicle Air Conditioners (SAE Standard J-1991). 
    Approved refrigerator or portable air conditioning recapturing and recycling equipment means any and all equipment that has been certified by Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. (UL), for the purpose of extraction and reclamation of coolants contained within refrigerators or portable air conditioning units, as defined in this section. 
    Environmental services manager means the person designated by the city whose primary responsibility is to direct operation of and personnel assigned to the infrastructure department, environmental services division. 
    Major refrigeration systems means refrigerators, freezers, cold storage warehouse refrigeration systems and air conditioners that hold more than 100 pounds of refrigerant or more than 100 pounds total, should more than one refrigeration unit or system exist at the same location. 
    Ozone depleting compound means those substances identified by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), as stated in USC 7671a, and the Montreal Protocol, which contribute to the depletion of the stratospheric ozone layer. Those substances shall include the following: 
(1)  Group I. 
CFC-11 (Trichlorofluoromethane) 
CFC-12 (Dichlorodifluoromethane) 
CFC-113 (Trichlorodifluoroethane) 
CFC-114 (Dichlorotetrafluoroethane) 
CFC-115 (Monochloropenetrafluoroethane) 
(2)  Group II. 
Halon-1211 (Bromochlorodifluoroethane) 
Halon-1301 (Bromotrifluoroethane) 
Halon-2402 (Dibromotetrafluroethane) 
(3)  Group III. 
CFC-13 
CFC-111 
CFC-112 
CFC-211 
CFC-212 
CFC-213 
CFC-214 
CFC-215 
CFC-216 
CFC-217 
(4)  Group IV. 
Methyl chloroform 
(5)  Group V. 
Carbon tetrachloride 
    Portable air conditioning unit means any and all air conditioner units that have less than a 100-pound capacity for the storing of coolant or less than 100 pounds total, should more than one unit exist at the same location. 
    Refrigerant means CFC-11 (trichlorofluromethane), CFC-12 (dichlorodifluoromethane, also known as chlorofluorocarbon-12 or R-12), or any substitute refrigerant used in motor vehicle air conditioning equipment, refrigerators, air conditioners, or refrigeration systems that contain an ozone depleting compound. 
(Code 1975, § 39-1; Ord. No. 2191, § 1, 9-28-92; Ord. No. 2656, § 3, 2-12-01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-27. - Violations and penalties. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this article. Any person who violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be fined as provided in Section 1-8(a). Each separate day or any portion thereof during which there is a violation of any provision of this article shall be deemed to be a separate violation. 
(Code 1975, § 39-8; Ord. No. 2191, § 1, 9-28-92) 
Sec. 22-28. - Motor vehicle air conditioners. 
(a)  No person who owns or operates a facility in which motor vehicle air conditioners are installed, serviced, repaired, or disposed of shall: 
(1)  Perform any service involving the release or recharge of refrigerant on a motor vehicle air conditioner without using approved motor vehicle refrigerant recycling equipment, as defined in Section 22-26. 
(2)  Allow the venting or release of refrigerants from a motor vehicle air conditioner. 
(b)  No person who owns or operates a facility in which motor vehicles are accepted for dismantling, scrap metal, or permanent disposal shall: 
(1)  Permit a motor vehicle to be dismantled, sold as scrap metal, or permanently disposed of unless the refrigerant has first been recovered by using approved motor vehicle refrigerant recycling equipment. 
(2)  Allow the venting or release of refrigerants from a motor vehicle air conditioner. 
(c)  No person shall sell refrigerant capable of being used to charge a motor vehicle air conditioner except in containers with a capacity of not less than 15 pounds. 
(Code 1975, § 39-2; Ord. No. 2191, § 1, 9-28-92) 
Sec. 22-29. - Major refrigeration systems. 
(a)  No person who owns or operates a facility in which major refrigeration systems are installed, serviced, repaired, or disposed of shall: 
(1)  Install, service, repair, or dispose of a major refrigeration system without utilizing approved refrigerant recapturing or recycling equipment, as defined in Section 22-26. 
(2)  Allow the venting or release of refrigerants from a major refrigeration system. 
(b)  No person who owns or operates a retail store, cold storage warehouse, commercial or industrial building shall permit the venting or release of any refrigerant. The provisions of this subsection shall apply to any alteration, renovation, or demolition of a building or structure that contains a major refrigeration system. 
(Code 1975, § 39-3; Ord. No. 2191, § 1, 9-28-92) 
Sec. 22-30. - Refrigerators and portable air conditioning units. 
    Any person who manufactures, repairs, services, or maintains a refrigerator or portable air conditioning unit shall recycle, recapture, or reuse any ozone depleting compounds used as coolants in such refrigerator or air conditioning unit so as not to permit the release of ozone depleting compounds. 
(Code 1975, § 39-4; Ord. No. 2191, § 1, 9-28-92) 
Sec. 22-31. - Fire extinguishing systems containing halon. 
(a)  Except as permitted by state statute, rule or regulation, no person shall release halon, an ozone depleting compound, from a fire extinguishing system during the training of personnel or in the testing of such fire extinguishing system. 
(b)  Any person who owns or operates a facility that repairs, services, or performs maintenance on fire extinguishing systems or units shall recapture and recycle any halon used as an extinguishing agent in the system or unit. 
(Code 1975, § 39-5; Ord. No. 2191, § 1, 9-28-92) 
Sec. 22-32. - Recapturing, recycling and disposal. 
(a)  All substances identified by this article as containing an ozone depleting compound shall be recaptured for the purpose of recycling or disposal, unless as otherwise specified by this article, during any process which may result in the release of such compounds into the atmosphere. Recapturing shall be accomplished by any person utilizing approved equipment, as defined by this article, in performing such services and shall comply with all applicable federal, state, and local statutes, rules and regulations. 
(b)  Should any recaptured ozone depleting compound not be recycled, or reused, it shall be deposited with an approved disposal facility, as defined in Section 22-26, or destroyed by a method that does not allow the release or escape of such compounds into the atmosphere in compliance with all applicable federal, State, and local statutes, rules and regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 39-6; Ord. No. 2191, § 1, 9-28-92) 
Sec. 22-33. - Material for padding or building insulation. 
    No person shall sell, manufacture, or install any material used for padding or building insulation that contains an ozone depleting compound or any ozone depleting compound that is used as a blowing agent during the manufacturing process. 
(Code 1975, § 39-7; Ord. No. 2191, § 1, 9-28-92) 
Sec. 22-34. - Conflict with state requirements. 
    In the event that any requirement contained in this article is more stringent than a corresponding state statute or regulation with respect to measures to preserve the stratospheric ozone layer, the state provision shall control as to that requirement. 
(Code 1975, § 39-9; Ord. No. 2191, § 1, 9-28-92) 
Secs. 22-35-22-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SOLID FUEL BURNING RESTRICTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Control of pollution caused by wood smoke, C.R.S. § 25-7-401 et seq. 

Sec. 22-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Air pollution alert means a period of time designated as an air pollution alert by the state department of health, representing a more severe air pollution condition than occurring during a high pollution day. 
    Air pollution emergency means a period of time designated as an air pollution emergency by the state department of health, representing a more severe air pollution condition than occurring during an air pollution alert. 
    Air pollution warning means a period of time designated as an air pollution warning by the state department of health, representing a more severe air pollution condition than occurring during an air pollution alert. 
    Approved solid fuel burning device means a solid fuel burning device which has been certified by the state department of health, in accordance with procedures specified in state Air Quality Control Commission regulation no. 4, as meeting the emissions standards for certification under such regulation, as amended from time to time. 
    Barbecue devices means devices that are utilized solely for the purpose of cooking food. 
    Exempt solid fuel burning devices means those devices specifically exempted from regulation by the commission in accordance with regulation no. 4. 
    High pollution day means a period of time declared to be a high pollution day by the state department of health, representing a less severe air pollution condition than occurring during an air pollution alert. 
    Sole source of heat means one or more solid fuel burning devices that constitute the only source of heat in a residence for the purpose of central or space heating. A residential solid fuel fired heating device shall be considered to be the sole source of heat if the private residence is equipped with a permanently installed non-solid fuel burning furnace or heating system designed to heat the residence which is physically disconnected from its non-solid fuel energy source, including heating oil, natural gas, electricity or propane. 
    Solid fuel fired heating device means a device designed for solid fuel combustion so that usable heat is derived for the interior of a building, and includes solid fuel fired stoves, fireplaces, solid fuel fired cooking stoves and a combination of fuel furnaces or boilers which burn solid fuel. Solid fuel fired heating devices do not include barbecue devices or natural gas fired fireplace logs. 
(Code 1975, § 39-13; Ord. No. 2286, 10-11-93; Ord. No. 2375, § 1, 6-26-95) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-62. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in Section 1-8(a). 
(Code 1975, § 39-16; Ord. No. 2286, 10-11-93) 
Sec. 22-63. - Use of solid fuel fired heating devices restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, permit or cause to be operated within any residential structure or unit a solid fuel fired heating device on a high pollution day, air pollution alert, air pollution warning or air pollution emergency, subject to the exemptions set forth in Section 22-64. However, such prohibition shall not take effect until the expiration of three hours from the time of public declaration of the high pollution day or air pollution alert by the state department of health in order to permit burndown of existing fires. It shall be the duty of all persons owning or operating a solid fuel burning device to be aware of any such declaration by the state department of health, and the fact that such person was not aware of such declaration shall not constitute a defense to the violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 39-14; Ord. No. 2286, 10-11-93) 
Sec. 22-64. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Application may be made to the city manager for an exemption from the requirements of Section 22-63 by a person: 
(1)  Residing in a residence relying on a solid fuel fired device as a sole source of heat; 
(2)  Having an approved solid fuel burning device; or 
(3)  Who is eligible for energy assistance under the low income, energy assistance program administered by the county. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, a residence shall not include any accessory or outbuildings or garages, whether attached or not, to the principal structure. 
(c)  Each person applying for an exemption shall complete a building inspection permit form or an application form, depending on the type of exemption requested. 
(d)  The applicant shall submit the application under oath that the information submitted meets the requirements of the applicable provisions of subsection (a) of this section and is true and accurate. 
(e)  The city manager shall issue the exemption to the address of the residence being sought for exemption, unless the exemption is under revocation or denial as provided in this article or the residence is determined to be ineligible for exemption under the standards of this article. No exemption shall be granted under subsection (a) of this section so as to extend the exemption more than three years from the date of initial issue. 
(f)  An exemption shall permit solid fuel fired heating devices to be operated during periods designated as air pollution alerts, air pollution warnings, air pollution emergencies and high pollution days. 
(g)  Upon suspension or withdrawal of an exemption, it shall be the duty of the owner or resident of the residence having been issued an exemption to forthwith remove any sign or other marker having been issued by the city for attachment to the residence to display the status of exemption. 
(h)  It shall be the duty of the resident or owner of the property for which the exemption has been issued to advise the city manager of any change of condition or circumstance set forth in the application for exemption within 30 days of such change. A determination shall be made whether the exemption shall be withdrawn due to ineligibility for exemption pursuant to the standards of this section. 
(Code 1975, § 39-16; Ord. No. 2286, 10-11-93) 
Sec. 22-65. - Suspension, revocation or withdrawal of exemption. 
    Any exemption granted under Section 22-64 may be revoked, withdrawn or denied upon personal service or mailing of a notice of suspension, withdrawal or denial submitted to the applicant for exemption or the resident of the residence, if no exemption has been granted, for the following reasons: 
(1)  Suspension. 
a.  Reasons for suspension include the following: 
1.  Three or more violations of this article within a 12-month period. 
2.  Any misstatement of fact in any application for exemption or renewal thereof. 
3.  The refusal of the applicant for exemption to permit city law enforcement and code enforcement officials inspection of the heating devices and facilities at reasonable times to verify the information contained in any application for exemption or otherwise to determine compliance with this article. Nothing in this subsection shall restrict the city from seeking a search warrant from the municipal court to enforce the provisions of this article against any residential property, whether holding an exemption or not. 
4.  Any other violation of the terms and requirements of this article. 
b.  A notice of suspension shall be operative for one year following the date the order becomes effective. Upon eligibility for reinstatement, the applicant shall fully be subject to the application standards set forth in Section 22-64. 
(2)  Withdrawal. In the event that an exemption is ordered withdrawn pursuant to change of conditions brought to the attention of the city pursuant to Section 22-64(h), such order of withdrawal shall remain in effect until the residence again becomes eligible for the issuance of an exemption. The applicant shall submit an application for reinstatement and shall have the burden to establish facts and circumstances which justify the reinstatement of exemption. 
(3)  Denial. If the resident or owner of a residence not having been issued an exemption under this article has committed acts which would justify a suspension as set forth in subsection (1) of this section, the residence shall be subject to an order of denial, which shall be operative for one year following the date the order becomes effective. At the expiration of such period, the resident or owner shall be reinstated to eligibility to apply for an exemption under this article. 
(Code 1975, § 39-17; Ord. No. 2286, 10-11-93) 
Secs. 22-66-22-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OUTDOOR BURNING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Control of pollution caused by wood smoke, C.R.S. § 25-7-401 et seq. 

Sec. 22-96. - Trash burning restrictions. 
    It is unlawful for any person to burn or allow to be burned, upon premises owned or controlled by such person or upon public streets, alleys, and rights-of-way adjacent to such premises, any rubbish; wastepaper; solid waste; refuse; yard waste; oil, gas, or byproduct of any oil or gas; or other flammable materials within the corporate city limits without first obtaining an emissions permit issued by the state. Any person in possession of a permit for the purpose of burning materials as stated in this section shall comply with all related federal, state, and local statutes, rules and regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 39-10; Ord. No. 2264, § 2, 6-28-93) 
Sec. 22-97. - Weed control burning restrictions. 
    It is unlawful for any person to burn or allow to be burned, upon premises owned or controlled by such person or upon public streets, alleys, and rights-of-way adjacent to such premises, any vegetation, overgrowth, or weeds in the corporate city limits, except as follows: between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. every day of every week. No burning shall be allowed during any high pollution day, air pollution alert, air pollution warning, or air pollution emergency as declared by the state department of health or any division thereof. 
(Code 1975, § 39-11; Ord. No. 2264, § 2, 6-28-93) 
Sec. 22-98. - Incinerators and containers. 
    It is unlawful for any person to burn or allow to be burned any materials contained within an incinerator or container within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a permit for incinerator use issued by the state. Any person in possession of a permit for incinerator use shall comply with all related federal, state, and local statutes, rules and regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 39-12; Ord. No. 2264, § 2, 6-28-93) 
Secs. 22-99-22-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - GRADING, EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 2433, adopted Sep. 9, 1996, has been included herein as §§ 22-111-22-118, 22-131-22-135, 22-141-22-144, 22-151-22-156, 22-161-22-171, 22-181, and 22-191-22-197 at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Building Code, Ch. 10; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 70. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-111. - Purpose. 
    This article is enacted for the purpose of regulating grading on private property within the incorporated area of the city to safeguard life, limb, health, property, and public welfare; to avoid pollution of watercourses with nutrients, sediments, and other earthen materials generated on or caused by surface runoff on or across the permitted area; and to ensure that the intended use of the graded site is consistent with the city subdivision and zoning codes, and related approvals. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-112. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    ASTM means the American Society for Testing and Materials. 
    Best management practices (BMPs) means schedules of activities, facilities, designs, prohibitions of practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices used to prevent or reduce non-storm water pollution of the municipal separate storm sewer and waters of the United States. 
    Board means the building code advisory board of the city. 
    CDPHE means the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment. 
    CDPS means the Colorado Discharge Permit System. 
    Compaction means the increase of density of a soil or rock fill by mechanical means. 
    Cut. See "excavation." 
    Department means the city development department of the city. 
    Depth of fill means the vertical dimension from the exposed fill surface to the original ground surface. 
    Depth of excavation (cut) means the vertical dimension from the exposed cut surface to the original ground surface. 
    Development engineering manager means the person, or designated representative, assigned by the city manager of the city within the city development department to fulfill the responsibility, duty, and authority associated with the position of development engineering manager. 
    Director means the deputy city manager of city development. 
    Drainageway means a depression in the earth's surface such as swales, ravines, gullies, or ditches. 
    Embankment. See "fill." 
    Erosion means the wearing away and transportation of earth material as a result of the movement of wind, water, or ice. 
    Excavation or cut means the removal relocation of naturally occurring earth materials by mechanical means, and includes the conditions resulting therefrom. 
    Expansive soil means any soil which exhibits significant expansive properties as determined by a professional engineer or the development engineering manager. 
    FEMA means the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
    FHAD means the flood hazard area delineation adopted by the city. 
    Fill means a deposit of earth material placed by artificial means. 
    FIRM means the Federal Insurance Rate Map. 
    Grade means the vertical location of the ground surface. 
Existing grade means the grade prior to grading. 
Finish grade means the final grade of the site which conforms to the approved plan. 
Rough grade means the stage at which the grade approximately conforms to the approved plan. 
    Grading means the act of excavating or filling or combination thereof. 
    Municipal separate storm sewer system means the city's storm sewer system. The system of conveyances including municipal roads with drainage systems, catch basins, culverts, curbs, gutters, ditches, man-made channels, detention and retention facilities, all for conveying storm water. 
    Person means any individual, firm, corporation, or agency, whether principal, agent, employee, or otherwise. 
    Professional engineer means any person licensed by the state to practice in the discipline of civil engineering. 
    Sediment means any material transported or deposited by water, including soil, debris, or other foreign matter. 
    Site means any lot or parcel of land or combination of contiguous lots or parcels of land, whether held separately or joined together in common ownership or occupancy, where grading is to be performed or has been performed. 
    Slope means an inclined ground surface the inclination of which may be expressed as the ratio of horizontal distance to vertical distance. 
    Soil means an all earth material of any origin that overlies bedrock and may include the decomposed zone of bedrock which can be excavated readily by mechanical means. 
    Standards and Specifications means the latest edition of the city of Thornton Standards and Specifications for the Design and Construction of Public Improvements. 
    Storm sewer system means facilities by which storm water is collected and/or conveyed, including but not limited to any roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, gutters, curbs, inlets, piped storm drains, pumping facilities, retention and detention basins, natural and human-made or altered drainage channels, reservoirs, and other drainage structures. 
    Storm water means precipitation that accumulates in natural or constructed storage and municipal separate storm sewer systems immediately following a storm event. 
    Storm water quality means the physical, chemical, and biological characteristics of storm water in respect to its suitability for a particular purpose. 
    Storm water management plan (SWMP) means a document which describes BMPs and activities to be implemented by a person or permittee to identify sources of pollution or contamination at a site and the actions to eliminate or reduce pollutant discharges to storm water, storm water conveyance systems, or receiving waters to the maximum extent practicable. 
    UDFCD means the Urban Drainage and Flood Control District. 
    Watercourse means any natural or manmade channel flowing continuously or intermittently in a definite direction and course or used for the holding, delay or storage of waters, which functions at any time to convey or store storm water runoff. 
    Waters of the United States means surface watercourses and water bodies as defined under 40 CFR § 122.2 as amended including all natural waterways and definite channels and depressions in the earth that may carry water, even though such waterways may only carry storm water during precipitation and may not carry storm water at and/or during all times and seasons. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 4, 2-12-01; Ord. No. 2935, § 5, 1-10-06) 
Sec. 22-113. - Grading permit required. 
    Except for specific exemptions listed hereinafter, no person shall do or permit to be done any grading on any site in the city without a valid grading permit issued by the development engineering manager. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 5, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-114. - Exemptions. 
    The following grading may be done without obtaining a permit. Exemption from the requirement of a permit shall not be deemed to be permission to violate any provision of this article. 
(1)  Minor projects which have cuts or fills, each of which is less than five feet in vertical depth at its deepest point measured from the existing ground surface, and which include all of the following: 
a.  Less than 50 cubic yards of graded material. 
b.  Do not create unstable or erodible slopes or fields; including grading which does not remove top soil and vegetation. 
c.  Do not encroach into a drainageway or watercourse. 
(2)  Excavations in connection with a swimming pool authorized by a valid building permit. 
(3)  Trenching and grading incidental to the construction or installation of approved underground pipelines, septic tanks and sewage disposal fields, conduits, electrical or communication facilities, and drilling or excavation for post holes or approved wells. 
(4)  Excavations of less than 100 and 150 cubic yards for soil or geologic investigations by a professional engineer. 
(5)  Grading in accordance with plans incorporated in an approved surface mining permit. 
(6)  Routine cemetery excavations and fills. 
(7)  An excavation below finished grade for basements and footings of a building authorized by a valid building permit. 
(8)  Grading work performed by the city. 
(9)  Agricultural and farming activities including tilling, plowing, and excavation for irrigation ditches. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-115. - Grading. 
    No person shall do or permit to be done any grading in such a manner that quantities of dirt, soil, rock, debris, or other material substantially in excess of natural levels are washed, eroded, or otherwise moved from the site, except as specifically provided for by a permit. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-116. - Water obstruction. 
    No person shall do or permit to be done any grading which may obstruct, impede or interfere with the natural flow of storm waters, whether such waters are unconfined upon the surface of the land or confined within land depressions or natural drainageways, unimproved channels or watercourses, or improved ditches, channels, streets, or conduits in such a manner as to cause flooding where it would not otherwise occur, aggravate any existing flooding condition or cause accelerated erosion except where grading is in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local laws, including but not limited to this article. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-117. - Hazards. 
    Whenever the development engineering manager determines that any grading on private property constitutes a condition which is a hazard to public safety, endangers property, adversely affects the safety, use or stability of adjacent property, or an overhead or underground utility, or a public way, watercourse, or drainage channel, or could adversely affect the water quality of any water bodies or watercourses, the owner of the property upon which the condition is located, or other person or agent in control of said property, upon receipt of notice in writing from the development engineering manager shall, within the period specified therein, obtain a grading permit and conform to the conditions of said permit. The development engineering manager may require the submission of plans or soil or geological reports, detailed construction recommendations, drainage study or other engineering data prior to and in connection with any corrective or proposed work or activity. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 6, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-118. - Not retroactive. 
    This article shall be prospective in operation only. The provisions of this article shall not apply to construction for which all previously necessary permits were obtained. Further, said provisions shall not apply to a project or development not yet constructed provided that an appropriate permit has been obtained and said permit is still valid and bears a date prior to the effective date of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Secs. 22-119-22-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURES 

Sec. 22-131. - Filing. 
    Applications for permits shall be filed with the development engineering manager on forms furnished by the city. Each application shall include a preliminary or final grading plan and an erosion control plan. The development engineering manager shall determine if the application is complete in accordance with the provisions of this article. The applicant shall be notified within five working days of the submittal of the application if the application is deemed incomplete and the requirements for completing the application. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 7, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-132. - Permit conditions. 
(a)  No permit shall be granted unless the project conforms to the city subdivision and zoning codes and all applicable city ordinances. 
(b)  Where the proposed project requires the filing of a subdivision plat or the intended use requires approval of a discretionary zoning permit, no grading permit shall be granted prior to the approval of the applicable planning authority. 
(c)  The permit shall be limited to work shown on the grading plans as approved by the development engineering manager. In granting a permit, the development engineering manager may impose any condition deemed necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public, to prevent the creation of a hazard to public or private property, and to assure proper completion of the grading, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Mitigation of any adverse environmental impacts. 
(2)  Requirements for dust, erosion, replacement of vegetation, sediment and noise control, hours of operation, sequence of work, access roads and haul routes, and work area traffic control. 
(3)  Requirements for safeguarding watercourses, whether natural or manmade, from excess deposition of sediment or debris in quantities exceeding normal levels. 
(4)  Requirements for submitting a tree mitigation plan in accordance with the provisions of the City Development Code, Chapter 18, Article IV, Division 3. 
(5)  Keeping public street and rights-of-ways free from mud and debris. For purposes of this Article V, the definition of debris includes discarded construction material of any type. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2616, § 1, 7-10-00; Ord. No. 2656, § 8, 2-12-01; Ord. No. 2687, § 21, 10-22-01; Ord. No. 3165, § 3, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 22-133. - Permission of other agencies or owners. 
    No permit shall relieve the permittee of the responsibility for securing any other permits or approvals required for work which is regulated by any other department of the city, the county, the state, or any other public agency, or for obtaining any easements or authorization for grading on property not owned by the permittee. Proof of application for applicable public agency permits may be required prior to issuance of a grading permit. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-134. - Time limits. 
(a)  The permittee shall perform and complete all the work required by the permit including regular clean up of mud and debris within the time limits specified in the permit. If the work cannot be completed within the specified time, a request for an extension of time setting forth the reasons for the requested extension shall be presented in writing to the development engineering manager no later than five days prior to the expiration of the permit. The development engineering manager may grant additional time for the work. 
(b)  If the work is not completed within the time limit specified in subsection (a) above, the city may utilize the funds deposited in escrow pursuant to Section 22-152, for the completion of the work and/or restoration of the site. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2616, § 2, 7-10-00; Ord. No. 2656, § 9, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-135. - Validity. 
    The issuance of a permit or approval of plans and specifications shall not be construed as an approval or waiver of any violation of the provisions of this article or any other applicable laws, ordinances, rules or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Secs. 22-136-22-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 22-141. - Application. 
    Three or more complete sets of grading plans including but not limited to profiles, cross sections, topographic maps and specifications shall be submitted to the development engineering manager with each application for a grading permit. When the final grading plans and other documents required hereunder have been approved, a grading permit will be issued by the development engineering manager. The work shall be done in strict compliance with the approved plans and specifications which shall not be altered without the approval of the development engineering manager. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 10, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-142. - Grading plans. 
    Final grading plans shall be prepared and signed by a professional engineer licensed to practice in the state. The grading plans shall be drawn on 24 inch × 36 inch sheets on an appropriate scale, but not smaller than 1 inch = 50 feet and shall include the following: 
(1)  The complete site boundaries and locations of any easements and rights-of-way traversing and adjacent to the property, appropriately labeled and dimensioned. 
(2)  The location of all existing and proposed roads, buildings, wells, pipelines, watercourse, railroad tracks, and the location of all improvements on adjacent land within 150 feet of the proposed work. 
(3)  Existing and proposed contour lines at intervals not greater than two feet, showing all topographic features and drainage patterns throughout the area where proposed grading is to occur. The contour lines shall be extended a minimum of 50 feet beyond the affected area. 
(4)  The location of all cut and fill lines and the limits of grading for all the proposed grading work, including borrow and stockpile areas. 
(5)  The location, width, and direction of flow of any watercourses. 
(6)  The limits of the 100-year floodplain and floodway as delineated on the FIRM or FHAD as required by the development engineering manager. 
(7)  The location of all deciduous trees over four inches in caliper and all evergreen trees six feet in height or taller. All trees to be removed shall be identified on the plan. The removal of any such trees will require the submittal of a tree mitigation plan in accordance with the City Development Code, Chapter 18, Article IV, Division 3. 
(8)  Proposed provisions for storm drainage control and any existing or proposed flood control facilities. 
(9)  An estimate of the quantities of excavation and fill, including quantities to be moved both on and off site, as well as the acreage of the total area to be disturbed by the activities. 
(10)  The estimated starting and completion dates of grading. 
(11)  A detailed erosion and sediment control plan including specific locations, construction details, and supporting calculations for temporary and permanent sediment control structures. The applicant shall submit to the city, proof of application to the state, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, or other agencies requiring a permit for the proposed grading. 
(12)  A phase two drainage study will be required prior to issuance of a grading permit. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 11, 2-12-01; Ord. No. 3165, § 4, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 22-143. - Approved plans-Modification. 
(a)  Proposed modification to an approved grading plan shall be submitted to the development engineering manager for approval. 
(b)  All necessary soils and geotechnical information and design details shall accompany any request for modification. 
(c)  The modification shall be compatible with any approved subdivision plat and all land use requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 12, 2-12-01; Ord. No. 2687, § 22, 10-22-01) 
Sec. 22-144. - Same-Distribution. 
    Four sets of approved plans shall be retained by the development engineering manager and one set of approved plans shall be provided to the permittee. One set of approved plans and permit shall be retained on the site at all times during the work. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 13, 2-12-01) 
Secs. 22-145-22-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PERMIT REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 22-151. - General. 
    The development engineering manager will issue a grading permit if final grading plans satisfy the provisions of this article and all of the conditions imposed. The development engineering manager shall identify the provision, requirement or condition that has not been met or performed by the applicant in the event the issuance of a grading permit is denied. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 14, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-152. - Fees. 
(a)  The schedule of fees and costs shall be those established and adopted from time to time by resolution of the city council. Before a permit is issued, the applicant shall deposit with the development engineering manager cash or certified check, in a sufficient sum to cover the fee for issuance of a permit, charges for review of plans, investigations and inspections, in accordance with schedules adopted by the city council. 
(b)  If, upon completion of the work there remains any excess of a security deposit, pursuant to Section 22-181, submitted as a requirement of the permit, the development engineering manager shall certify the same to the executive director of finance of the city for refund to the permittee. 
(c)  If grading work is done in violation of this article or such work is not in accordance with the approved permit, a fee, not less than twice the normal fee, covering investigation of any violation and inspection and plan checking of work required to correct such violation shall be charged to such violator to cover all costs. No additional permits will be reviewed or considered for that permittee until said costs are paid. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 15, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-153. - Geotechnical investigation required. 
    The application for a grading permit shall include a geotechnical report, prepared by a professional engineer, which includes, but is not limited to, the following information: 
(1)  A classification of soil types found on site and pertinent laboratory test data. 
(2)  A description of any encountered groundwater or excessive moisture conditions. 
(3)  A log for each soil boring and test excavation showing elevation at ground level and the depth of each soil or rock strata. 
(4)  An evaluation of the stability of pertinent natural slopes and any proposed cut and fill slopes. 
(5)  Recommendations for grading procedures including compaction requirements. 
(6)  Recommendations regarding drainage and erosion control. 
(7)  Any additional information as may be required by the development engineering manager. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 16, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-154. - Final geotechnical report. 
    Upon completion of the grading work, a final geotechnical report prepared by a professional engineer shall be submitted to the development engineering manager for approval. The report shall include, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  A complete record of all field and laboratory tests including elevation and location of all tests. 
(2)  A professional opinion regarding slope stability, soil bearing capacity, and other pertinent information. 
(3)  Recommendations regarding foundation design including soil bearing potential, and building restrictions or setbacks from the top or toe of slopes. 
(4)  Recommendations for structural design of all proposed public and private roadways. The recommendations shall be in conformance with the Standards and Specifications for Public Works Construction for the city. 
(5)  A declaration by a professional engineer that all work was done in substantial conformance with the recommendations contained in the approved geotechnical investigation report and in accordance with the approved plans and specifications. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 17, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-155. - As-built plans. 
    The permittee shall submit to the development engineering manager an "as-built" grading plan following completion of the grading operation. The "as-built" plan shall be on 24-inch × 36-inch photo mylar and shall be signed and sealed by a professional engineer. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 18, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-156. - Responsibilities of permittee. 
    The permittee shall also be responsible for the following: 
(1)  Protection of utilities. The permittee shall be responsible for the prevention of damage to any public utility or service. 
(2)  Protection of adjacent property. The permittee is responsible for the prevention of damage to adjacent property. Excavation shall not occur sufficiently close to the property line to endanger any adjoining public street, sidewalk, utilities, or other public or private property, or easement, without protecting such property from damage which might result. 
(3)  Protection of public streets. The permittee is responsible for the regular removal of any mud or debris that is tracked in the public right-of-way resulting from vehicles and equipment entering and leaving the site. Regular removal shall mean by the end of every workday that the permittee is working at the construction site, before the permittee leaves the construction site. Failure to remove such mud or debris in accordance with the notice as provided in subsection (6) herein, shall be deemed to create a public nuisance which may be abated in accordance with Section 38-391, in addition to any other remedies provided by the Thornton City Code. 
(4)  [Protection of trees.] Protection of all trees designated on the approved grading plan to remain. 
(5)  Erosion, sediment, and dust control. The permittee shall be responsible to prevent discharge of sediment or dust from the site to any watercourse, drainage system, or adjacent property by implementing temporary and permanent BMPs and to protect from all damage that may result from wind, erosion, or sedimentation from the site. The permittee shall be responsible for maintenance of all temporary structural BMPs used to prevent discharge of sediment or dust from the site until final stabilization of all disturbed areas. Permittee shall promptly remove any temporary BMPs after final stabilization. 
(6)  [Remedies.] If any of the above items are not being carried out in a manner satisfactory to the city or in accordance with this section, the city shall provide notice to the permittee to correct the condition without delay. If the permittee does not adequately remedy the condition, the city may use the security deposit to remedy the condition and the permittee will have no claim or right to any of the funds spent for on-site or off-site mitigation efforts or to correct property damage, or the city may order all work stopped by order of the development engineering manager in accordance with Section 22-191. 
(7)  Advance notification. The permittee shall notify the development engineering manager at least 24 hours prior to the start of work. 
(8)  Transfer of permit. No permit issued under this article may be transferred or assigned in any manner without the approval of the development engineering manager. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2616, § 3, 7-10-00; Ord. No. 2656, § 19, 2-12-01; Ord. No. 2935, § 6, 1-10-06; Ord. No. 3210, § 5, 9-11-12) 
Secs. 22-157-22-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 22-161. - Excavations. 
    Excavations shall be constructed and protected so that they do not endanger life or property. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-162. - Excavation slope. 
    The slope of a cut surface or permanent excavations shall not be steeper than two horizontal to one vertical exclusive of terraces and exclusive of roundings described herein. Cut slopes shall be rounded into the existing terrain to produce contoured transitions from cut face to natural ground. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-163. - Fill placement. 
    Fills shall be constructed in layers. The loose thickness of each layer of fill material before compaction shall not exceed eight inches. Completed fills shall be stable masses of well-integrated material bonded to adjacent materials and to the materials on which they rest. Fills shall be competent to support anticipated loads and be stable at the design slopes shown on the approved plans. Proper drainage and other appropriate measures shall be taken to ensure the continuing integrity of the fills. Earth materials shall be used which have no more than minor amounts of organic substances and have no rock or similar irreducible material with a maximum dimension greater than six inches. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-164. - Fill compaction. 
    All fills, except when supporting a roadway, sidewalk, utilities, or retaining structure, shall be compacted throughout their full extent to a minimum of 90 percent of maximum density as determined by appropriate ASTM standard method or other alternate methods approved by the development engineering manager. Fills supporting roadways, sidewalks, or retaining structures shall be compacted to 95 percent of maximum density. Tests to determine the density of compacted fills shall be made on the basis of not less than one test for each two-foot vertical lift of the fill but not less than one test for each 1,000 cubic yards of material placed. All tests shall be reasonably uniformly distributed within the fill or fill slope surface. Results of such testing and the location of the tests shall be presented in the final report. Compaction may be less than 90 percent within six inches of a slope surface when such material is placed and compacted by a method approved by the development engineering manager for the planting of the slopes. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 20, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-165. - Ground preparation. 
    The natural ground surface shall be prepared to receive fill by removing vegetation, noncomplying fill, top soil, and other unsuitable material, and where slopes are five horizontal to one vertical, by benching into competent material in a manner acceptable to the development engineering manager. The bench under the toe of the fill shall be at least ten feet wide. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 21, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-166. - Fill slopes. 
    The slope of permanent fills shall not be steeper than two horizontal to one vertical exclusive of terraces or roundings described herein. The development engineering manager may require that the fill be constructed with an exposed surface flatter than two to one or may require other measures deemed necessary for stability or safety. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 22, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-167. - Protection of adjacent structures. 
    Footings which may be affected by any excavation shall be underpinned or otherwise protected against settlement or lateral movement. Fills or other surcharge loads shall not be placed adjacent to any building or structure unless the building or structure is capable of withstanding the loads caused by the fill or surcharge. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-168. - Setbacks. 
    Cut and fill slopes shall be set back from site boundaries in accordance with this section. Setback dimensions shall be horizontal distances measured perpendicular to the site boundary. Setback dimensions shall be as shown in Figure 22-1. 
(1)  Top of cut slope. The setback may need to be increased for any additional interceptor drains. 
(2)  Toe of fill slope. Where a fill slope is to be located near a site boundary and the adjacent off-site property is developed, special precautions shall be incorporated in the work as the development engineering manager deems necessary to protect the adjoining property from damage as a result of such grading. These precautions may include but are not limited to: 
a.  Additional setbacks; 
b.  Provisions for retaining or slough walls; 
c.  Mechanical or chemical treatment of the fill slope to minimize erosion; 
d.  Provisions for the control of surface waters. 
  

Figure No. 22-1 
(Ord. No. 2656, § 23, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-169. - Drainage. 
    All drainage facilities shall be designed in accordance to the provisions of Chapter 400, "Storm Drainage Design and Technical Criteria," of the Standards and Specifications. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-170. - Terracing. 
(a)  Terraces at least six feet in width shall be established at not more than 25 feet in height intervals for all cut and fill slopes exceeding 30 feet in height. Where only one terrace is required it shall be approximately mid-height. Suitable access shall be provided to permit proper cleaning and maintenance. 
(b)  Swales or ditches on terraces shall have a minimum gradient of five percent and shall be paved with reinforced concrete not less than three inches thick or an approved equal paving. The swale or ditch shall have a minimum depth of one foot and a minimum width of five feet. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-171. - Erosion control. 
    Erosion control shall conform to the provisions in Section 412, "Control of Erosion and Sedimentation from Construction," of the Standards and Specifications. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Secs. 22-172-22-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - EROSION CONTROL SURETY 

Sec. 22-181. - Surety required. 
    The applicant shall provide surety, as defined in the agreements described below, for erosion/sedimentation control, periodic removal of mud and debris from public rights-of-way, as set forth in Section 22-156, and revegetation of the site prior to issuance of a grading permit. If a developer's agreement has not been executed prior to issuance of a grading permit the applicant shall enter into an agreement for issuance of a grading permit with the city. This agreement shall be in the form provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2616, § 4, 7-10-00) 
Secs. 22-182-22-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 22-191. - Suspension or revocation of permit. 
(a)  The development engineering manager may suspend or revoke a permit for good cause, subject to appeal to the building code advisory board. 
(b)  The development engineering manager may, in order to protect against an immediate threat to the public health and safety, or after the permittee's failure to comply with a notice of violation under [Section] 22-156, order work stopped until such time as the violation is corrected. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2616, § 5, 7-10-00; Ord. No. 2656, § 23, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-192. - Appeals. 
(a)  Definition. Whenever in this article reference is made to an appeal from any written ruling or administrative decision, the building code advisory board shall be the appellate body so designated whether it shall be styled as the board of appeals, housing appeals and advisory board, or by any other name. Hereinafter, in this section, the building code advisory board shall be referred to as the board. 
(b)  Organization. The board shall consist of five members, in accordance with the Building Code, Chapter 10, of the City Code, appointed by the mayor and city council. The board shall adopt reasonable rules and regulations for conducting its deliberations. 
(c)  Right of appeal. Any aggrieved person, firm, or corporation may appeal any final, written decision of the director or development engineering manager to the board. 
(d)  Application. Application for a hearing before the board shall be made on forms designated for such purpose. These forms shall be made available in the office of the city development department and shall be available to the public upon request. 
(e)  Fee. Each application for a hearing before the board shall be accompanied by a fee in an amount that shall be determined from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(f)  Time limit. Any final written decision of the director or development engineering manager shall be subject to appeal for 30 days. No appeal shall be accepted or heard if it is filed after that date. 
(g)  Scope of authority. The board shall have the authority to review any written final decisions of the director or development engineering manager when such decisions are based on the provisions of this article. The board shall not have the authority to review decisions based on the Development Code. The board may determine the suitability of alternate methods and materials and may review other matters which may properly come before the board, except that the board shall not have the authority to recommend decreasing public safety set forth in any section of this article. Where specific materials or method types of construction are required, such requirements shall be the minimum requirements; and any materials or method types of construction, which will afford an equal or greater degree of safety as specified within this article, may be recommended. 
(h)  Meetings. After the application has been filed and the fee has been paid, the development engineering manager shall notify the chairman of the board, who shall arrange a hearing as promptly as possible but in no case more than 15 days after the completion of the filing of the application, including the payment of fees. 
(i)  Evidence. The appellant and the department shall be given the opportunity to present evidence to the board. 
(j)  Decision. The decision of the board shall be final. This shall be binding on the city. 
(Ord. No. 2656, § 25, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-193. - Compliance required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to perform any grading on, or alter, maintain or use, any land area in violation of any provision of this article. 
(b)  No permit, certificate, license, or other document or oral approval, the use of which is subject to the provisions of these regulations, shall be issued by any department, agency, or board until it has been determined that all substantive requirements have been met and all procedures have been followed. 
(c)  Offenses committed and all liabilities incurred prior to the effective date of any subsequent amendments to this article shall be treated as though all prior applicable regulations were in full force and effect for the purpose of sustaining any suit, action, or prosecution with respect to such offenses and liabilities. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-194. - Injunctive relief. 
    In the event of a violation or violations of this article, or of any lawful rules or regulations promulgated hereunder, the city or any person affected by such violation or violations may institute proceedings to halt the same, notwithstanding the exercise of any other remedy or charge of article violation hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-195. - Corrective work. 
(a)  Abatement of unlawfully created conditions. 
(1)  The development engineering manager may authorize city crews or authorized contractors to enter private property to immediately abate a hazardous public nuisance. 
Whenever the following conditions are created by violation of this article, they are hereby declared to be in the category of hazardous public nuisance: 
a.  Where a violation has altered natural drainage patterns and has caused, or may potentially cause, flooding to any downstream property; or 
b.  Whenever a violation results in a hazard, that requires immediate correction for the preservation of the public health, safety, or welfare. 
(2)  Whenever the city is required to take action and expend any funds or takes any action, the city shall bill the landowner, lessee or licensee for the costs indicated herein. The following costs shall be billed: 
a.  Engineering and design. 
b.  Contractor service bills or city employee wages or salary at cost. 
c.  Administration overhead and supervision based on ten percent of all costs incurred. 
(b)  Stop work notice. 
(1)  If any person performs work in violation of the provisions of this article or without a permit as required by this article, the development engineering manager may serve upon such person a written order citing such violations and directing that person to stop work immediately. 
(2)  Upon receipt of such stop work notice the person performing the work shall: 
a.  Stop work immediately; and 
b.  Within 24 hours provide the development engineering manager with a list of remedies which can be immediately undertaken to bring the work into compliance with this article; and 
c.  Within 24 hours after acceptance by the development engineering manager of such remedies undertake, at the violator's expense, such action as necessary to bring the work into compliance with this article. 
d.  Upon failure of any person to comply with the stop work notice served pursuant to this section, the city may cause the corrective work to be performed. All persons responsible for the violation shall be liable jointly and severally to the city for the cost of such corrective work. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2656, § 26, 2-12-01) 
Sec. 22-196. - Violation. 
    It shall be unlawful: 
(1)  For any person to do or perform, or cause to be done or performed, any act or thing prohibited by the terms of this article, or prohibited by any lawful orders or regulations issued pursuant to any of the provisions hereof; 
(2)  For any person to fail to do or perform or cause to be omitted or not performed any act or thing required to be done by this article, or any lawful regulation or order issued under any of the provisions hereof. If any person, including but not limited to the officers and agents of a corporation responsible for its actions or inaction, and the partners, or members of a partnership, firm or joint venture, shall violate or cause the violation of any of the provisions of this article, they and each of them shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which a violation is committed, permitted, or continues. Upon conviction thereof, any person including but not limited to such partners, members, officers, or agents, shall be subject only to the fines provided for in Section 1-8 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 22-197. - Severability. 
    Should any section or provision of this article be declared by the courts to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of this article as a whole, or any part thereof, other than the part to be declared to be unconstitutional or invalid. 
(Ord. No. 2433, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Chapter 26 - FINANCE AND TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes:

Charter reference- Finance generally, Ch. IX; taxation, Ch. X; municipal borrowing, Ch. XI. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Home rule powers, Col. Const. Art. XX, § 6; municipal finance generally, C.R.S. § 31-15-301 et seq.; municipal taxation, C.R.S. § 31-20-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Conservation trust fund. 
(a)  A conservation trust fund is created pursuant to state law. The city has taken all actions necessary to qualify for distribution of state moneys allocated to conservation trust fund purposes. 
(b)  Any moneys received from the state for conservation trust fund purposes shall be deposited in the conservation trust fund and shall be expended, upon direction of the city council, only in accordance with the provisions of applicable state law. 
(Code 1975, §§ 5-122, 5-123; Ord. No. 705, 12-22-75; Ord. No. 2308, §§ 32, 33, 2-28-94) 
Secs. 26-2-26-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UNCLAIMED PERSONAL PROPERTY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Lost, unclaimed or abandoned property, § 38-61 et seq.; abandoned, inoperable or unsafe motor vehicles, § 38-421 et seq. 

Sec. 26-26. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for the administration and disposition of unclaimed property which is in the possession of or under the control of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 7A-1; Ord. No. 2102, 8-26-91; Ord. No. 2172, 6-22-92) 
Sec. 26-27. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Depositor means an entity which has deposited funds in escrow with the city, including a corporation, partnership, association, person or a duly authorized legal representative or successor in interest of such. 
    Director means the city finance director. 
    Owner means a person, including but not limited to a corporation, partnership, association, governmental entity other than the city, or a duly authorized legal representative or successor in interest of such, who owns any unclaimed property held by the city. 
    Unclaimed property means: 
(1)  Any intangible property, including any income or increment derived therefrom, less any lawful charges, held by or under the control of the city, and which has not been claimed by its owner or depositor for a period of more than one year after it became payable or distributable. Also included in this definition of unclaimed property is property held in a safe deposit box or any other safekeeping repository by the city which remains unclaimed by the owner for more than one year after the lease or rental period on the box or other repository has expired. Unclaimed, abandoned or seized motor vehicles are excluded from this article, as such property is governed by this Code. Municipal code bond forfeitures are also excluded, as such bonds are subject to the provisions of the Colorado Municipal Court Rules. 
(2)  In addition to property included in the definition of intangible property in C.R.S. § 38-13-102, intangible property shall also include but shall not be limited to: deposits for water, electricity, gas or cable TV service; overpayments on water, electricity, gas or cable TV service; street cut permit deposits; developer cost recovery agreements; monies unclaimed by beneficiaries in a pension fund; unredeemed gift certificates for recreation center services; uncashed payroll checks; bonds posted for reasons other than for municipal courts; lost and found money turned into the city; and uncashed court ordered restitution payments. 
(3)  Any negotiable tender, money orders, checks or drafts which have been deposited in escrow with city to ensure the depositor's compliance with city's ordinances, resolutions, regulations, other applicable law or agreements with city or to ensure that the city is reimbursed for any damages the city might sustain as a result of depositor's activities. 
(4)  Any unclaimed property described in subsections (1), (2) or (3) of this definition for which: 
a.  Performance of the obligations which the unclaimed property is to secure has been completed; 
b.  Performance of the obligations which the unclaimed property is to secure has not been completed and the time for such performance has expired pursuant to applicable law or agreement; or 
c.  The applicable law or agreement does not specify the time during which the performance is to be completed, and the director has either determined that performance of the secured obligations has not been commenced within a reasonable period of time following the deposit of the unclaimed property, or that performance of the secured obligations has not resumed within a reasonable period of time following the suspension of such performance. 
(Code 1975, § 7A-2; Ord. No. 2102, 8-26-91; Ord. No. 2172, 6-22-92; Ord. No. 2363, § 1, 1-9-95) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-28. - Procedure for disposition of funds. 
(a)  Under this article, the director shall dispose of funds by sending a written notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of any depositor or owner who has unclaimed property, as defined in Section 26-27, which is in the possession of the city and has been unclaimed for at least one year. 
(b)  The last known address of the depositor or owner shall be the last address of the depositor or owner as shown by the records of the city department with which the unclaimed property is held. 
(c)  The notice shall advise the depositor or owner of the type of unclaimed property, the date on which the city came into the possession of the unclaimed property, and the reason the unclaimed property is being held by the city. The notice shall also state that if the depositor or owner fails to provide the director with a written claim for the return of the unclaimed property within 30 days from the date of the notice, the unclaimed property shall become the sole property of city, to be utilized as it deems appropriate. 
(d)  If the depositor or owner did not receive the notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, notice shall also be published, pursuant to Section 2-1, 30 consecutive days. The notice shall state that if the depositor or owner fails to provide the director with a written claim for the return of the unclaimed property within 30 days from the date of the last publication of the notice, the unclaimed property shall become the sole property of city, to be utilized as it deems appropriate. 
(e)  If the director receives no written claim within the 30-day claim period as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, the unclaimed property shall become the sole property of city, and any claim of the depositor or owner to such unclaimed property shall be deemed abandoned. 
(f)  If the director receives a written claim within the 30-day claim period, the unclaimed property shall be returned to such claimant, unless the claim fails to clearly establish the claimant's right to such unclaimed property. The director shall be under no obligation to investigate the validity of a claim but may, in the director's sole discretion, request further supporting documentation from the claimant prior to the return of the unclaimed property. 
(g)  In the event that there is more than one claimant for the same unclaimed property, the director may, in the director's sole discretion, resolve such claim by depositing the disputed unclaimed property with the registry of the county district court in an interpleader action. 
(h)  In the event that all claims filed are denied, the unclaimed property shall become the sole property of the city, to be utilized as it deems appropriate. If any legal action is timely filed, the unclaimed property shall be returned pursuant to the order of the court having jurisdiction over such claim. 
(i)  The director is authorized and directed to establish and administer procedures for the disposition of unclaimed property pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1975, § 7A-3; Ord. No. 2102, 8-26-91; Ord. No. 2172, 6-22-92; Ord. No. 2363, § 2, 1-9-95; Ord. No. 3392, § 13, 8-9-16; Ord. No. 3476, §§ 14, 7-10-18) 
Secs. 26-29-26-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PURCHASING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-56. - Short title. 
    This article may be known and cited as the Thornton Purchasing Ordinance. 
(Code 1975, § 10-2; Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 5-8-95) 
Sec. 26-57. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bid means any form of competitive solicitation of offers. 
    Business means any corporation, partnership, individual, sole proprietorship, joint stock company, joint venture, or any other private legal entity. 
    Change order means a written order signed by the city manager directing the contractor to make changes which the changes clause of the contract authorizes the city manager to order without the consent of the contractor. 
    Competitive sealed bidding means a process used to acquire supplies and services that involves the review of written sealed bids presented by bidders for contracts exceeding $50,000.00. Such bids include the use of public notices and may be awarded on the basis of the criteria contained in the bid documents. 
    Confidential information means any information which is available to an employee only because of the employee's status as an employee of this city and which is not a matter of public knowledge or available to the public on request. 
    Construction means the process of building, altering, repairing, improving, or demolishing any public structure or building or other public improvements of any kind to any public real property.
